body:
Looking for fun and educational science programmes for corporate groups or families? Look no further as Science Centre Singapore offers various interactive 2-hour science family programmes, covering topics such as physics, chemistry and the popular gastronomy!

Check out our list of family programmes –

CHEM YOU MAGIC?

Recommended Age: 7 – 12 years old

Available in English and Mandarin

Is it magic or chemistry? Join us on this magical learning adventure as you learn more about chemical reactions that will blow you away! Activities include coloured fire demonstration, dancing raisins, red cabbage indicator and moving portrait.

BREAD BAKING AFFAIR

Recommended Age: 7 – 12 years old

Available in English

Did you know that bacteria and fungi have been helping us to make delicious food? Uncover the secrets of fermentation through fun experiments and bread baking!

SATURDAY LIGHT FEVER

Recommended Age: 7 – 12 years old

Available in English

Be amazed by the wonders of light! Learn some tricks with light, make your own kaleidoscope and create art with photosensitive paper while learning about the concepts of light.

UNBE-LEAF-ABLE PLANTS

Recommended Age: 7 – 12 years old

Available in English

Learn more about growing plants and take home a mini-ecosystem that is self-sustaining!

BOBALOGY

Recommended Age: 7 – 12 years old

Available in English and Mandarin

Are you a bubble tea lover? Sign up for our Bobalogy programme and get ready for a treat! Discover the secrets behind this popular drink and learn how to make your very own pearls.

STATELY MATTERS

Recommended Age: 7 – 12 years old

Available in English

Do states matter? Be prepared to have your mind blown as we take you on a journey to understand the different states of matter using gas rockets, water and other whacky creations! In this programme, you will also learn to create hydrogel, lava lamp, obleck and gas rockets.

NEWTON'S ACROBATS

Recommended Age: 7 – 12 years old

Available in English and Mandarin

Watch little toys tumble, rock and roll with the help of gravity!

LED’S PLAY

Recommended Age: 7 – 12 years old

Available in English

In this programme, you will learn more about electricity and circuits, and get to bring home your very own LED light-up card!

KITCHEN HACKS

Recommended Age: 7 – 12 years old

Available in English

Join our Science Educators as we whip up delicious meals using secret military technology! Plus, learn the science behind microwaves and the safety features of an oven that protect us from potential dangers.

DNA & FAMILY TRAITS

Recommended Age: 7 – 14 years old

Available in English and Mandarin

Discover the functions of DNA in our lives as well as the different traits that have shaped our family trees. Led by a Science Educator, you will also learn to extract DNA from cells and create your very own DNA model in this progamme!

For more information, visit our website here. Should you have any enquiries, do drop us an email at fp_enquiries@science.edu.sg.

description: From uncovering the traits in your family tree to whipping a delectable boba tea and creating your very own lava lamp, our Science Educators have prepared a plethora of interesting family programmes available for family or corporate bookings.
name: Family Science Programmes at Science Centre Singapore
notes: For more information on the Centre's hours, visit https://www.science.edu.sg/visit-us/opening-hours.

reviews.text: A great place for science enthusiasts! The shows are really great. The one I saw was on automation and robotics, I really loved it! If you are going on a trip to Singapore, please pay a visit to this amazing place.

Great for educational trips. Very Clean and exciting attractions! A replica of the famous Tesla Coil is showcased there. There is also an area for the kids (KidStop) if I recall. There is also monthly special themes like Insects and Dinosaur to Circus and Magic.

We went old school style, visiting the science centre! Not at all what we had 20 years ago but so glad it's still around and displaying so many science projects and displays of cool science tricks. My 6yo and 3yo definitely loved it. Omni theatre was breathtaking! So lucky it was a free entrance for Singaporeans during off peak period. Just pay for omnitheatre or the kidstop or other specialised exhibitions.

Great place to visit. So much to do and the kids had an amazing time. The 3 hour sessions due to Covid-19 are not enough to do everything so we will definitely be back. The mirror maze was a favourite with our 1yo, and our 7yo loved seeing the Tesla coil even though it wasn't running.

A cool place to learn science. It is convenient for people to visit this place as it is only a 10 minutes walk from the station. There are many topics of science being covered in this centre and has many school outreach programmes to allow students to grasp complicated science concepts.

body: ArtScience Museum™
description: Art, science, culture and technology intersect at the world’s first ArtScience Museum™, a lotus-shaped building located within the integrated resort of Marina Bay Sands®. Major international touring exhibitions have passed through, thanks to collaborations with the likes of the Natural History Museum of London, Japanese art collective teamLab, and jewellery brand Van Cleef & Arpels.
name: ArtScience Museum™

reviews.text: Filled with fun activities for kids! A great way to spend your afternoon if you're looking for something to do with your kids. Its not too crowded on weekdays. So that's really good.

Fun place for kids to play and interact with the exhibits. Well crowd control and good time spent inside. Kids could play color balls that changes color as they spin, color and scan sea animals into the giant wall display. Color and scan cars to the giant wall to see them transported by alien spaceship to the roads. Definitely full of fun for children.
When I went there with my friends while evening time so excited nice view thanks Singapore

Amazing pictures! must seeing destinations in SG! great experience!

I love that place since Im a big art fan!  And i like to take a good looking pictures!  I always will recommend this place to my friends!

Dont forget to check it out the indoor place at marina bay sands. Somehow  most of my friends didnt do it!

You have a huge discount  if you are staying in Singapore so ask one of your local friends!

enjoy!

Amazing Museum! The place overall architectural design is great.The exhibit is a great chance to expose yourself to current technologies. You can interact with the various shows inside the room. Inside Future World is relatively dark so if you want to snap pictures, make sure that your camera are capable of capturing great photos in low light mode.

admissionInfo:
Our standard 2 hour workshop package is $55 per pax. Participants will create their own mini-batik painting and will take it home as a souvenir.

We also cater to couple, families, tour, corporate teambuilding groups and with customization.
body: Batik is a traditional cloth originating from Java that is part of our intangible cultural heritage. It was also a popular medium with pioneer artists depicting lives in the early years of Singapore. Kamal Arts Studio at Geylang Serai is specialist in this ancient technique of using wax to decorate fabric into a contemporary art medium. Immerse yourself in experience of making your very own batik painting with traditional tools to bring home as souvenir. Be inspired by the batik art on display and soak in the atmosphere of the Malay market nearby.
description: Immerse yourself in experience of making your very own batik painting with traditional tools to bring home as souvenir.
name: Batik Painting Art Experience

reviews.text: Amazing place for art lessons and birthday parties! They also offer student care services🖌🎊😁🍀
Great place to learn hands-on arts and crafts. Wonderful and friendly teachers :)
Good environment, excellent place to have arts for kids! Highly recommend.
Great art studio for kids✨ They offer art classes, camps, student care, & even birthday parties! 🥳🎨
Very nice place for art classes & parties

body: Next to Chinatown Complex, Banda Street also sports various street art, part of the 2015 Colouring Banda Street project by PwC and Tanjong Pagar Town Council. On the side of a staircase is Welcome to our World. It depicts Samsui women, the hardworking women who carried out construction jobs and helped build Singapore. It also features the Aranda Lee Kuan Yew and Vanda Kwa Geok Choo, a tribute to Singapore’s first prime minister and his wife.
description: Next to Chinatown Complex, Banda Street also sports various street art, part of the 2015 Colouring Banda Street project by PwC and Tanjong Pagar Town Council. On the side of a staircase is Welcome to our World. It depicts Samsui women, the hardworking women who carried out construction jobs and helped build Singapore. It also features the Aranda Lee Kuan Yew and Vanda Kwa Geok Choo, a tribute to Singapore’s first prime minister and his wife.
name: Samsui Art Mural

admissionInfo: Free
body: Established in 2011, Goodman Arts Centre, located in the culturally rich Mountbatten district in the east, is a hub for theatre, dance, literary and visual arts. This centre is set within old-school buildings and houses over 40 arts groups. It has shared facilities, such as a music studio and an amphitheatre, which are available for rent to the arts community. It regularly hosts exhibitions, performances and family-friendly workshops, where visitors can learn different skills such as ceramic arts, singing and contemporary or cultural dances. Workshops require registration, and charges apply. Visitors can also enjoy a meal at casual dining restaurant Café Melba (www.cafemelba.com.sg), while young ones are sure to enjoy the games and activities available at Cafe Melba’s activities corner, outdoor lawn and bouncy castle.
description: Set within old school buildings, this performing and visual arts centre allows visitors to learn different skills, such as batik wax technique. Besides workshops, it regularly hosts exhibitions and performances, and visitors can dine at two restaurants set admist lush greenery.
name: Goodman Arts Centre
notes: Except dining establishments

reviews.text:
Easy parking, very well maintained premises. Particularly liked the artistically done paint combinations, gave a nice feel good effect

Well maintained restrooms, lovely cafe on sprawling premises

Going past the pottery section made you feel welcome. They have pieces outside and a sign invites you to pick up anything you may like, for free, and save it from landfill. Nice

An amazing venue for bringing artists and students of the arts.
Its also a great place to bring your young kids to during the weekend. The artground within the art center is a nice indoor artsy play area for the kids.
Free play area for children is meaningfully designed to cater to the motor skills of young children of various age groups.
A lot of art things going on. Can explore the available classes. The cafe seems nice too.
My boy is in love with this place, will definitely recommend parents out there to bring your children here. Very artistically decorated place.
Inclusive Arts Space....Thumbs Up!
Good place same like a name

admissionInfo: SAM museum buildings on Bras Basah Road and Queen Street are currently closed for redevelopment and upgrading works. Find out more about SAM's current Art Exhibitions & Events at partner venues and spaces here: https://www.singaporeartmuseum.sg/art-events
body: The Singapore Art Museum (SAM) has a great collection of contemporary art from the region. It has showcased a variety of paintings, sculptures & art installations by various artists. Its permanent gallery, Once Upon This Island, comprises works by 12 Singapore-based artists that explore what it means to live in this contemporary city-state. Travellers can also visit SAM at 8Q, a wing of the museum located across the road, to see the Moving Image Gallery, where film screenings are held. There are cafés and restaurants for visitors to have a meal after art appreciation.
description: A former boy’s mission school, the museum is home to a collection of contemporary art from the region, including works by 12 Singapore-based artists.
name: Singapore Art Museum
nearestMrtStation: Bras Basah Station / Dhoby Ghaut Station
notes: Closed for redevelopment.

pricing.others: Adult: S$10, Senior Citizen: S$5; Free admission for Children

reviews.text: This is such a graceful museum that has been tastefully restored to house a wonderful collection of general and cultural. This building was once the Singapore seat of rule and law and its historic past can be imagined on the lawns at the front. If you like a gallery...you'll love a visit here. I spent a day wandering through both buildings and had a very restful time soaking up the art. Take a break with tea and tea and finish off with a cocktails in the upper bar and breathe in the view before you.

Really good and interesting museum. It explains more about the history of Singapore but in an interactive way. All the digital experience is amazing! I loved the cinema!

The building is nice and their staff is friendly.

If visiting Singapore is definitely worth to visit.
Fantastic museum. I still remember a small exhibition on such a mundane thing as Hainanese Chicken Rice: it gave an incredibly interesting reflection on the cultural and ethnic mix of Singapore.
Most of the part is free to visit only some part u need to pay...good information about singapore history .they use,put  sound and physical visible things to understand history

This place is worth a visit,, if you haven't visited this place yet this is a must try. This is the place where you can explore the history of Singapore through digital presentation, exhibits and more. It's always good to know our history.

body: As Singapore’s first independent venue for experimental contemporary arts, this is where local art lovers come for edgy performances and alternative art shows, from dance, theatre and music to literature and visual arts. Founded in 1990, it was built in a former power substation—hence, its name. Dance classes and theatre workshops are also held here (visit the website for more information). Don’t miss Timbre® (timbregroup.asia/timbresg/timbre-thesubstation), the bar and bistro in The Substation’s open-air garden, which hosts live-music gigs till late every night.
description: Singapore's pioneer contemporary arts centre known for working with some of Singapore's most respected artists.
name: The Substation

reviews.text: Artsy place if you are in to art
Nice environment with wide walkway
Substation has been around for as long as I can remember as a teenager and it's a place to visit if you are looking for something different in the arts! A sub-culture if you will. :)
Great facility would come back again for sure.
The most authentic and sincere performance space in Singapore

body: Come together for events and seasonal exhibitions at Esplanade. Iconically shaped like the King of Fruits (durian), Esplanade is home to the vibrant local arts scene and is Singapore’s current national performing arts centre.
description: Come together for events and seasonal exhibitions at Esplanade. Iconically shaped like the King of Fruits (durian), Esplanade is home to the vibrant local arts scene and is Singapore’s current national performing arts centre.
name: Esplanade - Theatres on the Bay

reviews.text: A very unique structure for theater. You can enjoy the art of acting and there are time you can enjoy the music performed by professional musicians. Both interior and exterior were both amazing! Love the architecture, atmosphere and coziness in there. Love the night lights! And there are some restaurants in and outside the building.

Been my hangout every week with my dancemates, especially on Friday and weekends evenings when there are gigs here! You'd love love love it as well if you, like me, enjoy the feeling of being immersed in the musical vibes! Really lovely at night with the one you love as well 😊😊

Esplanade is a durian shaped theatre on the river bank of Singapore, along with many other landmarks of modern Singapore. The look & feel of this art center from near vs far differs so we did enjoy our walk from afar towards the building itself.

Amazing performance by the legend Einaudi Ludovico at the Esplanade, Singapore in January this year.  The theatre is a terrific venue to host world class performances ... looking forward to catch up more in near future.

The Esplande. It is nice to take a slow walk and enjoy the view. It is so modern with all the skyscrapers. Let me bring you to the old Esplanade it was name Queen Elizabeth walk nothing much to see. As you walk from across the Bridge from the G.P.O. (Fullerton Five Star Hotel now) you can see from afar a big U shape. A place for eating. There was a Stay Club at the end, Noddle Stall, other Food Stalls and also drink Stall. They have Square shining tables and chairs very light to carry. We all have our dinner under the stars. We can see the ships far from our shore. There were many small bum boats near Clifford Pier. After our meal we took a slow walk at Queen Elizabeth walk again and than we go home.

body: This Cantonese clan association was established in 1839 at Upper Chin Chew Street and moved in 1924 to the present building, designed by Westerhout & Oman. During the Japanese Occupation, the custodians volunteered the building as a clinic and hence its antique interiors remained intact. The association is well known for its lion dance troupe and martial arts. This is one of Chinatown's first community museums and entry is free.
description: This Cantonese clan association was established in 1839 at Upper Chin Chew Street and moved in 1924 to the present building, designed by Westerhout & Oman. During the Japanese Occupation, the custodians volunteered the building as a clinic and hence its antique interiors remained intact. The association is well known for its lion dance troupe and martial arts. This is one of Chinatown's first community museums and entry is free.
name: Kong Chow Wui Koon 冈州会馆

reviews.text: Very rich historical n cultural contents. Must visit to understand more of the immigrants from China century ago.
One of the very few clans in Singapore to have their own beautiful building. There are activities in evey week. Free to visit as well.
Great place to learn martial arts,lion dance and Chinese culture, the best of all, it is free!
My kids practised their weekly lion dance, they love it here!
A good place to learn Cantonese!

body: Tucked behind the building that houses Kilo Lounge and the Yoga Movement — 21 Tanjong Pagar Street, to be exact — are playful paintings of a sepoy (guard), pagar (gate), singa (lion), stamp, and even a nutmeg plant, a nod to the building’s heritage, a former nutmeg plantation.
description: Tucked behind the building that houses Kilo Lounge and the Yoga Movement — 21 Tanjong Pagar Street, to be exact — are playful paintings of a sepoy (guard), pagar (gate), singa (lion), stamp, and even a nutmeg plant, a nod to the building’s heritage, a former nutmeg plantation.
name: Nutmeg Mural by Ripple Root

body: Found in an alleyway between Smith Street and Temple Street, the mural depicts scenes from inside a Chinatown shop house. There are so many details to admire – from the simple wooden platform furniture to the kids playing with a paper sword to the spread of food on the dining table. The 2019 mural evokes plenty of nostalgia and features many household items that were once common place just two or three generations ago.
description: Found in an alleyway between Smith Street and Temple Street, the mural depicts scenes from inside a Chinatown shop house. There are so many details to admire – from the simple wooden platform furniture to the kids playing with a paper sword to the spread of food on the dining table. The 2019 mural evokes plenty of nostalgia and features many household items that were once common place just two or three generations ago.
name: My Chinatown Home Mural

body: Street barbers used to be a common sight, operating mainly out of makeshift sheds with walls of wooden planks, and wooden roofs or awnings along the alleys of Chinatown. As lifestyle changes, these traditional street barbers faced stiff competition from hair salons. Street barbers are almost non-existent today except for an odd stall or two.
description: Street barbers used to be a common sight, operating mainly out of makeshift sheds with walls of wooden planks, and wooden roofs or awnings along the alleys of Chinatown. As lifestyle changes, these traditional street barbers faced stiff competition from hair salons. Street barbers are almost non-existent today except for an odd stall or two.
name: Barber Chair 3D Floor Sticker

body: Channel your inner artist and sign up for a pottery class at Mud Rock Ceramics, where you can learn techniques in ceramics such as coiling, throwing and glazing. It's also the perfect opportunity to bring your date along and spend some quality time.
description: Handmade ceramics workshops
name: Mud Rock Ceramics
notes: By appointment only.

reviews.text: Lovely ceramics, classes, atmosphere, people & pup! Well organized classes.

Really enjoyed my workshop with Michelle and Seok. They’re wonderful teachers sharing their love and enthusiasm in a great setting. Highly recommend this studio! And don’t forget to give Buddy a pat 😉

I just finished my beginners course and boy I loved it. First of all, the place is gorgeous - very neat, hipster and well equipped. The course itself is structured so well, giving you a taste of all aspects of pottery, from hand building to throwing, trimming and glazing. Highly recommend it 👍🏼
Excellent place, very courteous and helpful owner. Loads of creativity evident in the displays.
Great place with great people! Took classes here and still coming regularly, years later :)

body: This creative workshop and contemporary gallery focuses on promoting artistic experimentation in the mediums of print and paper media. Centred on artist collaborations, visiting artists are hosted at STPI’s guests quarters and are frequently invited to give public talks to share their inspirations and experiences with the public. Past collaborations include exhibitions such as ‘Fragments From A Collective Unity’ by Aaron Curry from the United States in 2017 and ‘Freely Freely’ by local artist, Jane Lee in 2015. At its retail space, STPI x The Corner Shop, visitors can purchase artworks produced by artists in collaboration with the STPI Creative Workshop, scholarly art catalogues, STPI merchandise and creative magazines.
description: An internationally renowned space for conceptual developments in contemporary art practice in print and paper.
name: STPI – Creative Gallery & Workshop
notes: Closed on Public Holidays

reviews.text: Such an inspiring team! continue guys!
Nice place to work.
greAt gallery was here for murakami
Extremely interesting. Very well worth the visit.
Amazing place! So nicely designed when there was Cartier's showcase.

admissionInfo: Admission ticket of $6.40 for visitors aged 7 years and above. Free admission for children aged 6 and below.
body: Sneak a preview of the future with over 200 award winning futuristic design concepts from top designers across the globe. All of them, winners of the Red Dot Award for Design Concept, one of the toughest design competitions in the world. Only the best are on showcase. After visiting the galleries, shop at the design museum shop where you can buy carefully curated design objects from around the world and also those produce by Singapore designers. Dine at the museum cafe that features unique local deserts.
description: Visit one of the top design museums in the World and check out over 200 futuristic design ideas from across the globe
name: Red Dot Design Museum - A Preview of the Future Exhibition

reviews.text:
This is a small museum where you can see some interesting and futuristic creations. It is not so expensive, at least the entry.
I had the  best tea I had ever tasted there, the staff is very friendly.
I wanted to buy something from the shop there, but everything was quite expensive, but that was not shocking, because most of the objects were original and you cant buy them anywhere else.
In the end, if you have plenty of time in Singapore, if you dont mind to spend some dollars for tickets and if you are interested in design and modernity, it is definitely worth your time.

Re-explore & re-discover Singapore. This is a 'must' visit place. Some design pieces made you look at things in a different perspective. Enjoyed the time there & love the lighting design in the museum. Thanks to Carrie & Raudha for the great hospitality!

A very interesting museum! Definitely a must-go spot if you’re enjoying visiting museums! Entry fee is cheap and you get coupon if you purchase the entry ticket! Small but can offer you with insights and ideas!

It just lots of description of their rewarded items, nothing really you can touch or feel. Being a design museum I would expect the museum is also a show case but it's just a badly designed building and even the toilet was so badly designed that you need to open the toilet door by pulling the bag hanger!

Inspiring items. Great gift shop with tons of cool stuff for both kids and adults. Cafe very nice. The museum itself seems a bit small for the price. Easy to see everything in ten minutes. Entrance fee comes with a nice book filled with pictures and stories of all items. It would be nice to see more art and furniture designs. Too heavy on tech design.

body: Abdul Gafoor Mosque was built 112 years ago. Its walls are adorned with exquisite Arabic motifs and its panels feature beautiful Arabic calligraphy. Take note of how its magnificent green dome is surrounded by a ring of smaller minarets. This mosque is as much a place of worship as it is an architectural wonder.
description: Abdul Gafoor Mosque was built 112 years ago.
name: Abdul Gafoor Mosque

reviews.text:
The prayer hall is raised above the ground and surrounded with verandahs at the entrance and sides. It is oriented towards Mecca and thus skewed away from the lot lines and the street.
The verandahs are enclosed by a balustrade with circular and lancet-shaped openings and framed by repetitive cinquefoil arches double-framed with heavy mouldings. The bays are marked out with pilasters with ornate capitals. The wide openings give the interior an airiness that contrasts with the heavy columns in the centre of the prayer hall.
On either side of the main entrance are two graduated cinquefoil arched openings. The larger ones are nearest the entrance, while the smaller ones are further away.
The main entrance to the prayer hall is pedimented with an elaborate sundial in which the 25 rays of the sunburst are done in calligraphy. The sundial is flanked on either side by a series of pilasters and columns in miniature. The pediment above the sundial is shaped like an onion dome. The two square minarets on the left and right are complete with miniature columns and arches.
There are panels with calligraphic inscriptions in several places in the mosque, including over the entrance.
The interior of the cupola at the centre of the prayer hall is supported by four large cluster columns that form semicircular arches. Square and round calligraphic inscriptions decorate the interior of the cupola.
The cluster columns that hold up the cupola have elaborate mouldings and capitals.
From the exterior, the cupola emerges from the roof deck as a hexagonal-shaped tower that is divided into three levels and marked out with Doric pilasters.
On the first level of the tower are eight cinquefoil windows with coloured glass panes that let light through to the interior. These windows are ornamented with recessed mihrab-shaped moulding and cinquefoil arches.
The second level has pilasters and capitals and is topped by a balustrade with bottleneck balusters.
There are minarets at the corners of the hexagon. These minarets are crowned with onion-shaped domes with a crescent moon and a star at the pinnacle. The very centre of the hexagon is crowned with a large onion dome topped with a smaller onion dome. On the pinnacle is a star and crescent moon.
The corners of the front verandah have simpler and less elaborate cupolas.
The four corners of the building are anchored by large Corinthian columns in a cluster with elaborate capitals in a leaf design. The interior and exterior of the mosque have several types of columns and pilasters. They are both structural and ornamental and range from Doric to Corinthian. Columns can be paired with pilasters and pilasters are inset into columns.
The mihrab is plain. There is a narrow rectangular panel with a quotation from the Qur'an above it. Next to the mihrab is the minbar, a three-step timber staircase from which the imam leads prayers.
Above the prayer hall is a flat roof deck surrounded by a parapet wall with bottle-shaped balusters. It is topped with a line of 22 small six-level minarets crowned with onion domes, each with a crescent moon. The miniature minarets rise from the pilasters that frame the cinquefoil arched openings below
There is also a type of single-leafed window that is recessed and framed by an elaborate cinquefoil arch. It is flanked with pilasters and pedimented and has the same star-and-crescent pattern of the larger arched openings.
The ablution area in this mosque was originally a pool. This was later drained and a modern wash area put in. It is located outside at the southwest end of the mosque.
Currently mosque under reno. Men prayer hall at basement but good news its air conditioning. Looks near and tidy. May Allah make this Mosque a great mosque.
Very beautiful mosque 🕌 great architecture looks beautiful and get peaceful feelings. You can walk around or get up and enjoy panoramic views...
A beautiful masjid. Highly recommend Tamil people to come here for Jumaah. Open for visitors also, but remember to come in decent outfits!
Is a nice place of worship and you can get an coffee or tea just outside the most and local Indian delights

body: Teater Ekamatra was founded in 1988 to develop a form of experimental Malay theatre that fuses Southeast Asian theatre styles with contemporary techniques. Since then, the company has expanded its reach to both the Malay community and non-Malay audiences, focusing on general socio-political themes in its production.
description: Teater Ekamatra was founded in 1988 to develop a form of experimental Malay theatre that fuses Southeast Asian theatre styles with contemporary techniques.
name: Teater Ekamatra

body: Founded by Giles Dyan in 1994, Opera Gallery is one of the leading international dealers and representatives of modern and contemporary art, with galleries worldwide. Since its inception, Opera Gallery has been exhibiting an eclectic inventory of important works by countless modern and contemporary masters which include Pablo Picasso, Marc Chagall, Bernard Buffet, Alexander Calder, Jean Dubuffet, Lucio Fontana, Andy Warhol, Keith Haring, Fernando Botero and Pierre Soulages among many other key art figures. The gallery curates an extensive and varied programme of exhibitions, ensuring a fresh line-up for visitors to enjoy each time they visit.
description: The Opera Gallery is established worldwide with galleries displaying and dealing modern and contemporary art in New York, Miami, Aspen, London, Paris, Monaco, Geneva, Singapore, Hong Kong, Seoul, Beirut and Dubai.
name: Opera Gallery

reviews.text: Exciting Art gallery with cute but exquisite collection by a professional that respect and admire fine art. Love the inspiring sculpture and pictures. Conveniently located at neighbourhood of famous Orchard Road among luxurious hotels resorts shopping restaurants and amenities. Walking distance to Orchard MRT with plenty of dinning shopping banking supermarkets library cinemas entertainments groceries sundries postage services and amenities nearby. Friendly cosy comfy welcoming ambience for romantic intimates groups students expats locals visitors and families.

The Opera Gallery is one of the very few galleries in Singapore which can boast of well known European artists like Picasso, Marc Chagall, Fernando Bottero etc. The gallery is located in the busy shopping area of Orchard road and easily accessible. The exhibits are well spaced and is a good experience.
It's beautifully designed and very iconic place to visit

A community who respect and admire art is usually a more prosperous community as a poor community often concentrate on earning instead of Enjoying. Open Gallery Singapore have numerous artist sculpture and art product which are tag in high price. Recommended to View and Enjoy. No photo taking is allowed
Small, but exquisite collection. The curator of Opera Gallery Singapore certainly knows his/her metier. Most certainly not my last visit.

body: Children have so much to say and convey, where they love places that inspire their creative expression. TheArthaus offers just that as a cosy art studio allowing kids the freedom to explore their boundless imagination. It should be high on every parent's list of places to check out.
description: Art exploration workshops for kids
name: TheArthaus

admissionInfo:
Singaporeans and Permanent Residents enjoy free entry to all Permanent Galleries daily.

Special exhibitions are ticketed separately; admission fees vary depending on visiting exhibitions - refer to website for the latest ticketing information.
body:
The Peranakan Museum explores the art and culture of Peranakan communities in Southeast Asia, and possesses one of the finest and most comprehensive public collections of Peranakan objects.

The Peranakan Museum is currently closed for revamp and is slated to be open again mid-2021.
description: The Peranakan Museum explores the art and culture of Peranakan communities in Southeast Asia.
name: Peranakan Museum
notes: The Peranakan Museum is currently closed for revamp.

reviews.text: The building is stunning and the museum is very interesting, in fact, more interesting than the National Museum. I learnt a lot about the history, culture and traditions, ceremonies and so on.
stunning museum!! love it.

This place is an underrated gem in Singapore! I love how the Peranakan culture is not just limited to Singapore - apparently the Philippines has Peranakan roots, too! I saw how similar the cultures were, from the furniture to the wedding culture, and even the ways in which the women run the household!

Great museum!!! A bit more personal than your average museum visit. We did the tour with a volunteer guide and had plenty of luck with him. He had many great personal and family stories to tell and even some of the items on display were on loan from them. There are also temporary exhibitions, for us they most definitely were worth our time. In all a great 3 hours of quality time. I recommend visiting it during lunch so you avoid the strong mid afternoon Singapore sun.

Before I began my tour, I was given a circular card that I was supposed to take along with me. My challenge was to find the "family treasure stations", all located in different galleries. Each station represented a different item that's important to the Peranakans.

body: With new dustbins, renovated drain covers and freshly painted walls, the back lanes of Muscat Street have been rejuvenated for the first outdoor gallery in Singapore, Gelam Gallery! Using the walls at the back of the shophouses as canvases, the nondescript back lanes of Muscat Street that were once used only for delivery and refuse disposal have been given a transformational makeover. This extraordinary outdoor gallery will showcase murals and framed works of more than 30 artists from different backgrounds, newly graduated students from NAFA and LASALLE College of the Arts, experienced local and foreign artists.
description: An outdoor art gallery filled with beautiful murals and art pieces which is accompanied by decorated dustbins!
name: Gelam Gallery

reviews.text: Really nice place to take quality photos!

Lucked up and found this amazing outdoor art gallery in Kampong Glam. If you go early enough you can get the place to yourself. It is actually on Muscat Street and not Arab Street as shown on Google Maps.
Cool place for instagram if you’re bored with the haji lane. You can easily find turkish restaurants. The feel was so middle eastern-ish.

body: As you go further on a contemporary art trail of the Little India, drop by the House of Tan Teng Niah. The colourful house (or eight rooms to be precise) is the last surviving Chinese villa in the precinct. Look carefully and you'll notice each panel of the exterior is painted in a different hue than the other, resulting in a playful riot of colours.
description: Last surviving Chinese villa in Little India
name: House of Tan Teng Niah

reviews.text:
One of the hidden colorful gems in Singapore! The perfect photography spot!

Always a good vibes and memories are coming from there!

IF you are fan of street photography graffiti or history of Singapore then you are going to love it! remember it!

Cheers!
Beautiful aurrounsing. Many good stall to visit. Indian foods of various kind can be found.
If you're in the neighborhood ... Definitely worth stopping by and snapping a pic of this historic colorful Chinese merchant's house.

A pretty house making a great backdrop for  Instagram pics. The house is old but the take away is less about what's in the house or it's individual history but the care that the Singapore government takes around preservation.  Come here, take a few snaps and you're done although it's best combined by a bit of exploration of that part of Little India especially around the weekend when you get to see cool murals and the bustling activity that is the mark of Little India.

Visited in March before the lockdown. This house used to belong to Tan Teng Niah, a Chinese businessman who lived in what is now the Little India neighbourhood. While some of the architecture of the building retains Chinese elements, the restoration has given the building a very colourful scheme, which looks more South Indian than Chinese. It’s a very photogenic building, nevertheless.

body:
Be greeted by a lush, colourful tableau of flowering plants suspended from the ceiling, which move sinuously in mesmerising fashion at Dance, the first of the four garden landscapes of Floral Fantasy.

Encounter a bubbling brook (or stream) that meanders through grassy knolls in the second garden landscape Float.

Take a stroll down Waltz amidst a rain oasis and waterfalls of flowers among cascading rocks and winding driftwood. Imagine walking through a forest in the rain when you explore this garden landscape, and ponder about the fragility of our biodiversity. Spot the Poison Dart Frogs on display here; despite being tiny, they are hard to miss because of their brilliant colours.

Enter the last garden landscape, a cave-like space that is ringed with terraced rock formations, Drift. The semi-enclosed space is set aglow with soft lighting, creating an enthralling atmosphere.

Get ready to experience the 4D ride. Visitors embark on a simulated journey of a dragonfly's flight path through Gardens by the Bay to discover a whole new world of wonder.
description: Floral Fantasy is the latest thematic attraction at Gardens by the Bay. Flowers, artistry and technology come together to create a dream-like, fantastical experience for visitors. It comprises four diverse garden landscapes, each showcasing a different concept, as well as a 4D ride.
name: Floral Fantasy, Gardens by the Bay
notes: Closed once a month for maintenance. Please check website for details.

reviews.text:
The place is beautiful with lots of plants variety to look at. Especially inside the two domes. Remember to check out the pricing online and buy the tickets online first before coming over to collect it. It will be faster this way. One of the dome has the world's tallest indoor waterfall and the place is beautiful. The other dome has various plants at different season.

Remember to check out the maintenance of the indoor waterfall for the day of your visit. I went once and it was closed.

There are other places to look around outside of the domes but usually it's too hot during the day.

There are light and music show at the supertree groves at 8pm and other timings. There are also food places nearby the supertree groves to dine at.

You can go back towards the city with a link bridge towards Marina Bay Sands (the ship like hotel).

Enjoy your day here !

You should and must visit this place at night when it comes alive with light making it quasi magical.

One of the flower domes hosts a restaurant/bar. The view from up there is breathtaking.

No need to add photos. Loads already available.. we took loads.

must seeing destination in Singapore! beautiful during the day and night!

i love this place during the day and even more during the night with all the lights ON.

I prefer to come for the light show around 20.00 or at night around 00.00 am since it wont be crowded.

It has some attraction to visit as well. The easiest way to reach by the bayfront mrt or taxi.

Its free entrance so dont worry about that!

Enjoy your day!

Spending a vacation with my beloved student to Singapore.  This place is very beautiful filled with lights on a giant tree in the garden.  At night, visitors can enjoy the view of the lake and artificial fountains and sit under a giant tree while enjoying the song of the Queen that comes out of the tree.  At 9 pm there will be very beautiful fireworks.

Whilst the light show is suspended, and for good reason. It was great to go and visit at night. Our daughter loved the twinkly lights and it was like having our own private viewing. Always lovely to go and enjoy. Especially when there's no crowds.

admissionInfo: Free
body: The Buddha Tooth Relic Temple was inspired by the Tang Dynasty in China. Step in and view the intricate designs decked in traditional red lacquer paint. The temple gets its name from what the Buddhists regard as the left canine tooth of Buddha, which has been recovered from his funeral pyre in Kushinagar, India.
description: The Buddha Tooth Relic Temple was inspired by the Tang Dynasty in China.
name: Buddha Tooth Relic Temple

reviews.text:
I was here woth my sister back may 2019. Such a solemn place. Such respect to Singaporeans maintaining the temple peaceful, solemn and calmness inside. There are museums on the 2nd and 3rd floor. On the rooftop was the huge bell.
Well filming is actually not allowed once you are inside...

Stunningly beautiful, intriguing and spiritual.   Allocate a good hour to immerse yourself and enjoy.
When i visited the roof top was closed,  however level 1 and 4 still worthwhile
History and culture come to life in this Temple. Beautiful on the inside and outside. Love the lanterns, love the buddha images. Very calming place.
Feel and vibration here is great. A must visit in Singapore.

A must place to see. Once you get in, you realize how much history you can see at one place. Very convenient location. Easy to find and reach by walk or city transit. There's a thing for all ladies. You must obey the religious and come with clothes that cover your shoulders and legs if uncovered. At the entrance you can find a very kind lady who will support you with a scarf if you have forgot about this obligation.
Many thanks for your hospitality and kindness.

admissionInfo: General Admission is free for Singaporeans and PRs. Validation at ticketing counter is required. Special exhibition tickets start from $15. Please visit www.nationalgallery.sg/tickets for more information.
body: Situated in the heart of the Singapore Civic District, National Gallery Singapore oversees the largest public collection of modern art in Southeast Asia. Housed in two beautifully restored national monuments - City Hall and former Supreme Court - are impeccably curated exhibitions that reveal the cultural legacy and art histories of Southeast Asia. Come visit the Gallery today and discover the rich art and cultural heritage of Singapore and Southeast Asia through stunning modern art masterpieces.

businessHour.description: Revised opening hours from 15 Jun–10 Aug

description: Situated in the heart of the Singapore Civic District, National Gallery Singapore oversees the largest public collection of modern art in Southeast Asia.
name: National Gallery Singapore

reviews.text: Staff are friendly, particularly the staff at the Legends by Chua Soo Bin.

Airy, air-conditioned museum of local art, including some key documents on the history of Singapore (especially regarding formation of Malaysia and independence of Singapore). In terms of amenities, there is a cafe on the first floor, a few toilets on each floor, lifts, and ramps. The view from roof is very nice as well.

Very poor service experience provided by the gallery staff , most of the time,  the visitor experience ambassadors and the gallery ambassadors are really not well versed in their work and the general delivery of their services to the patrons and visitors coming to the gallery . At times , they are clueless of how to provide proper and concise information to the visitors, and they are always seen to be simply just uninterested to engage the visitors who are in need of some information concerning the place. More trainings or hands-on application courses should be provided for them to brush up on their skills and knowledge pertaining to the gallery

Plentiful art pieces to view. For those who like arts, this is the place to go to. The number of art collections is large enough to allow patrons to spend a day there viewing. Some staffs there are helpful in explaining the art works, while some staffs are being paranoid in whether the patrons have attain the admission sticker while they are viewing the art pieces there. It could be seen as a disruptive action. There are staffs who simply abruptly enter into a display room which gave a scare to patrons, especially when it's dark.

Lovely gallery with rich Asian art in a historical building setting. There's also a children's gallery with hands on activities. There are expensive eateries here though there's a courtyard serving more affordable food and drinks.

admissionInfo:
Adult: $42
Child: $32
body:
Bringing our unique blend of glitz and glamour, Madame Tussauds Singapore will take you to a party unlike any other through the 5-in-1 experience!

We are the only Madame Tussauds in the world that offers 5 different interactive experiences all under one roof - from Madame Tussauds Singapore to Images of Singapore LIVE, to “Spirit of Singapore” boat ride, to the only Marvel 4D Cinema in Asia and lastly, to our newly opened Ultimate Film Star Experience! 

Now get ready to photograph and pose with your favourite A-Listers, challenge sports stars, hop on stage with music legends, get in on action at our Marvel 4D Experience, and come face to face with international icons from Singapore, Asia, Hollywood, Bollywood and beyond!
description: Roll out the red carpet - the World Famous Madame Tussauds is now on Sentosa Island!
name: Madame Tussauds Singapore
notes: Last admission at 7pm

reviews.text: Very ecletic range of wax statues here, but fortunately they were arranged in zones so it was easy to walk through. Good to spend a couple of hours to take pictures. Not much interactive activities, but it is after all a museum of wax statues. The few activities they do have were hit-and-misses for me. The Singapore boat ride was quite short and could have been better if it was more educational instead of a mish-mash of Singapore-related things and people. The Marvel 4D show was entertaining, and the VR race was quite a fun experience though. Tried the Ultimate Film Star experience too and I guess it would be fun if there with a group of people to do the various stations together, and if you're into Bollywood. Overall, a pleasant trip but not someplace I would really want to visit again.
not bad... abit disappointed there's no guide to take the best picture angle

I had a amazing experience !  Surprise for us was the Marvel 4D movie which we really enjoyed. The status of celebrities are extremely accurate in the smallest detail. Felt like it was real person standing in Madame Tussauds. A must visit place in Singapore :)
Good but only for one visit
Will recommend if you were to get the tickets on sale. Definitely smaller than others such as the one at HK so set your expectations right and you'll enjoy it

admissionInfo:
Singaporeans and Permanent Residents enjoy free entry to all Permanent Galleries daily.

Special exhibitions are ticketed separately; admission fees vary depending on visiting exhibitions - refer to website for the latest ticketing information.
body: The Asian Civilisations Museum is devoted to exploring the rich artistic heritage of Asia, especially the ancestral cultures of Singaporeans. Opened in 1997 and in its present building by the Singapore River since 2003, the museum traces its roots to the Raffles Museum, founded in the middle of the 19th century. ACM focuses on the many historical connections between the cultures of Asia, and between Asia and the world. Singapore’s history as a port city that brought people together from all over the world is used as a means of examining the history of Asia. Special exhibitions bring magnificent objects from around the world to our Singapore audience. Signature programmes like the annual ACM After Dark, Saturdays@ACM, and Lunchtime Concerts encourage visitors to connect more closely with culture and the arts.
description: The Asian Civilisations Museum is devoted to exploring the rich artistic heritage of Asia, especially the ancestral cultures of Singaporeans.
name: Asian Civilisations Museum

reviews.text:
Loved the experience at "The Asian Civilization Museum", which is under the National Heritage Board of Singapore. The approach via can was not direct as I was dropped off about 100m away from the main entrance, but it was a good walk after a long cab ride!

I booked my ticket through "Tiquet" app and got S$2 discount on each ticket at S$6! The outside was maintained well and place was tidy and clean. The ticket redemption counter was fairly easy to navigate and the staff were pleasant and helpful.

There were 3 levels and each level was filled with different aspects of cultural artefacts and ancient items from different centuries. "The Tang Shipwreck" was a standout for me and loved how the entire area was set up, so KUDOS to the Curators!!

It was a long walk across all 3 levels, so do bring comfortable shoes. We were able to cover all three levels and was impressed with everything I saw. I wonder what is the significance of the "Directors Pick" was - noticed several items with a red banner against a number of the artefacts.
They have exhibits as old as 5,000 years. A rare chance to see such old artifacts.
A museum that is not boring at all. Relatively short visit 1-2hours and is always quiet and nice. Not many people around. The bookshop has interesting volumes for kids

Wonder why Buddha sits in the middle of a cross? Fusion new religion, or relic of a darker past? The answer would surprise you. Of course, this is clickbait to visit and support the museum. Gain that new insight, and earn your right to show off.
Colonial facade, beautiful place rich in history

admissionInfo: Haw Par Villa will be closed for upgrading works from 1 Oct 2020 to 31 Mar 2021. We apologise for the inconvenience.
body:
ANNOUNCEMENT:

Haw Par Villa will be closed for upgrading works from 1 Oct 2020 to 31 Mar 2021.
We apologise for the inconvenience.


Built in 1937, Singapore’s largest outdoor art gallery is the brainchild of Aw Boon Haw, millionaire philanthropist and marketing extraordinaire who gifted the world Tiger Balm. The eclectic park is a treasure trove of Asian culture, history, philosophy and religion – quirky yet enlightening at the same time. Since 2015, it is managed by Journeys Pte Ltd, an award-winning heritage specialist passionate in preserving and bringing the heritage gem to greater heights.

Free Admission


Opening Hours

ANNOUNCEMENT: Haw Par Villa will be closed for upgrading works from 1 Oct 2020 to 31 Mar 2021.

Haw Par Villa: 9am-7pm (last entry at 6.30pm)

Ten Courts of Hell: Temporarily Closed

Temporary Exhibitions (Haw Par Villa - The Exhibition & Sneak Preview of the upcoming Hell's Museum): 9am-5.30pm


Interactive Activities

• Fish and terrapin feeding

• Bubble Zone (available at the courtyard and Guan Yin Pond)


Public Guided Tours
(Currently Unavailable)

For private bookings, please email us at hpv@journeys.com.sg

• Finding your Tao in Haw Par Villa™ - The Tiger Balm Garden Story 

Tour Schedule: Daily, 9.30am 

Duration: Approx. 1 hour

Meeting Point: Haw Par Villa Visitor Centre (please arrive 15 minutes before tour start time for registration and payment)

• Journeys to Hell™ - Death & the Afterlife in Haw Par Villa

Tour Schedule: Every Friday, 6.30pm

Duration: Approx. 2 hours

Meeting Point: Haw Par Villa MRT Station, outside Exit A

For the latest tour schedule and rates, visit www.hawparvilla.sg


Private Bookings

Available for the following guided tours and programmes (customisable):

• Finding your Tao in Haw Par Villa™ - The Tiger Balm Garden Story

• Journeys to Hell™ - Death & the Afterlife in Haw Par Villa

• The Great Haw Par Villa Heritage Race (Amazing Race)


Event Bookings & Venue Rental

Selection of indoor and outdoor spaces available at the sprawling grounds of the historic Haw Par Villa. Check out our events minisite at www.hawparvilla.weebly.com for more details.

Get in touch at hpv@journeys.com.sg and our team will be happy to arrange for a site visit.
description: Haw Par Villa - formerly known as the Tiger Balm Garden – is an 8.5-hectare Asian cultural park, the last of its kind in the world.
name: Haw Par Villa
notes: Haw Par Villa will be closed for upgrading works from 1 Oct 2020 to 31 Mar 2021.

reviews.text: I found my visit to Haw Par Villa a very unforgettable one into Chinese folklore, legend and mythology. It's quite an Asian cultural park. You get to glean insights into Chinese mythology many iconic dioramas. Easy to get there. Metro station is right next to the place and free entrance.

Easy access via MRT. Free entry.
A lot of Chinese legends statues and tales.
The place is interesting for first timer and it’s big. Many sitting spots so you can rest anytime.
The place is old, so many things are worn down but appreciate their efforts to keep this place running with free entry.
You will enjoy a good walk here on a cooler day.

This place is a trip! Definitely a great experience, super unique here in Singapore. Culture and religion on display in statues and scenes that bring it to life. I had a great time wandering around. Cant wait to go back!

This is a really unique and bizarre theme park located in Singapore. It was built around 1937 by the Har Par brothers who made their fortune manufacturing Tiger Balm medicinal products. The park has some eerie and somewhat gaudy statues and dioraramas depicting chinese characters from folklore and mythology. I must say that these oriental statues and figurines are not in my opinion a work of art but has to be appreciated as part of Singapore's cultural heritage. Fifty years ago this park served as a means for families to bring their children here to teach the ancient Chinese folklore history. Sadly, the theme park is in need of repairs. It is still an attraction for families to visit but the dioramas and statues really does not blend in with modern Singapore. Hong Kong's Tiger Balm gardens were razed twenty something years ago and new apartment structure stands in its place. It is only a matter of time that realty development will take over this space. It is still a fascinating place to visit and the best is that it has no admission charge.

The building and the place looks a bit old as they maintained it from years way back till this date. But the attraction of the culture will never stop people from visiting. The part where you will understand about Chinese believes and cultures.

admissionInfo: Free
body: Catch Spectra at the Event Plaza along the promenade for a 15-minute free outdoor light show, with visual projections and colourful lasers, accompanied by an orchestral soundtrack.
description: Catch Spectra at the Event Plaza along the promenade for a 15-minute free outdoor light show, with visual projections and colourful lasers, accompanied by an orchestral soundtrack.
name: Spectra - A Light & Water Show @ Marina Bay Sands

reviews.text: Breathtaking no matter how many times you visit. Cloud Forest is closed to the public currently due to Covid-19 measures, but Flower Dome is still open! Wonderful flowers and succulents, very comfortable as well due to the cool temperatures in the dome.

Whilst the light show is suspended, and for good reason. It was great to go and visit at night. Our daughter loved the twinkly lights and it was like having our own private viewing. Always lovely to go and enjoy. Especially when there's no crowds.
I love the plants n flowers and the way they are displayed. Walking through The Dome and Cloud Garden gives me the feel that am overseas in a park, in a cooler country.
The garden has a natural beauty. It is quite a big park. The lighting show is also really great. The lamps in the water also look really great at night

I was lucky to visit Gardens By the Bay twice and both visits were amazing. They change their themes every now and then. The place was clean, crews were respectful and friendly. Very systematic set up and very safe. Their offerings are very educational on environment. Bring your children and oldies here. They will enjoy and will love it.

admissionInfo: Purchase a book and you will get a free colouring session on how to colour the templates in the book The free session is valid for 6 months from date of purchase.
body:
Singapore Food Makes Me Hungry is penned by two of Artsence@SouthBridge’s founders Jennifer Lim (Jenn) and Geraldine Koh (Geri) with the latter also the book’s illustrator. Both Jenn and Geri are very familiar and enamoured with Singapore’s local food scene having been raised and lived in Singapore for most of their lives. The book is a celebration of Singapore’s ubiquitous hawker culture, containing illustrations and detailed descriptions of many unique local dishes. Many of these dishes can traced back to each of Singapore’s major racial groups which have many popular dishes sold in hawker centres across the island.

The front cover conveys a design meant to evoke memories of ordering takeaway from a ‘zi char’ stall. ‘Zi char’ is a Hokkien phrase describing stalls which sell Chinese dishes meant for sharing and customers can choose from at least twenty different dishes of vegetables, meat, seafood, rice and noodles. The food may be consumed on site or if customers choose to eat it elsewhere, it is usually packed into a thin white paper box. The phrase ‘jio le’ can be found on the front cover and it is a Teochew phrase meaning to invite people and reflects Artsence@SouthBridge inviting readers to go on a gastronomical journey as they flip through the book.

The back of the book contains more than just the standard paragraphs about the authors because readers will find pieces of paper containing printed sketches of the dishes featured in the book. These sketches are not coloured to allow readers to paint the them using colour pencils. How they paint them is of course left to the preference of the readers.
description: A local food art journal with coloured-pencils illustrations of eight popular local food in Singapore. The book also contains colouring activity.
name: Singapore Food Makes Me Hungry
notes: Closes on Christmas Eve, Christmas Day, New Year's Eve, New Year's Day

reviews.text: Good one

Standard of food has dropped a lot from before. Still love the ambience and decoration. The crusts of both the chicken wrap and carbonara pizza were horrendous. Tasteless and thick as flour. In spite of it being named thin crust. Flavourless crust. Bubble tea was mostly Milo and the pearls were not chewy. Just soft and disintegrating with each bite. Bad choice for dinner. It was too expensive as well. Only cash and nets available. Not crowded on weekend night.

Ambient : 👍🏼👍🏼👍🏼👍🏼
Food : 🤤🤤🤤
Price : 💲💲💲💲
Service : N.A
Food is acceptable.
Overall experience is good.

Ordered menu:
- salad (nothing special, homemade is even better)
- truffle Fries (almost no taste)
- cucumber & lemonade juice (too sour)
- ice cream (5/5)
- cappucino (3/5)

We love the ambience. We came here for it but we are a bit disappointed with the food.. hope u can improve it.

Service was very slow, I waited for about 30 mins for my bubble tea to be ready (if you're wondering, the bubble tea has no tea taste at all and is very diluted). Food took about 45 mins at least. Taste wise was average. It was over priced and not worth the wait as it felt like the food were frozen or premade.

It's a pity though, the place looks really nice but the food and drinks are a huge disappointment.

admissionInfo:
Your lunch or dinner experience at Tthe Intan is approximately 2 hours

It includes:

- A spread of Peranakan dishes and home made Peranakan refreshments

- A brief understanding of the history and culture of the Peranakans

- Learning about the tradition
body:
The museum is a haven for treasures of this remarkable culture, and a tour of the Intan gives visitors a chance to walk back in time and marvel at the spirit of the Peranakan people. On arrival at the museum, the first thing that strikes you is how unassuming the exteriors of the house are. It is not until you walk inside that you get to marvel at the astounding collection of antiques that attempts to combine the charm of the past within the contemporary setting. The open layout and the mirrors create the aura of a spacious indoors, and within it, the sheer diversity of collectables from years gone by. From rows of beaded traditional slippers with intricate designs to vibrantly closured costumes, jewelry pieces and an array of trinkets, there is no shortage of traditional aspects to learn about in this culture. It is fascinating to note that, unlike your typical museum where information cards abound, The Intan has no cards at all. Ask Alvin Yapp, the museum’s owner, anything about the different collections and he will gladly indulge you. A tour of this museum is incomplete without enjoying a meal the Peranakan way. Needless to say, this is a favorite for many visitors as it is an opportune moment to sample traditional snacks and meals dotingly prepared by Mr Yapp’s mother. Best of all, the meals are served in charming crockery for a holistic Peranakan experience. Depending on the time of your visit, you may listen in to Yapp and a few of his family members belt out a local song or two. The Intan is open by appointment only, so bookings must be made in advance to ensure slots are available. Custom made packages are also available for private events as long as they are related to the Peranakan culture. Visitors should note that visits are strictly by appointment only.


*** This experience is only available if COVID 19 regulations allow
description: The Intan is a private home that houses one of Singapore’s most impressive collections of Peranakan (a group descended from Chinese settlers) artifacts. Owner Alvin Yapp has spent 30-plus years collecting 1,500 objects from Peranakan culture, most notably kasot manek (ornate beaded slippers worn by Straits Chinese women) and enamel tiffin carriers hand-painted in delicate floral patterns. Yapp's post-war home is a labor of love, and it shows in the meticulous way that he has arranged every square inch of it.
name: The Intan Private Lunch/Dinner Visit

reviews.text: Fantastic cozy experience. Alvin the homeowner is an amazing story teller and brings history to life. Don’t walk in, better connect With the museum before you go.

Closed yet according to Google it is open Monday morning at 11:30.

Seems it is only by appointment, so no walk in.

Very nice part of Singapore though to stroll around and have lunch ;)

SGD 60 per Visitor.

A great stop; well worth leaving the more congested tourist  parts of the city. Learn not just about Peranakan Culture, but gain a better understanding of Singapore and the relationship between it's different groups. Highly recommended.

(All photos without filter, it’s that colourful)
In the past I only knew Peranakan as Nyonya cuisine and colourful/ floral patterns. After visiting this house, through various types of collections (especially the well-made slippers upstairs) and explanation on how they were used and where they were arranged in a house,  I feel like I have a fundamental and memorable understanding of peranakan people and their culture. Singapore does not have that many historical/ cultural spots so this is definitely recommended! Instagrammable too 😉

A lovely museum, and the multi-hyphenated museum curator, Peranakan owner bring this place alive. The haven of collectables is alive with his explanation into the history, culture and lifestyle of the Peranakan. Highly recommended for those who are keen to know more about Alvin, his story and traditions of the Peranakan.

admissionInfo: Free admission to  premises of Rumah Bebe
body: Of the Perankan rites of passage, none was more elaborate than the wedding. True to their practice of elaborating on Chinese custom, the complete Baba wedding ceremony was extended over a period of 12 days. “Seronee “ music was played with a flute and gong throughout the ceremony. The wedding procession comprised of a pair lanterns with the surnames of the wedding couple, red buntings ( “chye-kee”) propped on bamboo poles, signifying good luck and prosperity and a pair of brocade umbrellas , to shelter the couple. The bride wore heavily embroidered layers of costumes, with a crown of floral hairpins and a headband. She was the “empress” of the day and walked, swaying in a gentle left to right motion – a belief that this movement would ward off any clashes with evil spirits. The groom , too , wore several layers of embroidered costumes, his jewels were confined to a jewelled cap, collar and belt. The bridal couple were assisted by a “Sanh-ke-um” ( Mistress-of-ceremony) and a “Pakchindek” (groom’s assistant). A young boy and girl played the role of ‘Koo-yah” (page-boy) and “Penyapit” (bride’s maid) in the procession. Services provided : i)Baba Wedding Performances for events/corporate functions ii) Rental of wedding costumes.
description: As a cultural outreach of the Peranakan heritage, we organize enactments of traditional Baba wedding to suit your needs. Be it an event, corporate or private, to share the heritage or a couple seeking to wed in traditional style , or just dressing up for a photo-shoot, we customize the ceremony accordingly.
name: Traditional Baba Wedding
notes: Closed during Christmas and Chinese New Year

body: Set within a reflective sculpted art installation are four different ways for you to descend and have fun!
companyDisplayName: JEWEL CHANGI AIRPORT TRUSTEE PTE. LTD.
description: It's a work of art; it's a playground; it's a viewing deck… Discover for yourself the different ways to enjoy this giant sculptural playscape!
name: Jewel Changi Airport Canopy Park Discovery Slides

reviews.text:
JEWEL CANOPY PARK IS AMAZING! Although quite tiring, the Manulife Sky Net and the Bouncing Net is really fun and safe. The ciew is also breathtaking even though its indoors.

For those who prefer relaxing activities, it is also nice to just take a stroll around the well designed park, decorated with all kinds of flora and fauna.

Definitely recommend!!

Great place to spend an hour here. Great with kids but only they are 110cm tall. Staff strictly adhere to the height requirement for kids for their safety. Entry ticket to the park is valid for the entire day. You may re-enter the park within the same day but not for the ticketed attractions which are limited to single entry.
Quite crowded, maybe due to the school holidays, so its hard to maintain a safe distance. The queue moves quickly though
Fun but a bit pricey for the bouncing with the 1 hour limit time

My mom and sister went to the Canopy park yesterday.

While the attractions were big fun, they encountered issues with unfriendly and doubtful staffs at the Sky Net, resulted in really unpleasant experiences.

My mom and sister did not enter Sky Net until 3:30pm, but the staffs said they have already been to the attraction at 3pm. While there is apparently system error where the blame should be on the dev team, the staffs pointed the arrow at my parent. With complete false confidence, they said their system will not have any mistake, and accused my mom for lying, saying she definitely has been there at 3pm. The staff also repeatedly asked my 8 years old sister if she has been to the attraction, giving absolutely 0 respect and trust in my mom's words. My mom is a kind woman and my sister is still small so they really couldn't talk back, had a really tough time handling the rain of accusations from the attraction staffs.

What is there to scam for? An entry? System failure is to blame the consumer? Is that the way Canopy Park and holder group operate? Where are the core values?

I urge you to not go to Sky Net if you want to avoid awful experience. Everywhere was fine but just don't go to Sky Net.

source: JEWEL CHANGI AIRPORT TRUSTEE PTE. LTD.

body:
MINT Museum of Toys houses a world-class collection of vintage toys and collectable items in an international award-winning contemporary building on 26 Seah Street.

Since its inauguration, the museum has expanded its collection, amassing over 50,000 items, 8500 of which are on display in the museum. The toys and items hail from over 40 countries and range in date from the 1840s to 1970s. These are displayed across the rooftop, basement; both serving as Enamel Sign Gallery and four thematic levels of the museum: Outerspace, Characters, Childhood Favourites and Collectables.

The collection is made up of various key collections, including the only Batman robot toy complete with cape and sword, Dan Dare’s first and only in the world Mekon Mask, a century-old Steiff Teddy Bear and the first mass-manufactured robot before WWII, and over two centuries old collectables. In addition to toys, the museum houses a collection of confectionary vintage tin boxes, large-item displays, such as Mobo horses and pedal cars, as well as original enamel advertising signs. Over the years, these have been incorporated into various exhibitions and programmes run by the museum, serving as windows into the past as well as inspirations for the present.

Today, the MINT Museum of Toys serves diverse and expanding audiences, including locals, tourists, families, collectors, artists and students. We continue to fascinate and inspire the imaginations of audiences, taking them to on a journey of rediscovery to rekindle that Moment of Imagination and Nostalgia with Toys (MINT).
description: MINT Museum of Toys houses a world-class collection of vintage toys and collectable items in an international award-winning contemporary building on 26 Seah Street.
name: MINT Museum of Toys
notes: Close on 1st day of Chinese New Year

reviews.text: This is a charming little place that you should definitely visit if you're a toy buff. The exhibits are spread across multiple floors with quite a lot of rare and expensive pieces included. The focus however, is more towards first half of this century with a majority of them being Tin toys. The exhibits are well categorized but the museum itself is not too big, so you should  be able to comfortably finish all the levels in an hour or two.
I will never forget the first time i was there. That's a wonder place make me go back to my childhood! When i have chance back to SG, I will go there again.

This museum consists of one man's huge collection of vintage, mostly 20th-century toys, crammed into a narrow five-story building, with a different focus on each of floors 2 through 5--you ride the elevator to the top and work your way down. There's a bar and shop on the ground floor. I particularly loved the "Outer Space" collection on floor 5, with toys themed to familiar science-fiction media and space exploration. (There I found the one item in the collection that I personally owned: a kids' card game from the late 60s called "Space Race.") There are some labels describing the history and provenance of some of the toys, including proud indications of particularly rare and valuable ones. For anyone whose childhood was somewhere from about 1920-1985, this place will hold a powerful kick of nostalgia.

Well designed and really have the collection that span a many years. The history of toys, the poster in steel and enamel, it was just amazing and mind boggling to see. It is a treat for the eyes and the collectors who wants to be reminded of the toys and collectables that have once in their life touched and played. A play full of colors and the architecture is a visual excitement that never fails to awe me.

The entrance fee was pricey for me. The toys in display all induced nostalgia and you learn interesting trivia now and then. But other than the trip down memory lane, only collectors will really appreciate the place. Kids will want to see SOME toys but since you cant play with them, adults are the target audience here, I think.
