body:
A 90 minute insider experience where guests go behind the scenes with wax artists and try their hand at the magic required to make the worlds greatest wax figures. Learn wax painting, hair insertion and even take home your own wax souvenir! You can be a wax artist!

Behind The Magic will give YOU the chance to explore the mysterious wax figure making process.

The workshop includes:
-A brief intro to the history on Madame Tussauds
- Introduction to the sitting process of a wax figure
- Discover the essential steps and tools in wax figure making process
- Interactive presentation: oil painting, hair insertion, wax surface fixing
- Fun facts sharing
- Q&A Session
- Customized gift to be brought home

More information:
- Reservation and payment must be made in advance 
- $49.90 per person which also includes an admission ticket for Madame Tussauds
- OR $25 top up if you already have an admission ticket for Madame Tussauds
- Behind the magic available for guests aged 13+. Younger guests are welcome, 1 child accompanied by maximum 1 adult, who will follow the workshop together because of safety reasons, tools with sharp edges are used during this workshop.

Ready to book? Click here now! 

Or go to: www.madametussauds.com/singapore/en/behind-the-magic
description: Create, Paint and Explore...Be a Wax Artist!
name: Behind The Magic

body:
The Straits Enclave Experience

Once you step into the Straits Enclave, it is like taking a step back in time into a different time dimension – 100 years back into an early 1920s Peranakan home when these architecturally stunning shophouses were constructed in Joo Chiat. Guests are welcomed by a captivating ambience, followed by a feast for their eyes where they will be tickled by the stories and Peranakan Chinese artefacts that will inevitably entice them to want to know more about the Peranakan culture. The place provides fascinating insights into the development of this unique culture and heritage that infuses Colonial, Chinese and Malay influences into their living spaces, furniture, deco, art, tapestry, kitchen wares, dressing, and more.

There many well-preserved antiques and museum grade items in the Straits Enclave that stood the test of time. Amidst the highly priced brown-and-gold furniture, look out for displays of vintage artefacts like grandfather’s clock, gramophone, cameras, heirloom porcelain wares, spittoons, silver-wares, pillow-ends and intricate beaded shoes, quintessential to the Straits Chinese household. The largest and heaviest item in the house is the mid-19th century antique bed imported from an old Dutch colonial house in Indonesia by a local Peranakan family. This bed was carefully dissembled on site, transported and brought up to the second floor through the narrow shophouse stairway and finally re-assembled to its original state without a scratch. Singaporeans and oversea guests looking to get up close and personal with the Peranakan culture will find Straits Enclave simply captivating.

About Straits Enclave’s Services

Cosy Enclave Meetings & Event Space. The Straits Enclave is the perfect location for hosting private functions and having an unforgettable evening with family, friends and corporate guests. Projector and screen provided for presentation. The Straits Enclave can have up to 20 visitors at a time for each event.

Promoting Local Culture. Take a private storytelling tour of Straits Enclave, and feel and touch Peranakan & Vintage Artefacts up-close for a greater appreciate of Singapore’s unique past and Peranakan Culture. Attend talks, classes and workshops to learn or research more about the Peranakan art and culture.

Cultural Photography and Location Shoot . Straits Enclave is available for photography, movie and location shoots. Delve into the cultural roots with Chinese or Peranakan pre-wedding photoshoot wearing traditional wedding Kua or Baju Kebaya with the grand location to capture the moment for keeps of a lifetime.

Experiential Private Dining. Visitors craving more for a complete experience can pre-book a private dining session at Straits Enclave. Preserving the authenticity of each dish is key to how Straits Enclave’s Chef teleports guests to the time when he/Chef fondly remembers these dishes growing up. Our in-house chef will take you on a gastronomical journey with authentic Peranakan or Western cuisines, special desserts and beverages from past generations’ secret recipes. Arrive early to indulge in pre-diner cocktail Nyonya style, and for a photo tour around the fascinating and charming/captivating Straits Enclave. Guests are given the chance to create their plate of Kueh Pie Tee and bowl of Laksa. Straits Enclave presents/promises an engaging, enriching and hearty experience. The Straits Enclave has a minimum setting of 4 pax and can host up to 16 comfortably seated guests. Prior arrangement and booking required with straits_enclave@yahoo.com

Exquisite Breakfast/Lunch/Afternoon Tea. Straits Enclave delivers an breakfast/lunch/afternoon tea experience with poise and sophistication like no other. Reserve a table in advance at the Straits Enclave to enjoy a truly unique experience. The charmingly traditional and elegantly riveting space is perfect for catching up with old friends and to reminisce the past over a variety of customisable menu such as the traditional colonial (English) breakfast, Laksa, Kueh Pie Tee, Peranakan kuehs, specialty desserts and tea brews, etc. The photo-worthy place alone is worth the visit and an afternoon of calories. Available on weekends. The Straits Enclave has a minimum setting of 4 pax and can host up to 16 comfortably seated guests. Prior arrangement and booking required with straits_enclave@yahoo.com
description: The Straits Enclave is situated in the heart of the heritage district of Joo Chiat known for its colourful Peranakan accented shophouses and it is a place where one must visit to appreciate the Peranakan culture - a prised part of Singapore's rich heritage. The Straits Enclave is a private gallery and event space with a simple aim of preserving and sharing a part of Singapore’s unique historical identity to the swiftly modernizing Singapore and rapidly changing world.
name: Straits Enclave @ Joo Chiat
notes: Prior bookings required. E-mail: straits_enclave@yahoo.com

reviews.text: Adding 5 more stars ⭐️ ⭐️ ⭐️ ⭐️ ⭐️ to the above... it’s a private museum, photo studio, private home dining, cultural workshop space & unique event venue... all rolled into one. From the private tour to the dine in experience, you can feel the owner’s love for local culture and the desire to share it with as many people as possible. It’s been truly memorable. Thank you #Support local

Nice to be able to go back in time and  feel the ambience of the Straits Settlement era. Thanks to the owner who allowed us to view his personal collection of Peranakan treasures.  We were served nice nonya kuehs and self-
served kueh pie tees.

Ensconced in the cosy street of Joo Chiat, my friends and I chanced upon this gem of a place where Clarence kindly brought us down the memory lane of his rich Peranakan ancestry. It was followed by a sumptuous spread of all our favourite Peranakan kueh ranging from Kueh Pie Tee to the feast of colours you see in the picture. He was very kind to help us with a surprise birthday celebration too. We were beaming from both the wonderful catch-up we had in such a lovely ambience and the authentic dishes. Will highly recommend the concept to all family, friends and tourists who are looking for a nostalgic trip down Peranakan history paired with impeccable hospitality. ❤️

Upon entering the premise, it honestly felt like time travel ensued and brought back the 1900s amidst the astounding array of magnificent antiques depicting the richness of peranakan culture - exquisite porcelain wares/colourful traditional costumes/prized antique furniture/ vintage artefacts/etc. make up the delightful private collection offering breadth & depth to enchant both laymen & enthusiasts alike.

What is also clearly evident is the level of attention to detail devoted to the creation of such a passionate heritage space: while there is always a display to pique one's interest at every corner, the exhibits never once felt cluttered or mundane.

For my next visit, I'm looking to partake in a gastronomical journey with the affable resident chef and experience authentic peranakan cuisine in the cosy setting of this hidden gem - truly a unique & remarkable cultural adventure in Singapore.
Unique dining and socializing place to reminisce the good old days. Great hosts, great food, great ambience.

admissionInfo: Free admission. Charges apply for in-house tours.
body:
A PERANAKAN EXPERIENCE -a 45 MINUTES IN-HOUSE TOUR . A 1928 restored Peranakan shophouse, Rumah Bebe is dedicated to preserving Peranakan traditional and cultural works of art. The shop features artefacts of porcelain , kebayas, batik, embroideries , beadworks and other works of art. Displays of antique kebayas and beadworks are for viewing and sale . Talks and demonstrations explain the techniques involved in creating such artworks like beading a pair of nyonya slippers. Visitors can also try on kebayas and take photos amidst the rich decor of the shop and enjoy light refreshment of home-baked nyonya pastries. Tours can be designed and customized for memorable visitors’ experiences.

NEW !!! 'The Little Nyonya Experience"   - An exclusive tour to experience the lifestyle of a nyonya
description: Introduction to Peranakan heritage, followed by kebaya and sarong tying. Viewing of beading demonstration of nyonya slippers.
name: 'THE LITTLE NYONYA EXPERIENCE''  - an in-house tour
notes: No in-house tours on weekends. Closed during Christmas and Chinese New Yearf

reviews.text:
Apam berkuah: 5 stars
Steam cake texture.

Putu tegair: 4.5
Cempedak is so xiang.

Onde onde: 1.5 stars
Strange but most of these had a strange metallic taste to them. 5 out of 7 were inedible.
Reserved a meal for two. Homecooked style Peranakan food that warms the heart.

It is just a store. When I entered, nothing in particular. The ladies looked at me like a stranger, no greet at al. The traditional food was not so tempting. So i decided to go out. Maybe this was good if u want to look for the clothes, etc
Food is fantastic! Felt like being welcomed in as a family member.
Delicious pineapple tarts, rempah udang and pang susie.

body: The history of Gillman Barracks is tied to the island’s colonial past. It was built in 1936 for the British 1st Battalion and was named after General Sir Webb Gillman. During World War II, it was one of the final battle sites before Singapore fell into the hands of the Japanese troops. After the country’s independence in 1965, the site became prime training ground for Singapore’s national servicemen. Only in 2012 was the area transformed into an enclave of contemporary art. Visitors will find international galleries such as Mizuma Gallery (www.mizuma.sg) and Sullivan + Strumpf (www.sullivanstrumpf.com) alongside homegrown outfits like FOST Gallery (www.fostgallery.com) and Chan + Hori Contemporary (www.chanhori. com). There are also several dining options like Masons (www.masons.sg) for European cuisine and The Naked Finn (www.nakedfinn.com) for top quality seafood dishes. Galleries open past their usual hours during the Art After Dark event (www.gillmanbarracks. com/others/gillman-barracks/current), which features live music and pop-up food stalls.
description: This enclave of colonial buildings houses 12 international galleries showcasing contemporary art.
name: Gillman Barracks
notes: Varies per gallery. All galleries closed on Mon and Public Holidays.

reviews.text: Old colonial barracks now converted to commercial use, mostly eateries.

Ordered Asahi and Corona Beers at $11 each. Chicken wings are normal (reminds me that the hawker's BBQ chicken wings are better than theirs), but pork chop is really tender even though its thick (eat it when it's still warm as it turns hard after it's cold).
We'll return with friends and even kids cos of the cool decor indoors.
Great waffles and alcoholic flavors. Super creamy ice cream. Loved the pistachio flavor as well

Beautiful Gillman Barracks with its lovely black and white art houses kept me company in my ten kilometre walk last evening. While my family ate and drank at Handlebar, I enjoyed the serenity and heritage of this special part of Singapore. Added bonus for my Solitary status the beautiful full moon.
Good restaurants and interesting art.

body: Built in 1929, this Art Deco streetblock has exposed brickwork and unique lion head rain spouts. In 1977, instead of urban renewal through demolition and rebuilding, the Urban Redevelopment Authority pioneered the rehabilitation of the then State owned property for adaptive reuse. Along with other rehabilitation projects at Tudor Court and Emerald Hill, these buildings were the forerunners of Singapore’s conservation programme that was to start in 1989.
description: Built in 1929, this Art Deco streetblock has exposed brickwork and unique lion head rain spouts. In 1977, instead of urban renewal through demolition and rebuilding, the Urban Redevelopment Authority pioneered the rehabilitation of the then State owned property for adaptive reuse. Along with other rehabilitation projects at Tudor Court and Emerald Hill, these buildings were the forerunners of Singapore’s conservation programme that was to start in 1989.
name: Murray Terrace

admissionInfo: S$9 per ticket for Non-Singaporean Students and Seniors (60 years & above) [Verification: Full Time students with valid student pass]
body: With a history dating back to 1887, the National Museum of Singapore is the nation’s oldest museum with a progressive mind. Journey through our galleries as we capture and present you the heart and spirit of Singapore and its rich cultures, traditions and stories. Be it world-class exhibitions, visually captivating art installations or magical festivals, there is something for everyone at the museum.
description: Come experience our stories of Singapore and the world – right at the National Museum of Singapore.
name: National Museum of Singapore
notes: Last entry to Glass Rotunda at 6.15pm and last entry to all other galleries at 6.30pm

reviews.text: We got wonderful experience. Huge museum of Singapore historical collections, as you expected from a museum. Clean, nicely decorated and beautiful building too. Good for those who love and curious about history; especially Singapore national history. Good for all kind of visitors, with family, couple, friends or alone. But you might expect walking a bit because of the vast building.
History of Singapore Just next to for Canning Park.

All articles and exhibits are well exhibited and highlighted. Place is fully air conditioned and equipped. Kind staff provides all necessary information. I recommend a guided tour inside which is offered free of charges at designated hours. It helps to get first impression and initial information about the articles and exhibitions there.

The Museum is huge and very interactive, old and yet modern way to display the pieces of history make the visit amazing. Normally, I am not a huge fan of museums, but this one is worth visit. Some of the parts were less interesting, but I really liked the mode and costumes that were displayed there.

Quite well done, though the singapore history gallery was a bit too long and detailed (felt like there was so much on literally anyone remotely famous). Rotunda was cool but would have preferred being able to know the names of the animals. Visit was free. Lockers available. Honestly it exceeded my expectations. Building was absolutely beautiful.

body: The association was founded in 1879 at Upper Cross Street with financial assistance from Hoo Ah Kay, a well-known community leader from Whampoa district in Guangdong province. The association was relocated to New Bridge Road in 1917. The building is a hybrid of Neo-Classical and Art Deco styles which are popular with Chinese developers in the past who wanted to project a modern image. To the Chinese, New Bridge Road was colloquially referred to as Da Po Er Ma Lu, Mandarin for Greater Town's Second Road. The first road referred to in this instance was South Bridge Road.
description: The association was founded in 1879 at Upper Cross Street with financial assistance from Hoo Ah Kay, a well-known community leader from Whampoa district in Guangdong province. body: To live out the dream of soaring like a superhero, drop by iFly Singapore, Southeast Asia’s largest wind tunnel for indoor skydiving. The 18-foot-tall acrylic glass walls allow visitors to enjoy panoramic views of the South China Sea and Siloso Beach. State-of-the-art technology will lend visitors wings in an experience that gives them a taste of skydiving and simulates free falls from heights of 12,000- to 3,000-feet. First-timers needn’t fret, as trained professionals will be on hand to guide them.
description: Enjoy skydives in wind tunnels for an unforgettable experience.
name: iFly Singapore

pricing.others: 1 Skydive S$89; 2 Skydives S$119 (walk-in); 2 Skydives S$109 (2 day in advance online rate); 2 Skydives S$89 (2 day in advance online off-peak rate)

reviews.text:
What an experience... WOW!  It is quite expensive but definitely awesome.  Friendly staff,  excellent coach,  professional and helpful.

“Fly without wings; Dream with open eyes; See in darkness.”
First time try, very easy to fly and relax. Good experience
Perfect fly.

What a blast!
Came here in February 2014 and dislocated my shoulder 45 seconds into the jump.
Had to sign to the instructor that I was in excruciating pain.
Nevertheless, the team took care of me and called me an ambulance.

Lucky for me though, as I sat there on the seat in pain, my shoulder popped itself back in! Hooray!

This meant I wouldn't have to take an expensive tourist ambulance trip to a hospital.

Phew.

Those 45 seconds were fun though.

Had a great time at iFly. Session was at 4pm but had to be there 1 hour beforehand for a short briefing on the hand signals used , what to expect in the wind tunnel etc. Each session had 6 people.

Necessary precautions were taken due to the COVID situation - face shields , googles were all sanitised.

body: Chinatown Street Market re-creates the street hawking of yesteryear with 140 stalls offering a wide array of Singapore-centric and themed souvenirs, apparels, arts and crafts. Walking down the bustling downtown of Pagoda Street, Sago Street, Smith Street, and Trengganu Street transports you to an old era of Singapore. Scour through these streets with stall offerings in which reflects Chinatown’s heritage tells little known stories of Chinatown’s rich and vibrant culture. Experience a glimpse of Chinese culture unique to Singapore at Chinatown today.
description: A vibrant one stop destination for interesting and diverse shopping, dining and entertainment.
name: Chinatown Street Market

reviews.text: I still remember my amazing shopping done here. I bought many things that too at a much cheaper rates. The food i had was tasty and clean. Shopkeepers are friendly. I went in the afternoon and found the place very crowdy.  You need to go when the sun is going down, so there will be less crowd. Must visit when in Singapore.
This was a fun place to walk through. You are able to find absolutely everything in Chinatown's street market. I have seen a lot of interesting buys. Tip: better to visit when the sun is going down.
if you're looking to get some souvenirs, visit this place. Has plenty of street food that's very comforting when you're hungry

Best place for souvenir at reasonable price. Most shops are good. Just outside Chinatown MRT on Buddha temple side.
Please like my review if useful

Every 15th Day of the 8th month at full moon the Asian countries celebrate the Mid-Autumn Festival. Also Singapore's Chinatown gets a festive decoration and mood. The event has many names and is also called Mooncake, Harvest or Lantern festival and is nowadays rather similar to Thanksgiving.
Historically the festival dates back to the Chinese Shang Dynasty (1600-1046 BC) where it was a Harvest festival. In years to come some Epic stories brought in a twist and the Moon goddess Chang'e brought the full moon to the center of the festival. The yellowish, round shaped Mooncakes are an important part of the family gathering during this period.

admissionInfo: Admission is free and strictly by appointment.
body: The bright blue National University of Singapore (NUS) Baba House was once the ancestral home of shipping tycoon Wee Bin and introduces visitors to Peranakan culture from the early 20th century to the present. Most of the original interior of this Peranakan-style house is intact and the ornate exterior is a testament to Singapore’s architectural heritage. More than 2,000 Peranakan antiques, such as porcelain ware, furniture, art and embroidery, are on display on the first two floors. These include artefacts found inside the NUS Baba House when parts of it were excavated.
description: This Peranakan-style house is a testament to Singapore’s architectural heritage, with its ornate exterior and interior still intact.
name: NUS Baba House

reviews.text: Beautifully done building. Enjoyed my visit with the guide. Would have been better with a guide that is more trained in explanation of the restoration work and structure. Maybe next time

Amazing experience, this is first time for me to see real heritage house in Singapore. We signed up for a self-guided tour but there are staffs inside to provide answers to our questions, they are very friendly and helpful. The house is really beautiful, with lots of details in decorations, furnitures, etc. definitely a worth exploring experience.
Wonderful experience. If you are interested in Peranakan culture you should visit this place. They have great guide and you'll have a good time here
Excellent place to go for an authentic knowledge of wealthy living of the Peranakn, with a glimpse of conservation engineering.
It was nice experience, I recommend spend time to know more about interesting Peranakan culture. Book online in advance

admissionInfo:
Adult (13 years old and above): SGD11.80
Child (7 to 12 years old): SGD6.40
Free admission for children aged 6 and younger.
body:
The Red Dot Design Museum presents a large collection of contemporary design works across disciplines including innovative products, research concepts, communication works and art. The current exhibition 'Human-Nature' questions the nature of being human in a world where we achieved enhanced abilities through technology and algorithm, where humans co-exist with robots, machine learning and big data.

In addition to design exhibitions, the museum features one of the best design shop, a design cafe and outdoor bar. Here, you can buy carefully curated design objects from around the world and also those produced by Singapore designers. The cafe features unique local deserts, craft beer, gourmet coffee and tea.

Exhibit at the museum is  the Human-Nature design exhibition which ends September 2020. Through presentation of design works from various disciplines including innovative products, research concepts, communication works and art, Human-Nature exhibition explores how humans excel beyond our natural ability through technology and algorithm and questions the nature of being human in a world where we co-exist with robots, machine learning and big data.
description: Contemporary Design Museum that presents award-winning good designs. Museum shop retails design products sourced from all over the world.
name: Red Dot Design Museum
notes: Museum is open during Public Holidays.

reviews.text:
This is a small museum where you can see some interesting and futuristic creations. It is not so expensive, at least the entry.
I had the  best tea I had ever tasted there, the staff is very friendly.
I wanted to buy something from the shop there, but everything was quite expensive, but that was not shocking, because most of the objects were original and you cant buy them anywhere else.
In the end, if you have plenty of time in Singapore, if you dont mind to spend some dollars for tickets and if you are interested in design and modernity, it is definitely worth your time.

Re-explore & re-discover Singapore. This is a 'must' visit place. Some design pieces made you look at things in a different perspective. Enjoyed the time there & love the lighting design in the museum. Thanks to Carrie & Raudha for the great hospitality!

A very interesting museum! Definitely a must-go spot if you’re enjoying visiting museums! Entry fee is cheap and you get coupon if you purchase the entry ticket! Small but can offer you with insights and ideas!

It just lots of description of their rewarded items, nothing really you can touch or feel. Being a design museum I would expect the museum is also a show case but it's just a badly designed building and even the toilet was so badly designed that you need to open the toilet door by pulling the bag hanger!

Inspiring items. Great gift shop with tons of cool stuff for both kids and adults. Cafe very nice. The museum itself seems a bit small for the price. Easy to see everything in ten minutes. Entrance fee comes with a nice book filled with pictures and stories of all items. It would be nice to see more art and furniture designs. Too heavy on tech design.

body:
Located in the heart of Chinatown, the Buddha Tooth Relic Temple & Museum’s richly designed interiors and comprehensive exhibits on Buddhist art and history tell stories of culture over thousands of years old. This Tang-styled building’s design was inspired by the Buddhist Mandala, a symbol of Buddhist culture that represents the universe.

Built in 2007, the temple gets its name from what the Buddhists regard as the left canine tooth of Buddha, which has been recovered from his funeral pyre in Kushinagar, India and displayed on the temple’s grounds. The Buddha Tooth Relic is housed in a giant stupa weighing a whopping 3,500 kilograms and made from 320 kilograms of gold, of which 234 kilograms were donated by devotees.

If you’re looking for a little quiet contemplation amid Chinatown’s hubbub, the roof garden, with its pagoda and Buddha prayer wheel, offers a tranquil hideaway.

name: Buddha Tooth Relic Temple & Museum 佛牙寺

reviews.text:
I was here woth my sister back may 2019. Such a solemn place. Such respect to Singaporeans maintaining the temple peaceful, solemn and calmness inside. There are museums on the 2nd and 3rd floor. On the rooftop was the huge bell.
Well filming is actually not allowed once you are inside...

Stunningly beautiful, intriguing and spiritual.   Allocate a good hour to immerse yourself and enjoy.
When i visited the roof top was closed,  however level 1 and 4 still worthwhile
History and culture come to life in this Temple. Beautiful on the inside and outside. Love the lanterns, love the buddha images. Very calming place.
Feel and vibration here is great. A must visit in Singapore.

A must place to see. Once you get in, you realize how much history you can see at one place. Very convenient location. Easy to find and reach by walk or city transit. There's a thing for all ladies. You must obey the religious and come with clothes that cover your shoulders and legs if uncovered. At the entrance you can find a very kind lady who will support you with a scarf if you have forgot about this obligation.
Many thanks for your hospitality and kindness.

body:
The former majestic theatre attracted the most glamorous opera stars from China. With their beautifully painted faces and exquisite costumes, they performed to capacity audiences. Standing ovations and catcalls filled the theatre every night. Graceful hostesses sashayed amongst the patrons, serving wine and tea with teasing smiles.

This was originally a Cantonese opera house built by philanthropist Eu Tong Sen in 1927 for his wife after she was refused admittance to another opera performance house. A highlight of this Art Deco building is its decorated façade of hand-painted tiles depicting opera characters and flying dragons. Not content with building merely one theatre, Eu bought all the properties on the entire street, popularly known then as Theatre Street.
description:

body:
A JOURNEY OF FUN AND DISCOVERY

Explore and enjoy 20 different interactive touch-points over 10 content zones. Learn about the history and development of Changi, go behind the scenes of its operations and play games simulating airport functions. A fascinating of discovery and play for both adults and children alike. 

EXPERIENCE THE MAGIC OF TECHNOLOGY

Experience magical surprises through state-of-the-art technology that is first in Singapore and Asia. Highlights include a garden that sings, and adrenaline-pumping runway race, a quest to collect airport trolleys, a battle of smiles, a journey through time and space... and more. Set aside 90 minutes to see it all!
description: Go on a journey of fun and discovery through the exciting virtual world of Changi Airport! Engage in the wonder of amazing projection experiences and enjoy interactive games and immersive shows. In this first-of-its-kind digital attraction, experience the magic of technology and learn about aviation and what makes the airport tick.
name: Changi Experience Studio

reviews.text: Total new experience, good for young and old.. have lot of fun and interaction with the digital experience, try the smile challenge and my mum hit the 9th position, the music playground and of course try the cycling... Support local tourism @ jewel and visit the Changi Experience Studio and level 4
My family and friends love the bicycle race.

Located at Level 4, Lobby C,Jewel Changi.  Interesting,discover the journey of building Changi Airport by placing Travel Guide(plain card). Many interactive activities.
Hanging Garden,exploring how Sunflower garden being built,Changi have their own flower nursery
Smile challenge with your friends.

We like the Amazing Runway,race between plane and porsche. Is fun but tiring,the best is with 3-4 persons challenge with each others. Will always win,if you are at the team plane.

Games,
1)Check in game,add up the baggage weight and check any prohibited items so as to decide if passengers are cleared to check-in.
2)Baggage sorting game,had to guide the various luggages onto the correct belt.
3)Aircraft turnaround game,had to ensure disembark passengers, clean the plane and board the passengers in the shortest turnaround time 4)Immigration game,had to match the correct visitors' fingerprints,starting easy till ending is difficult to find.
5)Security Officer,from the scanning baggage had to spot dangerous items,knives,baseball stick,etc. Quite difficult to spot because things are overlapping each others. Now I understand why take times at the queue of immigration.
6) Nectar collecting game,collect as much as u can,in order to get points for shopping discount.

Would like to Thank you,
-the young man(Indian or Malay guy)that attend my colleague,suddenly felt unwell in the studio. He gave water and suggest him to lay down and rest and keep checking on him whether he is feeling better or not.
-the Chinese auntie,that helped to clear the vomit.
-And then 2 ladies came too to ask need any medical assistance.

Definitely worthed a visit! You learn a lot about Changi's past, present, and future in a very special and unique way. If visiting Jewel, plan on spending at least an extra hour for Changi Experience studio.
Must visit!

body:
Fascinating wall murals have been mushrooming all over the city in recent years, thanks to Singaporean artists like Yip Yew Chong. His work isn’t just Instagram-worthy, it’s turning roads, like this one in Chinatown, into street museums.

Yew Chong painted these murals from his personal memories of Singapore’s past – he grew up in Sago Lane, a street across the road. The Paper Mask & Puppet Seller (on the right) was inspired by a real person who sold masks on this very street. And the Indian man in The Mamak Store (on the left) was a shop owner who sold Yew Chong sweets and knick-knacks, and taught him his first Tamil words when he was a kid. Keep an eye out for more of his street art around Chinatown – they can be found at various parts of Singapore too.
description: A collection of 2 murals by local artist Yip Yew Chong
name: Mohamed Ali Lane Murals: Paper Mask & Puppet Seller and Mamak Store

admissionInfo: Free admission
body:
During the early 20th century and late 1900s, the most defining feature of affluent Peranakan* houses was the intricate tiles that embellished the facades, courtyards and furniture.

A Peranakan himself, Victor Lim, owner of Peranakan Tiles Gallery, turned his childhood passion for these heritage gems into a unique business. As a teenager in the 70s, he salvaged vintage tiles from demolished traditional Peranakan shophouses all over Singapore, and restored them to their original grandeur. Today, his beautifully restored pieces of art are being displayed and sold at his gallery – yes, you can own a piece of Singapore history.

Like a museum, it houses an impressive collection with historical significance. Victor’s personal favourite, among the 20,000 tiles he has collected, is one that was shipped over from a church in England over a hundred years ago. Turn the page to see why there’s a lot more to this site than meets the eye.

*The term is an Indonesian/Malay word that means “local born”, which generally refers to people of Chinese and Malay/Indonesian heritage.
description: A museum showcasing vintage Peranakan tiles from the early 20th century
name: Peranakan Tiles Gallery

reviews.text: I stumbled into this quaint gallery and shop that's moving to a new location on Temple Street soon, and really loved it. A lovely lady walked around with me and gave me a bit of a history lesson on the origins of these old and beautifully restored tiles. Fascinating. Check it out if you can. It's free to enter and you can purchase these incredible pieces.

【2019.12.27】
This's the BEST Peranakan tiles shop, we believe!!

The tiles are so beautiful and the variety of them are so wide , but the hospitalities of shop staffs are really worth!!

You should go and feel the air, and get some your favorite tiles, hopefully.
Beautiful shop full of amazing restored antique tiles from many eras and styles. Very friendly and helpful staff.

You must be here to experience the depth of Peranakan and SINGAPORE culture.
The products are too beautiful to choose one.
The owner and shop staffs are too nice to leave the store after shopping!

Terrible service , check my conversation with them - how do you communicate with customers? I bought in person previously but needed some more sent -after they never responded to my last message (OK, you don't want to post, just be polite, no need to ignore and be rude) I found THE SAME TILES made by other tile manufacturers in Singapore and Kuala Lumpur 80% cheaper - so Ive just order 3 crates from KL.

admissionInfo: Strictly by Appointments
body:
Founded in 2003, The Intan is a Peranakan heritage home-museum. The brainchild of antique collector and owner Alvin Yapp, The Intan (meaning 'rose-cut diamond' in Malay) enlightens its guests about the multi-facetted aspects of Peranakan culture through a kaleidoscope of rare historical artefacts, intriguing personal stories, and authentic dining experiences.
Located in the heart of Joo Chiat, a traditional Peranakan enclave and Singapore’s ﬁrst heritage town (2011), The Intan offers personalised tours conducted by Alvin, which culminate with authentic Peranakan tea sessions and dinners inspired by his mother. The Intan also doubles up as a unique event space, having hosted a variety of activities that included jewellery exhibitions, art shows and violin recitals.
Awarded Best Tour Experience by Singapore Tourism Awards 2016 and voted Best Overall Experience in Singapore’s inaugural Museum Roundtable Awards, The Intan has been featured internationally on CNN Travel, Discovery Channel and National Geographic. Singapore Travelholic lists The Intan as the top 5 Peranakan activities to do in Singapore.
With a vision to promote Peranakan culture beyond Singapore, The Intan’s collection has been showcased in places such as Croatia, Hawaii and Hong Kong
description: Founded in 2003, The Intan is a Peranakan heritage home-museum. The brainchild of antique collector and owner Alvin Yapp, The Intan (meaning 'rose-cut diamond' in Malay) enlightens its guests about the multi-facetted aspects of Peranakan culture through a kaleidoscope of rare historical artefacts, intriguing personal stories, and authentic dining experiences. Located in the heart of Joo Chiat, a traditional Peranakan enclave and Singapore’s ﬁrst heritage town (2011), The Intan offers personalised tours conducted by Alvin, which culminate with authentic Peranakan tea sessions and dinners inspired by his mother. The Intan also doubles up as a unique event space, having hosted a variety of activities that included jewellery exhibitions, art shows and violin recitals. Awarded Best Tour Experience by Singapore Tourism Awards 2016 and voted Best Overall Experience in Singapore’s inaugural Museum Roundtable Awards, The Intan has been featured internationally on CNN Travel, Discovery Channel and National Geographic. Singapore Travelholic lists The Intan as the top 5 Peranakan activities to do in Singapore. With a vision to promote Peranakan culture beyond Singapore, The Intan’s collection has been showcased in places such as Croatia, Hawaii and Hong Kong.
name: The Intan
notes: Strictly by Appointments

reviews.text: Fantastic cozy experience. Alvin the homeowner is an amazing story teller and brings history to life. Don’t walk in, better connect With the museum before you go.

Closed yet according to Google it is open Monday morning at 11:30.

Seems it is only by appointment, so no walk in.

Very nice part of Singapore though to stroll around and have lunch ;)

SGD 60 per Visitor.

A great stop; well worth leaving the more congested tourist  parts of the city. Learn not just about Peranakan Culture, but gain a better understanding of Singapore and the relationship between it's different groups. Highly recommended.

(All photos without filter, it’s that colourful)
In the past I only knew Peranakan as Nyonya cuisine and colourful/ floral patterns. After visiting this house, through various types of collections (especially the well-made slippers upstairs) and explanation on how they were used and where they were arranged in a house,  I feel like I have a fundamental and memorable understanding of peranakan people and their culture. Singapore does not have that many historical/ cultural spots so this is definitely recommended! Instagrammable too 😉

A lovely museum, and the multi-hyphenated museum curator, Peranakan owner bring this place alive. The haven of collectables is alive with his explanation into the history, culture and lifestyle of the Peranakan. Highly recommended for those who are keen to know more about Alvin, his story and traditions of the Peranakan.

admissionInfo: Cinematic experience featuring a state-of-the-art 6D cinema and the full sensory exploration of The Macallan Sherry Oak and Double Cask expressions. The Sensory Cinema screenings will take place from 12:00pm to 8:40pm with screenings every 20 minutes.
body:
Presenting The Macallan Experience at Raffles Hotel Singapore; a key highlight of this iconic experiential space that encapsulates the fundamental chapters of our story through engaging and inspiring storytelling. For a limited period of just four months from 26th October 2020 to 10th February 2021, The Macallan Experience will take guests on an immersive, sensorial and memorable whisky journey. The journey begins by taking you deep into the heart of The Macallan, where our legendary casks mark the start of the journey. Here you will feel the heat, the sounds and the vigour captured in the process of cask making by the craftsmen of Jerez de la Frontera in Southern Spain, who have handcrafted every single oak cask to our exacting standards.

Moving from the cask journey, you will be captivated by a full sensory exploration of The Macallan. A state of the art 6D cinema delivers the pinnacle cinematic tasting experience, taking you deeper into our world with exceptionally memorable moments embedded within awe-inspiring immersive storytelling. Witness moments of commitment and dedication through stories that inspire and bring to life the dedication to creation that has shaped The Macallan’s history and future; the inspiration to choose the risks worth taking. Each ticket to the cinematic tasting experience is priced at SGD$28.

Take a journey through time and immerse in the rich heritage of The Macallan with our archival gallery; an ultimate showcase of The Macallan’s rare collections from the archives. Discover an extensive library of some of the oldest and rarest whiskies such as The Macallan 72 Years Old in Lalique , The Macallan in Lalique Six Pillars Collection, Fine and Rare and Masters of Photography. , Raffles Special and Diamond Jubilee. An interactive kinetic art installation inspired by The Macallan Six Pillars created exclusively for The Macallan Experience, brings our stories to life through artistic formations. Designed collaboratively by neuroscience agency, Rebel and Soul and award-winning creative technology agency, FutureLabs, this spectacularly innovative creation allows guests to interact with formations as they transition and alter to different shapes representing the nature and craft of the exceptional single malt, The Macallan.

Experience the finest range of exquisite single malts and curated cocktails at a dedicated whisky lounge bringing you into the ultimate world of The Macallan, storytelling and conversations. For those seeking further exploration, private master classes and tasting experiences are also available to book. To complete the whisky journey, a fine selection of The Macallan whiskies and merchandise, including limited editions and releases will also be available for sale. 

In celebration of the long-standing and fruitful partnership with Raffles Hotel Singapore, the two iconic brands proudly present the private VIP Dining Room experience, where a curated and exclusive menu by award-winning chefs, uniquely paired with The Macallan whiskies, will be unveiled every month. Gourmet seekers can look forward tasting the exquisite flavours of The Macallan whiskies alongside cuisine created by Pierre Burgade, Executive Chef of Raffles Hotel Singapore, and his team of Chefs de Cuisine from La Dame de Pic, 藝 yì by Jereme Leung, and Butcher’s Block .
description: The ultimate brand experience of our remarkable single malt at one of Singapore’s most famous icons.
name: The Macallan Experience at Raffles Hotel Singapore
notes: Closed on designated public holidays

address.buildingName: Lee Kong Chian Natural History Museum

admissionInfo: For full admission info, please visit https://www.sistic.com.sg/events/lkc2015
body:
Get acquainted with the incredible world of biodiversity at Singapore’s one and only natural history museum. Be awed by our three real and gigantic sauropod dinosaurs that take centre stage at the Lee Kong Chian Natural History Museum. Learn about the biologically diverse ecosystem of Southeast Asia through our 2,000 specimens and interactive displays.

Lee Kong Chian Natural History Museum looks forward to engage visitors on biodiversity, environment and conservation topics in and of South-east Asia. The iconic rock-like building, located at National University of Singapore, 2 Conservatory Drive Singapore 117377, will be a one-stop exhibition, education and research facility servicing a multitude of biodiversity activities in Singapore and the region.
description: Lee Kong Chian Natural History Museum
name: Lee Kong Chian Natural History Museum

reviews.text:
A very good place to gather knowledge about nature and history. Good detailing about all the animals and their origins are given. It's an amazing place to know about your favorite animal. I am amazed to see that.
One can spent good 2 to 3 hours if interested to read and go through the details. Otherwise an hour is enough.
Good exposure for kids to generate new and interesting thoughts.
Great place for a different type of family experience in Singapore when you're tired of the zoo, bird park and river safari . Quite a stunning collection !

This is the most impressive museum in Singapore. There are 3 full dinosaurs fossils and lots of fossils and preserved bodies of other animals including a whale, crocodiles, tigers , bats, butterflies, etc. There are 2 levels of exhibits in this museum. It is a highly recommended to visit in Singapore.

Finally Singapore has our own Natural History Museum. Looks smaller scale as compared to overseas version but the specimens are no less impressive. The dinosaurs and Sperm Whale is obviously the centre of the draw. Other interesting facts about specimens and history of nature in this part of the world is also truly fascinating. It is a pity that time slot is limited during this Covid-19 situation. Didnt manage to complete the whole place before closing hours. Will be a nice place to bring the kids to learn more about nature world and start them on a fascinating journey on our world.
Mammals, amphibians, reptiles, birds, insects, aquatic and prehistoric creature exihibits in great display with the taxidermy.

body: The four-storey Indian Heritage Centre fuses traditional and modern architectural elements. Inspired by the stepwells in India, the unique glass façade is a large mirror by day and turns transparent at night to reveal a ‘glowing lantern’ of the façade’s colourful mural. The centre showcases Indian culture and history, and houses a permanent exhibition titled, ‘Indians in Singapore - Past & Present’. Through the displays and with the help of audio guides and augmented reality technology, visitors will discover connections between South Asia and Southeast Asia, and gain a better understanding of the Indian community in Singapore. The centre also provides venues ideal for conducting events, seminars and workshops. Grab a Little India Heritage Trail booklet from its Visitor Services Counter and embark on three specially curated thematic routes around the Little India neighbourhood that features over 40 heritage sites. The trail is available till 8 July 2020.
description: Discover more about Indian culture and history through the displays, audio guides and augmented reality technology.
name: Indian Heritage Centre

pricing.others: Adult S$6, Senior Citizen & Student S$4; Free admission for child under six

reviews.text: Lots of culture staff for Indians
Very interesting centre, I learnt a lot about the culture. The staff is very polite and really nice. You feel welcomed.
Very good. Made me proud. But old as I used to handle some of the artifacts personally when I was a kid. Nostalgic journey for me!
You need to have a guide for the best experience. It was an eye-opening experience.
Nice museum with lots of artifacts from Indian Singaporeans. It also gives you a history of India/Singapore relations. Adult entry is 8$.

body:
Learn about the rich history of Singapore’s Malay community through artefacts and interactive displays.

The centre occupies the grounds of the original Istana Kampong Glam which was built in 1819 by Sultan Hussein Mohamed Shah, and was home to Malay royalty for over 50 years.

Head over to their website to learn more about the latest exhibitions and programmes offered by the centre.
description: Learn about the rich history of Singapore’s Malay community through artefacts and interactive displays.
name: Malay Heritage Centre

reviews.text:
It's clean and well preserved. The overall design is retained however the palace grounds is improved with modern landscape. The contents of the museum is so insufficient to reflect the true Malay culture. The kampung spirit and the simple lifestyle of the Malays.
Not much history about the inhabitants of the palace. I know as my great grandmother was an inhabitant there. Direct descendent of Sultan Hussein.
Memories

My children appreciated how difficult travelling by ship was for people who wanted to go Mecca for their pilgrimage. The artefacts caught their attention too as they think about how it is made and used.
I enjoyed touring around. Nice to look back at the past and realize there are so many changes that happened to Malay.
Well maintained and very clean. Contents may not be as complete but still good enough to learn more about the Malay culture

body: The Istana Heritage Gallery offers visitors the opportunity to learn about the history of the Istana and learn about the President’s constitutional, ceremonial and community roles. It was officially opened in October 2016 by Singapore’s former President Tony Tan, and its curated collection includes artefacts and State Gifts, as well as a replica of a signing-in table used during State Visits by foreign leaders. Also on display is a reference piece of the bust of Singapore’s late first president, Encik Yusof Bin Ishak, whose portrait is featured on the country’s currency notes. The gallery is located in Istana Park, which is across the road from the Istana, and can accommodate a maximum capacity of 45 pax. Admission is free, but an advance notice of two weeks is required for group visits. Visitors are to conduct themselves in a respectable and careful way in the gallery; selfie sticks and tripods are prohibited, and children below the age of 12 have to be accompanied by an adult at all times.
description: Learn about the history of The Istana, the official residence of Singapore’s president, and the role of the president.
name: Istana Heritage Gallery

reviews.text: Good place to learn Singaporean history. You will be able to see some gifts from foreign countries. They are worth seeing. It’s small but enough displays. It’s free admission. Excellent volunteer guide supports you.
The host of the gallery was nice and welcoming.  A must see if you want to know more about the Istana.
This is my volunteer duty work place
We will get knowledge of how Singapore was built

Visited the Gallery today.
The place was not as big as I imagined but it was not cramped. It is  a good place to go to if you want to know it's history.
The chronicles are quite systematic.  The pictures and images are good.
Managed to recall all pass Presidents.
The 2 staff who are on duty today were very efficient.
The only thing need to improve is maybe should have more exhibits.
And there is a park where you can have a stroll. Only need more shades and seats. There is also an Art Cafe where you can enjoy some live art work.
I walked pass a Bistro too bit did not check it out.

body: Images of Singapore LIVE employs actors and special effects to construct a narrative of Singapore’s history from its past as a Malay fishing village to the present day. During the 30-minute character-guided tour, visitors can interact with the guide and gain insights into Singapore’s history through nine immersive themed areas. The tour ends with the Spirit of Singapore Boat Ride, during which iconic landmarks and the founder of modern Singapore, Sir Stamford Raffles, make an appearance. Photography is not allowed. Tickets include admission to Madame Tussauds™ Singapore, which houses approximately 60 life-sized wax figures, including Singapore’s first Prime Minister, late Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew, who is depicted with his wife Kwa Geok Choo. Also featured are international personalities such as Formula 1 racing driver Lewis Hamilton, martial artist Bruce Lee and actor Shah Rukh Khan.
description: Watch actors and special effects construct a narrative of Singapore’s history from 1819 to the present day.
name: Images of Singapore LIVE
notes: Last Admission: 7pm

pricing.others: Adult S$42, Child aged 12 and below S$32; Includes admission to Madame Tussauds Singapore

reviews.text: Images of Singapore is Located in the same complex as Madame Tussauds. It is a wonderful way to learn about the history of Singapore right from when it was a Small British trading Post to the Present Day. The experience now is more interactive and engaging than previously when it was just a museum like presentation. Definitely a must visit if you like history and Nostalgia.

Highly contrived with bare minimum details about the history of Singapore. The old version Images of Singapore was much better, about 15 years ago.
The boat ride at the beginning is a joke, taking barely 2 minutes to go around, with so little to see.
Pease give an option for the 4 attractions under separate ticketing instead of a bundle for all 4 as they cater to different age groups.
Overall a very disappointing experience.

We only wanted to see the Images og Singapore but had to buy entrance to Madam Tussaud’s in order to get access..
The experience was not great, it was expected to have a guide through out the whole experience but there were none at a big part of it. The boat ride was pure disappointment, and honestly don’t understand why it was even made..
Very interesting way to a nation's history. The interactive live show surely leaves a deeper trail of memory, compared to usual  tedious reading at history museums.

Great place for everyone to learn the history of Singapore. The concept consists of about 5-6 rooms with an character in each room who will share their nostalgic piece of history. Travellers will be moving from room to room.

body: The Vintage Camera’s Museum is Singapore’s first and only museum dedicated entirely to antique photography. Its all-white camera-shaped building with an entrance shaped like a lens is hard to miss and its interior boasts a collection just as impressive. With over 1,000 cameras on display, some dating from as far back as the 1800s, the museum is a photography enthusiast’s haven and a site where amateur photographers can get an in-depth understanding about the history of photography. Its collection includes a six-metre-long Mammoth Camera as well as miniature spy cameras featured in movies such as James Bond. Visitors can also handle and try some of the cameras for themselves. Email to enquire about group deals.
description: Examine cameras that date as far back as the 1800s and learn about the history of photography at the Vintage Camera's Museum.
name: Vintage Camera's Museum

pricing.others: Adult S$20, Child S$15, Senior Citizen S$15

reviews.text:
Quaint and unique museum just steps away from Arab Street. The staff is extremely kind and knowledgeable. A very boutique experience. Definitely worth a detour. You will hardly find yourself in a museum in the shape of a camera ever again.
There is an astonishing variety of cameras of all ages and sizes. The instructional videos are helpful.
Also, the click art room with the painted illusions is really nice and the staff takes pictures of you.

Small little museum and I would consider this a hidden find. Never knew there is a camera museum in Singapore. The person must have spent a bomb on the collections. Vintage and every milestone in photography, definitely an eye-opener. The tour was a good one, carried out by a photography enthusiast - brief and simple, what amazed me was the collection that is on display. Surprisingly spent longer than intended as we took a walk through history of photography in a small little space.

It's a wonderful experience. We got to learn a whole fascinating history of Camera. Its evolution, the changes and various designs it went through to finally arrive at the present digital camera we use today is filled with interesting facts, innovations which are really attention catching. We also got to have a go at all the olden time cameras and use them.
Really memorable experience. Do visit this Museum and get your pictures clicked by olden time cameras to capture the special moment.

The museum itself was very interesting if you are interested in film cameras. Lots to look at and appreciate.
Unfortunately the guy behind the counter spent the entire time on his phone and did not even speak to us. Great museum but if you are looking for human interaction - forget it.

The museum is like a big room with all the different cameras through the years. The history on how it was developed was very educating. You can take photos and even hold some of the camera relics. This is great for photography enthusiasts. It could be developed more by adding more exhibits of old photos and probably have a souvenir shop. As a photographer, I personally enjoyed my visit here :)

body: Also known as Silat Road Sikh Temple, it was previously situated at Pearl’s Hill, where the Sikh police barracks and quarters were located. The majority of Sikhs who came to Singapore in the 19th century took on jobs as policemen. The temple, in addition to being a place of worship, also served as a meeting ground for their family and friends. As more Sikhs arrived, a larger site—comprising a temple and living quarters—was erected at Jalan Bukit Merah, formerly known as Silat Road. The temple contains the world’s largest palki, a palanquin used to hold the scripture when a priest leads prayers, which weighs ten tonnes. Some visitors drop by to view the tombstone of the late Sikh freedom fighter Bhai Maharaj Singh, who is believed to answer prayers.
description: This Sikh temple houses a seven-storey shrine as well as the Sikh Heritage Centre, allowing visitors to learn more about Sikh History & Culture.
name: Gurdwara Sahib Silat Road

reviews.text: Is a calm place for meditation

I would love to go there for pry, that please serve food ( Langer) Hole day long any one can have
Great
A great place to have a peaceful mind, you can volunteer here too
Nice n calm place to maditate....

The gurudwaras all around the world are serving mankind without being biased to anybody.
This temple has given me pleasant fond memories,
Whenever I was hungry and had no money in my pockets this Sikh temple was the place I went to.

I am highly thankful and grateful to the Sikh community and it’s temples worldwide.....🙏❤️❤️

body: The iconic Sultan Mosque, built in 1824, is a landmark of the Kampong Glam district, which attracts many who are keen to discover the culture and history of Malays, one of Singapore’s main ethnic groups. Also known as Masjid Sultan, the mosque’s name pays homage to Sultan Hussein Mohamed Shah, the first Sultan of Singapore and 18th ruler of Johor. In 1975, it was gazetted as a national monument. The mosque’s mass prayer hall can host up to 5,000 visitors. While its two giant golden domes make for an impressive sight, their bases are adorned with glass bottle ends, which were donated by poor Muslims during its construction, so that all Muslims, not just the rich, could contribute. Guided tours are given by multilingual docents in English, Malay, Japanese and Chinese, among other languages. Docents vary from day to day depending on their scheduled duties and it is best for travellers to call ahead to check if their preferred language is available.
description: Built in 1824, this landmark of the Kampong Glam district attracts many who are keen to learn about Malay history and culture.
name: Sultan Mosque

reviews.text: Prayer by booking only due to covid 19

Always such a joy coming here! Memorable and very historic! Situated in the heart of Arab street and the facilities are large and comfortable. Highly recommend checking it out and praying here if you're in Singapore!

Arab Street and it's surrounding area is the perfect place to come to experience being somewhere away from the modern architecture of Singapore. There is a very good variety of authentic middle eastern dishes and nice way to spend a pleasant afternoon browsing the shops.

WONDERFULL MOSQUE!
once toured around this area, there are various souvenir shops with affordable prices, there are also several Middle Eastern restaurants, so when you are hungry and want to eat halal food, you will not have trouble finding halal food around here.
I would love to come back here soon.

Wherever I go abroad, I try to find the local mosque. My first solo traveling was nice when i found this mosque, place is clean and spacious, walking distance from my hostel and at night its so good there.

admissionInfo: Free
body: Located along the Marina Bay Waterfront Promenade, the Fullerton Heritage precinct comprises The Fullerton Hotel Singapore and The Fullerton Bay Hotel Singapore, as well as lifestyle and dining destinations The Fullerton Waterboat House, One Fullerton, The Fullerton Pavilion, The Clifford Pier and Customs House. On the lobby level of the Fullerton Hotel is The Fullerton Heritage Gallery, which displays decades-old photographs, maps, stamps and philatelic materials that showcase the district’s rich history. The district is within walking distance to the Merlion Park and is also a popular spot to watch the Marina Bay fireworks display on occasions like National Day and New Year’s Eve. On The Fullerton Monument Tour, visitors will be led by a tour guide to discover the rich history of the Fullerton Building, where Singapore’s General Post Office was once located. The tour is open to the public on Mondays and Thursdays at 11.15am and Saturdays at 3.45pm. Another tour, A Maritime Journey Tour, steers visitors on the story of Singapore’s historic waterfront that began as a trading post in 1819. The tour is also open to public on Fridays at 3.45pm and Sundays at 11.15am. Tours can be booked up to one month in advance and participants will meet at The Fullerton Hotel’s concierge. Admission is free, but private guided tours can also be arranged at a fee.
description: The Fullerton Heritage District showcases the precinct’s rich history and is also a popular spot to watch the Marina Bay fireworks display on occasions like National Day and New Year’s Eve.
name: The Fullerton Heritage Singapore
notes: Varies by establishment, see website for more details

reviews.text: Great place for dinning, leisure and exercising. The scenarios is superb by the bay and adequate space for everyone to enjoy. It will be good to go at the period before sunset to capture photos of the bay sceneries, follow by dinning at the many restaurants there and then take photos again when the night falls.

Excellent view of the pier and good choice of wines. Wonderful place to visit if you wish to impress a girlfriend.

admissionInfo: Free
body: The Changi Museum documents significant events that occurred during WWII and the Japanese Occupation. Often included in tours about the city-state’s wartime past, the museum also commemorates the prisoners-of-war and civilians who were detained in Changi Prison during the war. Among the wartime artefacts on display are photographs, artwork by several detainees and a duplicate of the famous Changi Murals that Stanley Warren, one of the POWs, painted during his incarceration. Located in the centre of the museum is the Changi Chapel, a replica of the one built by the POWs.
description: This museum commemorates the prisoners-of-war and civilians who were detained in Changi Prison during World War II. History buffs will learn more about the significant events that occurred in Singapore during the Japanese Occupation.
name: Changi Museum
notes: For more information, please visit the official website.

reviews.text: Very well designed and laid out with some moving accounts of WWII memorabilia. Be prepared to spend a minimum of half a day here.

Changi Chapel & Museum are closed for renovation works until 2020. There is currently no forecast for its reopening to the public. If you are already here, you can visit the nearby Changi Village or Changi Jewel.

Hear the curator of Typesettingsg Yao Yu share more on the history of letterpress printing and how it contributed to Singapore's history, and later, learn how to operate the printing press and create your own unique piece of print.

body: Baba House is a museum in Singapore, showcasing Peranakan history, architecture and heritage. It is a traditional Peranakan pre-war terrace-house which was formerly owned by the family of a 19th-century shipping tycoon Wee Bin who settled in Singapore, after arriving from the southern Chinese province of Fujian.

The house is really beautiful, with lots of details in decorations, furnitures, etc. definitely a worth exploring experience.
Wonderful experience. If you are interested in Peranakan culture you should visit this place. They have great guide and you'll have a good time here
Excellent place to go for an authentic knowledge of wealthy living of the Peranakn, with a glimpse of conservation engineering.
It was nice experience, I recommend spend time to know more about interesting Peranakan culture. Book online in advance

body: Along Mohammed Ali Lane, you’ll spot another snapshot of history—a quirky scene of Singapore’s street vendors from our early years of independence in the 1960s. To gain insights into our city’s yesteryears, observe the detailed renderings of old-school goodies in the Mamak Store (provisions stall). A few steps away, a craftsman presents an amusing assortment of masks and toys, while Samsui women (female migrant workers from Sansui District, China, known for their iconic red headscarves) watch from the sidewalk. The mural also depicts a craftsman making a lion dance head, the mural is based off the actual shop at No. 3 Ann Siang Hill in the 1980s.

To gain insights into our city’s yesteryears, observe the detailed renderings of old-school goodies in the Mamak Store (provisions stall). The mural also depicts a craftsman making a lion dance head, the mural is based off the actual shop at No. 3 Ann Siang Hill in the 1980s.
name: Old Trades Mural

body:
Telok Ayer Church ranks as the oldest among Methodist Chinese speaking churches. Deep in the heart of the old Chinese settlement, the church was the base from which the Methodist pioneer missionary, Dr. Benjamin West, reached out to the migrated Chinese. Amazingly, after so many years, the church building has kept to the original design with little alteration to the exterior look. The basic design is western: a rectangular main body sitting on arch colonnades. But the architecture added an open pavilion on the roof at the front of the building. The roof of the pavilion is carved in the traditional Chinese manner. By this addition, the basically Roman styled building is given a Chineseness that will speak to the migrant Chinese and be identified with them.

Because of the history and uniqueness of the Church building, on 23 March 1989, the government announced that Telok Ayer Church would be preserved as a National Monument. In the following year, in response to the Government's preservation as National Monument, the Church embarked on a major extension and renovation work to restore the Church building to its original grandeur. Started in October 1993, the preservation and conservation project ended in August 1995 at a total cost of $3M.

body: Take a peek into what it was like during the early years of Singapore and learn about the personal stories of those who made Chinatown their home.
description: Take a peek into what it was like during the early years of Singapore and learn about the personal stories of those who made Chinatown their home.
name: Chinatown Heritage Centre
notes: Chinese New Year Eve - Closes 5pm, Chinese New Year First Day - Closed

reviews.text: It is a place where experiences from my 4 months in Asia were sinking in. It shows traditional lives as they were and as they still are in Chinese live-in eateries in Vientiane or on the bustling streets of Chinatown in Bangkok. Personal stories and family stories make one think about the lives of immigrants of old and new times. They also make you think about your own life story. The whole place is also a subtle homage to Chinese culture. Beautiful for anyone who has ever visited and admired China.
Great place to catch up how the good old days are like... in chinatown...

Great museum experience that isn’t cliched. And best part is that it’s privately owned, so not much full-blown propaganda here. You get to have a glimpse of living in a shophouse like in the 40s-60s, which is an insightful experience. Worth mentioning also are the brochures - informative and creatively made. Thumbs up! Please carry on the great effort in educating about this niche. 👍
Chinese food fix, as good as you'd expect and reasonably priced places galore!
Amazing Chinatown! It's much more interesting and picturesque of many I've seen around the world because of architectural beauty and wonderful vibes. Food court is just great!

body: When the Japanese bombed Singapore between December 1941 and January 1942, residents in this area dashed here for cover. During peace time, the bomb shelter was planned to be used as a covered playground for children.

The air raid shelter at Blk 78 Guan Chuan Street is the last remaining pre-war civilian air raid shelter and the only public housing building by the Singapore Improvement Trust (SIT) to have been built with an air raid shelter as part of its design. Today, it is conserved as part of the Tiong Bahru Conservation Area. Visit Singapore’s only remaining pre-war air raid shelter, nestled in the heart of 1930s Tiong Bahru, one of Singapore's first public housing estates.

body:
About the Royal Albatross

Welcome onboard the Royal Albatross, Asia’s only 22 sail 4 mast traditionally rigged luxury tall ship. Get inspired by the massive Dacron canvas sails, tall wooden masts and luxurious handcrafted woodwork on board the ship which took craftsman over 360,00 man-hours and over 6 years to redesign. The Royal Albatross was designed by Hollywood Master Rigger, Jim Barry who was involved in the designing of the ships in Master & Commander and Pirates of the Caribbean and had even appeared in the movie “Dark Knight” as Bruce Wayne’s private yacht. This famous ship played host to international guests like Princess Anne, Actress Jane Seymour, and many others. Indulge yourself from the time you board with a specially crafted welcome drink. Make memories on board the ship and enjoy the company of your loved ones as we set sail with a specially curated 3-course menu. Choose to venture on 2 very unique sailing experiences by sailing into the Sunset or watching as Singapore’s Cityscape light up at night with fireworks en-route. Experience something unique onboard the Royal Albatross.

American Origins

The Royal Albatross started her life in Charleston, South Carolina, the USA in 2001 as Windy II. Used for day trips and cruises along Lake Michigan and the Great Lakes. She participated in regional tall ship festivals and races along the summer months. She was acquired in 2008 and relocated Singapore from Chicago 15,000Km away. The Royal Albatross is currently the only Tall Ship in Asia. What the name stands for The Albatross family has 22 species of birds which represents each one of the 22 sails onboard the ship. The largest most elegant species of the Albatross family is the Royal Albatross. And similar to the Royal Albatross the ship in all its brilliance can cover great distances at sea elegantly and effortlessly.


Traditional Uses

Tall ships were used as the only form of global transport in the Golden age of Discovery, Ships like these could cover massive distances across the oceans and were usually in charge of carrying precious cargo for international trade. In fact, a similar tall ship the Santa Maria famously transported Christopher Columbus from Spain to discover America in 1492.   Over time thousands of these ships were lost at sea, leaving today; less than 100 working tall ships in existence, most of them owned by Navy’s, Trusts and NPO’s. A few are in private ownership and certified for passenger service for the public to use.  Of these few, the Royal Albatross the only one reconfigured to a luxury specification, making her the most unique luxury Tall Ship in the world!

Sticking to tradition, the Royal Albatross is a traditionally rigged Barquentine Class A Tall Ship with 22 sails, 4 masts, and over 200 ropes.  She requires a specialized crew to maintain her and manually operate the various sails on board the which add to the ship's unique appeal.
description: Enjoy romantic views as you set sail on Asia's only luxury tall ship
name: The Royal Albatross
notes: Please check sailing schedule for sailing times, https://www.tallship.com.sg/sailing-schedule/

reviews.text:
On behalf of my family, I would like to thank all the crew and especially, Ms Chloe for an awesome wife's birthday celebration on board.

The whole experience was excellent and meaningful for my family.. once again, THANK YOU ALL.

Long and beautiful ride.

I give 4* just because I sow the brochure on the table* please give a review* i did gave a review. And it was 5*. I sow after that * give a review and get 10% off your drinks* and I did tell that to the waiter but I still was charged fully.

As well as waiting time to leave the boat after the trip. I was rushing to leave the place so I asked If I can do so. Staff nicely explained that I have to wait and leaving is table by table. 15 min later still waiting..back again and finally- got a permission. So some people have to leave early due to the leaving policy and some should wait even want to leave first.

Other then that - good job.
Great food, even better service and a beautiful evening sailing around Singapore. Highly recommended.

body:
Singapore Philatelic Museum is the custodian and curator of Singapore's treasure of philatelic materials. The museum collections range from stamps and archival philatelic material of Singapore from the 1830s to present day, and stamps from member countries of the Universal Postal Union.

The Singapore Philatelic Museum is currently closed for revamp and is slated to be open in 2021.
description: Singapore Philatelic Museum is the custodian and curator of Singapore's treasure of philatelic materials.
name: Singapore Philatelic Museum
nearestMrtStation: City Hall, Clarke Quay, Bras Basah
notes: The Singapore Philatelic Museum is currently closed for revamp and is slated to be open in 2021.

body: Established in 1827, the Al-Abrar mosque on Telok Ayer Street is an example of the multi-cultural nature of the Chinatown district and is one of Singapore's oldest mosques. Located on the same street as the Nagore Dargah Indian Muslim Heritage Centre, Thian Hock Keng temple and the Telok Ayer Chinese Methodist Church, this mosque was first established for the Chulias - a group of Tamil Muslim settlers from South India. The building’s simple architectural design, which was designated a national monument in 1974, features western elements like French windows and Doric columns in its interiors, and now serves as an important place of worship for many office workers in the surrounding neighbourhood.
description: Established in 1827, the Al-Abrar mosque on Telok Ayer Street is one of Singapore's oldest mosques set up by the Chulias - a group of Tamil Muslim settlers from South India.
name: Al-Abrar Mosque

reviews.text: Nice masjid that is tucked away amongst the skyscrapers
Cosy little mosque 🕌 . Looking forward to the new look after the renovations
Historical building,easy to have praying but hard to get car park.

One of the few Mosques in the midst of the busiest part of town. Not a huge building but suitable if you are in the area and just need a place to solat or seek some personal tranquility. Friday sermons are held in Tamil and Arabic mostly.
India mosque in between cafes in telor ayer, Chinatown area. I was there for shalat jumat. The imam speaking in tamil language. What a new experience i ever had

body: Nestled between two shophouses along Keong Saik Road, Cundhi Temple is easy to overlook. Nonetheless, this tranquil place of worship holds fascinating insights into Chinese spiritual beliefs and traditional architecture. Dedicated to Cundhi Gong, a bodhisattva venerated in Mahayana Buddhism, this temple is rich with unique architectural details that incorporate both Eastern and Western influences. The interior and exterior columns of the temple possess a mix of Chinese and European features, while the circular windows are a mix of traditional and modern styles.
description: Dedicated to Cundhi Gong, a bodhisattva venerated in Mahayana Buddhism, this temple is rich with unique architectural details that incorporate both Eastern and Western influences.
name: Cundhi Gong Temple

reviews.text:
准提佛母, fondly addressed by many many worshippers around the world,  is a very merciful and extremely responsive bodhisattva who hears the needs and cries of the world .
.

Do you know that 四马路 guanyin temple is so 灵感 because she is also 准提佛母？
.
The moment you enter this 准提宫 along Keong Saik Rd , you will see the magnificent Goddess sitting right in the middle of the Hall .

.

.
Think this temple closes quite early . It will be safe to reach before 3pm .

.
If you would like to recite and honour her mantra , you can also search for it over at Youtube .

.
Thank you and stay happy ok
Chan buddhist temple of guan yin. Excellent and friendly people here :)

The quasi-lifting palace. For the first time in many years, I met the place of worship. It is fate. .
