Quasi Tipsa Temple

address.buildingName: Nagore Dargah Indian Muslim Heritage Centre

admissionInfo: Free
body: Indian Muslim culture and heritage come to life for visitors here through artefacts and engaging multimedia displays. The shrine was designated a national monument in 1974, before being turned into a heritage gallery for Indian Muslim culture and heritage in 2011.
description: The centre pays homage to the contributions of the Indian Muslim community here in Singapore.
name: Nagore Dargah Indian Muslim Heritage Centre

reviews.text: Beautiful and peaceful place to learn about the history of Indian Muslims in Singapore. The building itself is worth the walk and the exhibits inside are absolutely worth a visit.
Indian vibes.  Beautiful and unique architecture. Looking stunning in the street

Great little museum about the Indian Muslim migration to Singapore. Everything was well documented and personalized. The person working there was welcoming and friendly! Located in Chinatown near the hop-on hop-off bus.
Muhammad was very helpful and welcoming! Fascinating place to learn about the culture and history of Insian-muslims. ☺️ Quaint and free of charge! Nice place to stop by

it’s so great to see Singapore preserve these heritage sites! Nagore Tamil Nadu to Singapore is just amazing👌🏻👌🏻 Singapore you are purely multi cultural and you maintain every race and it’s  history is preserved👍👍

admissionInfo: Free Admission
body:
Walking along the streets in Chinatown, you will first be welcome by Nanyang Old Coffee shop of its wonderful coffee aroma. If you were to explore further by slurping into the great cup of Singapore traditional coffee, you will realise that this is a perfect embodiment of Singaporean’s life within this Singapore traditional coffee shop. Besides being awarded “The Best Singapore Traditional Coffee” and beloved by many local customers, Nanyang Old Coffee is beyond its great coffee, there is a myriad of memories, friendships, history and culture within a small cup of traditional coffee.

At level 2, there is a mini coffee museum in the café where you could feel the nostalgic atmosphere while enjoying your coffee. Nanyang Old Coffee is a place where the locals feel like home. For a tourist, it is a place where ones could experience the real, unpolished Singaporean way of living.
description: Enjoy a cup of Kopi in a Good Old Days Museum
name: Experiencing Singapore Coffeeshop Culture

admissionInfo: Please make a reservation to avoid disappointment. Thank you!
body:
Singapore Traditional Café has its own unique coffee culture! The session will be conducted in a nostalgic atmosphere of “Museum in a Café” area. Attendees could experience our local café culture and at the same time learn the coffee ordering lingo and enjoy the fun of making their own traditional coffee! Participants will indulge in our Street Food Combo Meal that makes up of Bak Kut Teh, Curry Chicken, Laksa and Chilli Crab Sauce with Crab Stick.

Topics sharing on:

1) Introduction of the characteristics of Singapore Traditional Coffee

2) The handmade Singapore Traditional Coffee and Its Brewing Equipment

3) The Brief History and Olden Days Culture of Singapore Coffeeshop

4) Hands-On Coffee Making & Coffee Appreciation

5) Indulge in a Combo Meal of Singapore where you could taste a variety of local street foods in one serving.
description: Learn the Singapore Coffee culture and its unique ordering lingo and experience the process of making a cup of authentic Singapore Traditional Coffee!
name: Singapore Traditional Coffee Hands-On Coffee Making Workshop

reviews.text: A little waiting time, so best to make sure you know what you want on menu before hand. Prepare for outdoor seating as limited indoor. If you can try going to level 2 from the side via staircase where more seating and a mini museum located. Order from level 2 for seating at level 2 too.

Poor service from the 2 person today.

1)when arrive, asked kindly to the 1 of the staff if I am able to put my stuff down first before I scan the QR code. At first I thought she didn't hear me so repeated twice then she took out her earphone and say "what you want?" with an attitude tone and give me a black face like it was my fault to ask nicely.

2) As I was already ordering my drinks with another staff, half way she just say "we closing in 30mins" in yet another rude tone. Why didn't they inform me when I first come in? And wait till I settle down and order half way then inform me about it?

I really don't understand why must both staff be so rude and give an attitude tone? When I was just asking nicely and also ordering normally.

So far I got no issue with any coffee stall place I went to for my entire life. But only this place seems to have an issue with me.

Coffee is good.
Services really damn bad

Had breakfast at one of singapore oldest coffee place. Located in the hustling area of chinatown. Ordered the coffee+toast+eggs meal set. Eggs were served at perfect temperature and coffee was nice too.
Set price was $5
Great place for a good kaya toast. One of the oldest place but one of the best certainly
A traditional Singaporean kopi shop. Reasonably priced, fast service, and good kopi... I recommend their chilli crab spaghetti.

admissionInfo:
•	Each guided tour is limited to 10 or less people and will take approximately 60 minutes.
•	Suitable for those who are new to whisky or experienced aficionados
•	Learn to identify unique unique whisky flavours through our curated tasting experience.
body: The Grande Whisky Collection is home to one of the largest collection of rare whiskies in the world. The museum’s vault houses priceless whiskies from some of the oldest and most established distilleries in Scotland and Japan, including some closed ones. At The Grande Whisky Collection, our Whisky Ambassadors will bring you on an interactive guided tour to discover the fascinating history and untold stories of whisky. Lookout for some of the rarest bottles of whiskies in the world, including the highly coveted Yamazaki 50, Royal Lochnagar 31-year old single cask (in which the entire cask is owned by The Whisky Trust Group), and others from Ardbeg, Auchentoshan, Dalmore, Macallan, Nikka, Oban, Saburomaru and more. Our tours are suited for those who are new to whisky or experienced aficionados. Guests will learn to identify unique whisky flavours and reminiscing aromas through our carefully curated whisky tasting experience at the end of the guided tour. There is also a Gift Shop which offers a unique range of merchandise that can be personalized with laser engraving.
companyDisplayName: THE GRANDE WHISKY COLLECTION PTE. LTD.
description: Asia's First Rare Whisky Museum
name: The Grande Whisky Collection
notes: Open Everyday.

reviews.text:
Tour was nice and entertaining but was tasting selections could have been more interesting.

Out of 9 whiskies our group tasted, only 1 can be said as really rare, the rest are standard offerings you can buy almost at any decent whisky shop.
Strongly recommended for the informative and interesting tour. The tasting flight was comprehensive and matches what was covered in the tour.

Interested in whisky, and have quite in-depth study about the category, I was excited to see there is a whisky collection in Singapore! The signs to the museum was very clear, though I had doubts at first, because it was leading towards the carpark. It is parked away in a corner of the carpark on the level 5 of Ion Orchard, with a very elegant sign on the way.

There was a counter at the entrance, with two indian staff chit-chatting behind the counter. I approached them, wanting to find out more about the place. Firstly, they were very caught them in their own jokes, and then when the male staff noticed me, he said something inaudible and made some incomprehensible gestures with a fierce face. Before I could even finish my sentence to ask more about this place, he said something else (most likely English but it is incomprehensible) in a very rude tone.

There was no intention to share with me what this collection is about, how I can get tickets, what I can get out of here. I did some research online afterwards, and to be honest the place is quite impressive. However, the image is totally destroyed by the staff, who cannot converse in English, unwelcoming, and disinterested in customer service. Without this part been fixed, I will definitely go out of my way to discourage my whisky friends to visit this place.
Great experience for any whisky connoisseur

source: THE GRANDE WHISKY COLLECTION PTE. LTD.

admissionInfo: Free
body: Set on a hilltop, Fort Canning Park is a respite from the surrounding urban landscape. The iconic 18-hectare park is steeped in history: Sir Stamford Raffles, the founder of modern Singapore, built a bungalow on Fort Canning Hill, and it became the home of subsequent colonial governors. Fort Canning Hill was a major communication centre, and key historic events took place here. Fort Gate, the remnant of a 19th century fortress, is also located in the park. Visitors will stumble upon these sites, as well as interesting flora and fauna on a self-guided 45-minute Colonial History Trail following storyboards and maps around the area. Visitors can also take a ticketed tour of the Battlebox, the British nerve centre for operations during World War II.
description: Situated in the central area of Singapore, Fort Canning Park is a landmark that showcases flora and fauna, as well as historical artefacts.
name: Fort Canning Park
nearestMrtStation: Dhoby Ghaut Station / Clarke Quay Station /  Fort Canning Station

reviews.text: Must go in the morning, too many places to visit

Take a stroll here to discover many of Singapore’s historical milestones. It was the Headquarters of the Far East Command Centre and British Army Barracks. Here was the place where the decision to surrender Singapore to the Japanese on 15 February 1942 was made. Now, filled with many historical gardens for you to walk down memory lane and appreciate what we have now- the peace and harmony. You do need stamina to walk through all the sites but definitely worthwhile as you soak yourself in the serenity of it all...
Its a fort on a hill, what not to like about greeneries?
Very nice park area on the hill near to historical police and fire stations and a short walk from Clarke quay. Very clean and tidy, well maintained area. Lots of steps of you like to keep fit!

A historic site of Malay kingdom, British fortification, and now a great park overlooking Clark Quay, Civic area, with many, great trees. Best visited one hour prior to sunset, circle around the top of the hill on foot, watch the city's night life come alive as the darkness falls.

admissionInfo: Free
body: Set up in 2003, the Ngee Ann Cultural Centre comprises the Ngee Ann Kongsi Heritage Hall and Collections Gallery. The former commemorates the entrepreneurial spirit of pioneers from the Ngee Ann Kongsi, a Teochew charitable welfare organisation founded in 1845. Its displays of archives and artefacts, such as account books from the 1920s, elaborate on the Kongsi’s history and its contributions to the development of Singapore.
description: The centre celebrates the entrepreneurial spirit of pioneers from the Ngee Ann Kongsi, a Teochew charitable welfare organisation founded in 1845.
name: Ngee Ann Cultural Centre

body: In the 19th century and early 20th century, Singapore played an integral role in the development of musical boxes in Southeast Asia. At the Singapore Musical Box Museum, visitors will get to travel back in time as they pursue more than 40 antique musical boxes exhibited in the museum and learn about the history of musical boxes and how it made its way to Singapore. A 40-minute guided tour, available in English, Mandarin or Japanese, is included in the admission ticket where in-house curators and research workers will provide detailed information on the museum and its exhibitions.
description: Find out how Singapore played a role in creating musical boxes in Southeast Asia in the 19th and 20th centuries.
name: Singapore Musical Box Museum

pricing.others: Adult S$12, Student & Senior Citizen S$6, Free admission  for children aged six and below

reviews.text:
An enriching experience for music lovers. Defintiely worth the visit. Thanks to our very knowledgeable and engaging guide Mr Tay, we learnt the history behind the display musical movements and boxes. We also get to hear so many beautiful music and close up views of how the mechanisms work.
Small musuem but rich learning.

There is an entrance fee, and the museum is overall  small. It's well worth it if you do the guided tour (in English - there are Japanese plaques for some pieces) as the tour guide will explain the history and mechanics of the pieces and play them for you. The tour is approximately 40 minutes and you may need to wait as they do one group at a time. I love music boxes so I thought it was a magical experience to see and hear the antique ones. You'll probably never get a chance to hear them otherwise!
A rare and special place to visit. Step into another world. The collector and guide is passionate and fascinating. The boxes delightful and awe-inspiring.
A small private museum. The guide was so full of enthusiasm and knowledge of all the music boxes. Throughly recommend a visit.

A little treasure in Singapore. The guided tour is compulsory due to the precious music boxes. But that is the only way to enjoy the museum. They give you history of music boxes and they play these grand masterpieces. The music "boxes"are the size of pianofortes and grandfather clocks and jukeboxes! Made beautifully and the music..! Thank you for sharing these treasures! You will want to hear these music boxes over and over again. If you want to take home a little souvenir, there are a lot of music boxes for sale at the shop.

body: More than just payment for postage, stamps shed light on the culture, history and milestones of a country. At the Singapore Philatelic Museum, which is housed in a century-old colonial building, visitors will find an enchanting collection of more than 12,000 stamps and objects related to the country’s postal system. With beginnings dating back to the 1830s, the collection here was acquired in Singapore and overseas. Look out for the world’s first stamp and the museum’s crown jewel - the only known complete set of 1854 Indian stamps, which were used in the Straits Settlements.
description: Here visitors can find Singapore’s only operating colonial postbox outside the museum as well as 12,000 stamps and objects related to the country’s postal system.
name: Singapore Philatelic Museum
notes: The Singapore Philatelic Museum is currently closed for revamp and is slated to open end-2020.

pricing.others: Adult: S$8, Child: S$6, Senior Citizen: S$6

reviews.text: A small museum brimming with interesting things. The exhibition on the Little Prince as well as the envelope exhibit were fascinating. $8 for foreigners but well worth it. Front desk workers are polite and informed. Thank you for a lovely visit.
I love collecting stamps and coming here is adding a new knowledge about stamps!

I feel like this is an underrated place in Singapore! Although small, this museum is really interesting and offers great insight into the world of letters and postcards! If you're a postcard lover, this is the place to be. Great selection of postcards and stamps as well. This is also a nice place to visit with children since some of the displays in the museum can be touched/interacted with. Be prepared to spend around an hour and a half in this place. :)

Visited the museum for the little prince exhibition. Singapore citizens and PR get in for free and everyone else pays only $8. You can easily spend an hour here and perhaps 2 hours if you read every single description. I enjoyed the unexpectedly high quality exhibitions and it’s probably one of the most overlooked museums in Singapore!
Fun for the kids to explore. Have interactive elements. Enjoy going there to check the exhibits.

body: The Singapore Civil Defence Force provides fire-fighting, rescue and emergency medical services for Singapore and is recognised as a professional body of well-trained officers and men ever-ready to respond to life threatening emergencies. At the Civil Defence Heritage Gallery, visitors will learn about the history of the Singapore Civil Defence Force, as well as the latest fire-fighting and rescue technology they have developed and used. The gallery also features customised interactive stations for a close-up experience of what fire fighters and rescuers experience in an operation. Visitors can opt for a guided tour through the gallery. The guided tour is available in English only.
description: Visit the country’s oldest fire station and learn about its firefighting and civil defence developments from the late 1800s to present day.
name: Civil Defence Heritage Gallery At The Central Fire Station

reviews.text: Due to covid situation, two administrative counter staffs are very lazy and close-off the site before closing time, even the local residents could not enter the site; online website wasn't update on the closing time (is now at 4:00pm) and the booking requirement before site-visit is not updated clearly on the website as well. Very disappointed and won't go again, the two administrative counter staffs wasting visitors' efforts to travel all the way there.

Very informative museum/heritage gallery. It shows the evolution of the technology used by the Singapore fire service through different era.
Free admission, definitely worth a visit and good to bring young ones here too... Saw a few of them having a big grin on their face when they climb on one of the old fire engines on display.
Small but nicely set up. Friendly staff too!

Visited the museum back in March. This former fire station houses the museum of the history of fire fighting in Singapore. There are some fantastic exhibits including actual fire engines and archival footage of past firemen. The exhibits on the 2nd floor cover more modern fire fighting techniques with outstanding videos and animatronics on not just fire fighting and rescue missions. This is an amazing and free museum, but I'd would've been happy to pay.

A great educational 2 hours spent here, learning about the fire department and their rescue missions. Best part of the gallery is the enigmatic tour guide, Mr Segar, who brought the exhibits to life. My 2 kids who were initially not interested to check this place out came out giving it a 2 thumbs up. Highly recommended free spot to check out!

admissionInfo:
Locals/PR
Adults: S$10
Child <7 years, seniors > 60: S$6

Foreigners
Adults: S$14
Child <7 years: S$10
body:
See the most beautiful tortoise in the World, the Radiated Starred Tortoise; the pampered behaviour of our ever attention seeking Aldabra; the most dangerous Alligator Snapping turtle with the strongest bite pressure as compared to many animals and more. Be amazed by the behaviour of the box turtle completely hiding itself in its shell when faced with danger and how snapping turtles lure their prey.

As a turtle museum, the humongous collection of turtle artefacts placed none beside us. The many different countries the artefacts were bought from, their history; the many different materials they are made from, tells a diverse story.

Come and have an unforgettable opportunity to experience an up close and personal interaction with Giant Tortoises and be assured of a turtly memorable experience.
description: World's largest collection of live turtles and tortoises, and artefacts from all over the world.
name: The Live Turtle and Tortoise Museum
notes: Stay Tuned to our facebook page and website for Public Holiday opening hours!

reviews.text: Educational but enterance fee too expensive.
Small area but worth to drop by

Pretty fascinating to see so many different species of tortoise and turtles. But not well supervised. Once you enter, people pretty much do anything they want to do. Some people were feeding where it says “no feeding”. Touch them and press them however they wanted. Feel bad for the turtles.

Entrance is only reasonable for Singapore citizens and PR. We had to pay “Foreigner fee” because we are EP/DP. The food items for feeding are separate charge. Of course the kids wants to feed the turtles endlessly!

This place is really fun for anyone who likes turtles and tortoises. It is fairly small, so it won't take you long to walk around. Feeding the animals is definitely the highlight - they have vegetables and pellets for purchase so you can feed various turtles and tortoises. Our young kids had a great time. There is also a bench swing that's nice and peaceful. Would definitely recommend this place!

Not such a big place but they are flexible with how we play with the animals not so stringent. Quite hard to get in so best to drive. No atm so either cash or paynow. Wld be best if cheaper but still an Afternoon well spent

address.buildingName: Tanjong Pagar Railway Station to Woodlands Train Checkpoint

admissionInfo: Free
body: Rich in history, the Rail Corridor is testimony to Singapore’s longstanding relationship with its neighbouring country, Malaysia. Trains used to shuttle cargo between both countries, via the Tanjong Pagar Railway Station and the Woodlands Train Checkpoint. Today, this 24-kilometre route—which connects vast stretches of greenery in Singapore—is also known as the green corridor and is frequently visited by sports enthusiasts like runners and hikers. Two distinct truss bridges found at Upper Bukit Timah Road near The Rail Mall (www.railmall.com.sg) are a popular backdrop for photographs amongst visitors. The mall has a number of dining and retail establishments, and makes a great stopover for lunch or afternoon tea break. Singapore’s Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA), which manages the Rail Corridor, has a detailed walking map on its website (www. thegreencorridor.org/tag/rail-corridormap) that visitors can consider.
description: This stretch of greenery documenting Singapore's relationship with Malaysia is frequented by runners and hikers.
name: Rail Corridor

admissionInfo: Free
body: Part of The Southern Ridges, Labrador Nature Reserve is just the place for nature lovers and history buffs. A former British military base, its beginnings date back to the 19th century. Visitors can examine World War II relics like a machine gun post and artillery pieces. As visitors take in the views of the sea and cliff-side vegetation, they can look out for 70 species of birds, such as the oriental magpie-robin and black-naped oriole. Home to the only coastal cliff in the country, the reserve has many picturesque spots for nature photographers to hone their skills. Besides self-guided nature walks, travellers can book a private heritage walking tour (max 20 pax per group).
description: This former British military base is home to the only coastal cliff in the country and has many picturesque spots, perfect for nature photographers.
name: Labrador Nature Reserve

reviews.text: Loved it with the family. It is a round about route and walking directly from labrador station is better. Good breeze and not too hot due the the amount of trees near the walk paths. Crazy clean waters that makes you feel like dipping.
A nice place for morning walk. Windy and cooling weather.

I have fond memories of the park that had remained mostly unchanged since 1983. Major difference is there is a road that leads now to the seashores and the park lights doesn't go off at midnight. Which was kind of a good then, to have a darkened place to watch the night skies.
A place that’s filled with many types of natural plants. Even monkeys, squirrels and monitor lizards is sighted in it. The water is so clear that we can see the bottom of the stream.

It's a beautiful place for jogging, track parallel to sea. Over looking Sentosa, Fort and reflections. On right is harbour side with big vessels seen. Good for those who like quite place, not so crowded. No eateries... Carry your own food

admissionInfo:
Singapore Flight
Adults: S$33
Child: S$21
Senior Citizens (Singaporeans and local residents only): S$24

Singapore Sling Flight
Adults: S$69
Child: S$31

Singapore Flyer Sky Dining
For two guests: S$351.92

Premium Champagne Flight
Adult: S$79
body:
Experience breathtaking, panoramic views on Asia’s largest observation wheel. Enveloped safely in a capsule 165m above ground level, you will be treated to a visual 360˚ feast of iconic and historical landmarks such as Singapore River, Raffles Place, Merlion Park, and Empress Place. Look towards the ocean and you’ll be greeted by the waves and waters that brought spices from ancient lands to Singapore – the cornerstone of our city’s modern prosperity. Catch glimpses of the neighbouring Indonesian Spice Islands and the Straits of Johor, Malaysia while watching the ships sail serenely by. On top of that, your Singapore Flyer flight also includes FLYER 360+, an interactive in-capsule experience that enhances your flight experience with its rich content on Singapore history, culture and iconic landmarks.

Indulge in a multi-sensory dining experience with the Singapore Flyer Sky Dining or toast to the good things in life with the Singapore Sling or Premium Champagne Flight.

Click here to purchase your flight tickets online now!
description: A moving experience at every turn
name: Singapore Flyer

reviews.text: The place is amazing especially the view. The ride will be about 30 minutes long so its not too bad. The view is amazing and you can see all the places from a height of 165m I think. This is definitely the one place you want to go to but if you have a phobia of heights you can go but if you don't its fine.

Go after sunset for the beautiful city lights.
You will get good view of the lake and the city's skyline but not good view of the marina bay building.
For someone who has already seen the city skyline from marina or garden by the bay its nothing new because its the same view from a slightly different angle.

WoooHooo..... The best flyer i ever experienced. It is a gigantic wheel which looks really colourful during nights. The whole city can be experienced here. Its works really slow so that we can have a good view around the city. We can book tickets online as well. One of the important Point of interest around Singapore

No trip to Singapore is complete without a visit to the Singapore Flyer. It is the best ride  I ever have  experienced. Singapore Flyer is a gigantic wheel which looks really colourful during at nightime. The whole city can be viewed and experienced here. The Singapore Flyer travels  really slow so that you can have a good view around the city and see all the local landmarks  around Marina Bay. We can book tickets online as well. One of the best tourist destinations  and points of interest around . worth 5 stars all the way for the experience
Special experience. Due to safe distancing, there were 3 pairs of us inside the the cabin. Booked the 7pm slot so I would be able to see the sky change colour. Had 1-for-1 Premium Champagne

body: Discover how Singapore survived the Japanese Occupation at the historic Former Ford Factory. Through three intertwining narratives on Japanese aggression, British defences and how civilians in Singapore were caught up in the larger forces of imperial struggle and war, the exhibition showcases fresh perspectives on the fall of Singapore. Visitors will have the unique experience of being able to walk into the boardroom where the surrender took place on 15 February 1942. Learn about acts of atrocity such as ‘Sook Ching’ where there was mass screening of Chinese men and those suspected of being anti-Japanese were mercilessly killed. Discover other harrowing experiences and the different ways people responded to severe challenges and suffering through the display of personal items from that time and the oral history interviews of eye witnesses to actual events. Join the walk in tours led by experienced volunteer guides to discover more stories behind the rich collections on display. There are 20 places available daily (except for public holidays). Tour schedules are subject to change, so to avoid disappointment, do check the website for details.
description: Learn about the struggles Singapore faced under the Japanese  Occupation and how the country survived World War II.
name: Former Ford Factory
notes: Closed on the first day of Chinese New Year

pricing.others: Admission is free for Singaporeans & Permanent Residents,  Foreigners S$3

reviews.text:
Extremely informative. I would recommend you take your child here. It gives them a good idea of the fight for freedom. The exhibitions here are historically accurate. I liked that they had a different and unique theme for different parts of the museum.
They made it interactive learning but it is currently closed due to COVID-19. They have also paid respects to soldiers from different cultures and ethnicities.
They have planted a war garden which shows all the plants they used during the war.
Overall, I really loved this place and would definitely recommend for you to visit.

Great place for anyone looking to learn about Singapore's place in WWII. It has a lot of information and even stuff like the setting for the British surrender of Singapore to the Japanese in 1942. Lots of info about what life was like for the locals. Also it isn't too graphic (which some war museums can be) so you can take the kids.

Amazing unknown and hidden museum of Singapore. Great overview of Singapore before and during the war. Events are described rather objectively and there is much to learn in every section. Great location in the old Ford Factory. Highly recommend !
Good place to learn about the period when Singapore was under Japanese rule. Lots of other things to do nearby (within a few bus stops) too!
Very informative place. Free of charge for singaporeans. Come here since you cannot travel anyway.

admissionInfo: Free admission
body:
[29 June 2020] All areas of Fort Siloso has reopen. Tours and programmes will not be available until further notice.

Fort Siloso was built in the late 19th century. During that time, Singapore had become an important trading port for the British, so it was imperative that the island was protected from sea invasion.

However, during World War II, Japanese troops invaded Singapore by land from north Malaya. This led the British to turn Fort Siloso's guns towards the mainland instead to help support the ground forces defending Singapore from the invasion.

Today, more than 70 years after the war, Fort Siloso stands as a beloved historical site. The only preserved coastal fort in Singapore, it is home to a wealth of WWII memorabilia, including coastal guns and the remains of fortified military structures and tunnels.

Begin your exploration from the Fort Siloso Skywalk, a treetop trail set 11 storeys above ground. You may also choose to explore the fort by the Heritage Trail or the Gun Trail, both of which are sure to take you on an unforgettable journey back in time.

Relive some of the momentous events in Singapore's history with the Surrender Chambers immersive show. Be guided by light, sound and video effects starting from the Japanese invasion, all the way to the Japanese's eventual surrender at the end of WWII.

Let yourself be transported back in time through the stories of people who lived during the Japanese Occupation, and experience the Allied forces' counterattack and the end of the war through six interactive zones. Before you leave, share a message of peace on the wall of poppies.
description: Fort Siloso was built in the late 19th century. During that time, Singapore had become an important trading port for the British, so it was imperative that the island was protected from sea invasion.
name: Fort Siloso

reviews.text: Free entry. Beautiful hidden view. Great introduction to Singapore history. Didn’t dare to take a picture of the soldier life because the rooms and soldiers looks creepy 😬
An educational historical place for World War II
Well maintained World War 2 conditions to let visitors feel and experience how it impacted Singapore and her citizens. Brings history back to life.

This place is more than meets the eye, can enter via the Fort Siloso Skywalk to have a breathtaking view of the beach and the surrounding. Plenty to view and understanding the history of Singapore. Strong air con in the building galleries, recommend bring umbrella if you go in mid afternoon.
Ended up here by accident. Very well preserved fort with interactive education and trails. Highly recommended

admissionInfo:
$300 for 2 person 
$500 for 4 person
body:
The museum is a haven for treasures of this remarkable culture, and a tour of the Intan gives visitors a chance to walk back in time and marvel at the spirit of the Peranakan people. On arrival at the museum, the first thing that strikes you is how unassuming the exteriors of the house are. It is not until you walk inside that you get to marvel at the astounding collection of antiques that attempts to combine the charm of the past within the contemporary setting. The open layout and the mirrors create the aura of a spacious indoors, and within it, the sheer diversity of collectables from years gone by. From rows of beaded traditional slippers with intricate designs to vibrantly coloured costumes, jewellery pieces and an array of trinkets, there is no shortage of traditional aspects to learn about in this culture. It is fascinating to note that, unlike your typical museum where information cards abound, The Intan has no cards at all. Ask Alvin Yapp, the museum’s owner, anything about the different collections and he will gladly indulge you. A tour of this museum is incomplete without enjoying tea  the Peranakan way. Needless to say, this is a favorite for many visitors as it is an opportune moment to sample traditional snacks  dotingly prepared by one of Yapp's aunts. Best of all, the refreshments are served in charming crockery for a holistic Peranakan experience. Depending on the time of your visit, you may listen in to Yapp and a few of his family members belt out a local song or two. The Intan is open by appointment only, so bookings must be made in advance to ensure slots are available. Custom made packages are also available for private events as long as they are related to the Peranakan culture. Visitors should note that visits are strictly by appointment only.


Your experience at The Intan is approximately 1 hour and it includes:

- Tea & home-made Peranakan refreshments (available if COVID 19 regulations allow)

- A brief understanding of the history and culture of the Peranakans

- Learning about the traditional and lavish Peranakan wedding ceremony

- Appreciating the colorful and intricate beadwork & embroidery handmade by the Nyonya ladies Peranakan women
description: The Intan is a private home that houses one of Singapore’s most impressive collections of Peranakan artifacts. Owner Alvin Yapp has spent 30-plus years collecting 1,500 objects from Peranakan culture, most notably beaded slippers and enamel tiffin carriers hand-painted in delicate floral patterns
name: The Intan PRIVATE Tea Visit

body:
Do you know what your poo is telling you? What colour should it be? What is it made of? Find out at Science Centre Singapore’s latest exhibition – Know Your Poo. Dedicated to uncovering the science behind this essential bodily function, the exhibition seeks to de-stigmatise conversations around poo and provide an understanding about gut health and the importance of sanitation.

Launched in conjunction with World Toilet Day on 19 November 2020, the permanent exhibition is the Centre’s latest interactive venture pointing the spotlight on the global sanitation crisis. The lack of adequate sanitation access to more than half of the global population and the staggering number of deaths caused by water and sanitation-related diarrheal diseases highlight the detrimental impact of poor sanitation, especially among developing countries. Just as water is key to survival, toilets are critical to help prevent spread of diseases. That is why the United Nations General Assembly introduced Sustainable Development Goal 6, which promises sanitation for all by 2030 by calling for universal access to adequate and equitable sanitation and an end to open defecation.

At this exhibition, guests may explore the five themed zones featuring over 15 interactive exhibits –

ZONE 1: TO FLUSH OR NOT TO FLUSH

Have you ever flushed your pet fish down the toilet bowl? Or a cockroach? You may not be the only one! However, these are things that should not go down the loo. Challenge yourself to identify things that you should or should not flush down the toilet bowl.

ZONE 2: BIOLOGY OF WASTES

Go back to basics with a lesson on digestion and waste production. From bowel transit time to pathogen transmissions, here is everything you need to know about what goes on inside your digestive system. Plus, journey through the Secret Chamber of Farts to learn fun facts on bodily gas! Not to be missed!

ZONE 3: WHERE DO WASTES GO?

Now that you’ve made an offering to the porcelain throne, what happens next? Zone 3 illustrates the “offloading” process and how wastes are collected around different parts of the world. Get the dirt on the engineering behind our toilet bowls, then sober up with a showcase on the global sanitation crisis and the need for improved sanitation in less-developed countries.

ZONE 4: SINGAPORE WASTE TREATMENT STORY

Society has come a long way from open defecation to the modern flush toilets installed in almost every home. Explore how toilets and sanitation have evolved over the course of Singapore’s history by taking a peek into cubicles showcasing past and present conditions.

ZONE 5: KEEP YOUR TOILETS CLEAN

Challenge yourself to clean the toilet in the fastest time and be crowned as the King of Toilet. Find out the location of the cleanest hawker centres and coffee shops toilets across Singapore as featured in the Toilet Cleanliness Index.

reviews.text: A great place for science enthusiasts! The shows are really great. The one I saw was on automation and robotics, I really loved it! If you are going on a trip to Singapore, please pay a visit to this amazing place.

Great for educational trips. Very Clean and exciting attractions! A replica of the famous Tesla Coil is showcased there. There is also an area for the kids (KidStop) if I recall. There is also monthly special themes like Insects and Dinosaur to Circus and Magic.

We went old school style, visiting the science centre! Not at all what we had 20 years ago but so glad it's still around and displaying so many science projects and displays of cool science tricks. My 6yo and 3yo definitely loved it. Omni theatre was breathtaking! So lucky it was a free entrance for Singaporeans during off peak period. Just pay for omnitheatre or the kidstop or other specialised exhibitions.

Great place to visit. So much to do and the kids had an amazing time. The 3 hour sessions due to Covid-19 are not enough to do everything so we will definitely be back. The mirror maze was a favourite with our 1yo, and our 7yo loved seeing the Tesla coil even though it wasn't running.

A cool place to learn science. It is convenient for people to visit this place as it is only a 10 minutes walk from the station. There are many topics of science being covered in this centre and has many school outreach programmes to allow students to grasp complicated science concepts.

body: Before Tiong Bahru, there was Haji Lane ? Singapore's original hipster neighbourhood that's peppered with charming boutiques, watering holes, cafés, and restaurants.
description: A leisurely 10-minute walk away from Bugis MRT is an ethnic enclave turned shopping haven. Lined with an eclectic mix of generations-old heritage stores, independent boutiques and crafts shops, Kampong Glam?s shophouses are a welcome change from air-conditioned shopping centres. Much of its charm as the former home of the local Sultan (King) has been retained, yet new tenants inject fresh allure into one of Singapore?s most iconic heritage neighbourhoods. Wander through back alleys and along five-foot ways offering trinkets that you won?t usually find in any malls. Start from the shops around the biggest landmark, Sultan Mosque, and work your way into the narrow alleyways that are full of curious finds.
name: Kampong Glam Singapore Visitor Centre

reviews.text: Strategic location.  Nice building deco, reminds me of Malacca and Penang.
Information center about Singapore. Become one with capsule Cube hotels. But there are often no officers

description: Enjoy panoramic views with Singapore Cable Car – the perfect gateway into Sentosa!
name: Singapore Cable Car
notes: Last boarding time: 21:30 hrs

reviews.text: no air con... but now... no much other choice...

Absolutely loved it! Its quite an experience to see the west side of this country from top & in the air. It was also a time to rest our feet for a while from the day-long walking. During the night the lights of the ships and the hotels create a unique ambiance nice! Highly recommend

I went to Sentosa Island by the Singapore cable car. This was a wonderful experience. You can see the whole Sentosa Island from the Top, especially Universal Studios (one of the attractions of Sentosa Island). I just love the ride. It is of around 5-7 minutes ride but it's amazing. I would highly recommend the visit once at least. Whenever you get a chance to visit Singapore you must visit there.

There is an amazing offer, at about $40-/ you can buy the 1 year membership with full unlimited access to the cable car for 1 whole year. The view from the cable car is nothing less than stunning. Also for local Singaporeans they can purchase the Sentosa cable car line for only $3. All the reason more for you to go there before the price Jack up again to pay for the expensive yet not worth Singapore ministers.
Bring your family, girlfriends, scandal, mistress or gay parents while it's still not tourists infested.
The best way to get to Sentosa Island

source: MOUNT FABER LEISURE GROUP PTE. LTD.

body:
Housed amid the greenery of Orto Leisure Park, away from the hustle and bustle of town, Katapult features over 8000 square feet of custom-made, interconnected trampolines.

It doesn’t matter if you’re under 5 or an extreme sports junkie; we offer everything from a kids’ zone and dodgeball courts to professional Olympic trampolines, wall runs and world-class airbags. In other words, it can be as easy or challenging as you want – but it will always be gravity-defying fun!
description: Indoor Trampoline Park
name: Katapult Trampoline Park

admissionInfo: Free admission. Simply identify and register yourself at the security post before entering the club premise.
body:
Located at the tip of our Club's breakwater is Raffles Marina's own lighthouse. Built in 1994 and overlooking the Tuas Second Link - Singapore's second causeway to Malaysia, this 12 metres high icon flashes every 10 seconds with a beam that reaches 15 metres. The lighthouse is maintained by the Club and is the only lighthouse not owned and operated by the Maritime Port Authority of Singapore.

The beacon is also a popular spot for cycling communities, leisure photography groups and bloggers. Some of these photographs have been featured on sites such as Pinterest, Flickr and on Instagram via this hashtag, #rafflesmarinalighthouse.

The lighthouse, together with the marina, has been featured on wedding and lifestyle websites and blogs, Raffles Marina has been described as one of the most ideal and unique venues among couples for wedding photography and nautical themed weddings.

During the evenings, soak in the expanse of the beautiful sunset right at the sea as you take a stroll down the pier to the lighthouse. No wonder this icon is known to many as one of the most picturesque in Singapore!

Visit Raffles Marina Lighthouse, opens daily from 7am to 12am.
description: Located at the tip of our Club's breakwater is Raffles Marina's own lighthouse. Built in 1994 and overlooking the Tuas Second Link - Singapore's second causeway to Malaysia, this 12 metres high icon flashes every 10 seconds with a beam that reaches 15 metres. The lighthouse is maintained by the Club and is the only lighthouse not owned and operated by the Maritime Port Authority of Singapore.
name: Raffles Marina Lighthouse

admissionInfo: Free
body: Bukit Timah Nature Reserve is the second ASEAN Heritage Park here, after Sungei Buloh Wetland Reserve, giving it recognition for its regional importance and conservational value. As one of the largest patches of primary forest in Singapore, it is home to a high percentage of Singapore’s native fauna and flora, including thorny rattans, the Singapore freshwater crab and Sunda pangolin. The reserve is also where visitors can climb Singapore’s tallest hill—which stands at 163 metres—and commemorate reaching its peak with a photograph by the iconic summit stone. Also not to be missed is the spectacular quarry views from the lookout point at the far end of the trail.
description: At this ASEAN Heritage Park, visitors can climb up Singapore’s tallest hill of 163m and snap a commemorative photo by the summit stone. Enjoy picturesque views from the lookout point at the far end of the trail.
name: Bukit Timah Nature Reserve

reviews.text: If you enjoy a nature appreciation walk, try the Bukit Timah walking trail. Bask in the beautiful greenery, cool air, chirping birds, carefree butterflies and steep steps. Be prepared for a little challenge if you are generally less active.

The main hike to the summit is very short less than 30min. Good to explore other paths such as the diary farm loop, jungle fall path, south view path. Generally not so big nature reserve and these paths can completed in an hr more  at a fast pace. Though the diary farm National Park is quite a long walk if u want to do it too and see quarry and may take much longer. At the start you can take the south view path if the incline is too steep on the main path.

Good place for a leisurely walk , jog or hike. A cross country running trail during our younger days and now an adventure hike for middle agers hahaha. We also come across some soldiers ok their topo or navigation exercises, reminiscing my army days of trunching through the same forested areas and crossing insane swamps to get to that checkpoint, one of them is called hell.

The place has been nicely done up!  The trails are reinforced and clearly marked.  Had a lovely morning walking up to the summit via the catchment trail. Great day too!  Cool morning after the previous wet weather. Saw some interesting plants and trees too.

Bukit Timah hill is the highest point in Singapore. Pristine, green and quite scenic. Path to hill is steep, but it is very short and easily doable. Also there are various other trails that one can do. Great for everyday walking routines and running too.

body:
Get set for a hands-on journey of discovery and sharpen your detective skills. At Sentosa Nature Discovery, nature and fun go hand-in-hand.

The exploration starts with a fascinating gallery of interactive exhibits at the Gallery to brush up your Science Process Skills: Observe, Classify, Compare and Infer. Equipped with these skills, step out into the jungle and explore a wilderness teeming with birds, insects, other wildlife and plants in all manner of different habitats.
description: Embark on a hands-on journey of discovery and sharpen your detective skills. At Sentosa Nature Discovery, nature and fun go hand-in-hand.
name: Sentosa Nature Discovery

pricing.others: Free. For Guided Tours contact us at 1800- SENTOSA (736 8672) or email to nature@sentosa.com.sg

reviews.text:
Great use for an old monorail station. We used this trail to join up to Imbiah trail.
Not crowded and it costs nothing!
This part is flat and good for kids and elderly folk, there are no stairs to navigate. Needs a little upkeep to make it sparkle again.

i visited today, nothing much that u can see due to pandemic. the nature was nkt well taken care of.. i can see cicada, lots of spiders and lots of trees. Nothing more, i expected to see more than these.. eg reptiles. but nowhere to be seen.. still, i had a great walk in the nature.

This I must say is a hidden gem. Did not know sentosa even had such a place until chances upon it by accident. To find this place itself is not easy. It is free btw.

Basically this nature discovery is a exhibition area and a broad walk walk through the nature reserves in sentosa which was once the old monorail track.

The main center itself is very informative. Telling you about the nature in sentosa (natural reefs, primary and secondary forest etc). There is also a downstairs section where it talks about the type of rocks found in sentosa. This place is a real gem.

The trail itself is good too. It is a nature walk to the imbiah trail where one can get some fresh air. Think of it like walking through bukit timah! Sentosa is not just about the beach and the sun!
It was a good walk. And the place can be better maintained
Really nice trial, also for small kids. A lot to discover.

admissionInfo: Free
body: Known as a green lung in the centre of Singapore, the Central Catchment Nature Reserve is the island’s largest reserve with more than 2,000 hectares of forest cover, supporting an extensive ecosystem of biodiversity. A popular attraction within the reserve is the Jelutong Tower, a seven-deck observation tower with unobstructed views of the forest. Visitors will also be near the Nee Soon Swamp Forest, a rare primary freshwater swamp forest. The nature reserve is also home to MacRitchie Reservoir Park, a good starting point for the 20-kilometre network of boardwalks and trails of varying difficulties and distances (from one and a half kilometres to six kilometres and beyond) that takes visitors through the forest and around the reservoir. It is worth trekking to the TreeTop Walk (Opening hours: Tue–Fr i 9am–5pm; Sat–Sun & Public Holidays 8.30am–5pm), a 250-metre-long suspension bridge running between the two highest points in MacRitchie where visitors can enjoy expansive views of the forest canopy. Visitors are advised to hike towards the bridge by 4.45pm from the Ranger Station as the gate closes at 5pm. Water sports enthusiasts can choose to rent canoes and kayaks, and observe the beauty of nature from the glistening reservoir waters. The park has an amenities centre with lockers, showering facilities, drinking water points and food kiosks.
description: MacRitchie Reservoir Park is a good starting point for the 20km network of boardwalks and trails of varying difficulties and distances that take visitors through the forest around the reservoir.
name: Central Catchment Nature Reserve and MacRitchie Reservoir Park
notes: MacRitchie Reservoir Park: Mon–Sun 24 hours

reviews.text:
Serene. Refreshing. Challenging.
Good place for a short trail run - end to end route is a little over 10km. Consider wearing good trail shoes with cushioning as the route is slightly pebbly. You will run into monkeys, birds, skinks, monitor lizards and jungle fowls.
So much nature, peaceful and great place for  walking,run.

The Central Catchment Nature Reserve is a large forest reserve in the centre of Singapore. There are walking trails of various difficulty levels that cut across the reserve. You can enter and exit from Bukit Timah, Rifle Range Road, MacRitchie Reservoir and Thomson.
Tiring but enjoy the scenery, wildlife and trekking.
xibeh natureeeee

address.buildingName: (Bukit Merah, Henderson Road and Mount Faber Park)

admissionInfo: Free
body: Spread over ten kilometres of green and open spaces, a hike through The Southern Ridges takes visitors to five local parks, namely Mount Faber Park, Telok Blangah Hill Park, HortPark, Kent Ridge Park and the Labrador Nature Reserve, which are linked by park connectors. As part of the journey, travellers cross bridges through the Adinandra Belukar, a distinct secondary forest, and can observe a variety of bird species. Henderson Waves—a picturesque bridge with wave-like arcs— is another highlight of the walk. Set 36 metres above ground level, Singapore’s highest pedestrian bridge is a marvel even at nightfall—it is illuminated with LED lighting from 7pm to 7am nightly. From many of the bridges and walkways, trekkers can enjoy panoramic views of lush greenery, as well as the sights and sounds of wildlife such as cicadas, straw-headed bulbuls, kingfishers and even migratory birds of prey. Go to the NParks website (www.nparks.gov.sg) for self-guided walking tours. For the suggested routes, the difficulty level is moderate to challenging, and the walking time is three to five hours.
description: A trek along The Southern Ridges brings visitors to five other parks - Mount Faber Park, Telok Blangah Hill Park, HortPark, Kent Ridge Park and the Labrador Nature Reserve.
name: The Southern Ridges

reviews.text: Lovely place for slow walk and exercise.  Not too strenuously for the unfit. Best part, it is partly shaded and it is not walking on mud ground. So even after rain, you won't get muddy shoes

It's a good place to do your brisk walk. Scenery and the amazing bridge walk makes you forget that you have walked the distance. It's a good exercise for beginners who wishes they don't get intimidated by the activity.

Great canopy walk, it is a little crowded on the weekend so I'd suggest going off peak hours. The whole path is slightly downhill if you're walking from Faber, which is great but that slight incline is pretty tough if you're going the other way (with a buggy in the heat of the day).
Always like walking here since it is a relatively peaceful and cooling walk. For those who have a fear of height, dont worry! The metal structures are very sturdy!

Walked from Kent Ridge to Harbour Front. Trail was relatively easy walk. Very limited sections of steepness. Only downside was the direction/trail could be better marked when transitioning from one section to the next. Just went with the general direction and was OK.

body: Enter a world of perpetual spring! Replicating the cool and dry Mediterranean climate, Flower Dome showcases exotic plants from five continents which are displayed in nine different Gardens. Wander amongst thousand-year-old olive trees and unusual Baobabs as you take in sights of the Flower Field Display.
description: Step into the Flower Dome and stand in awe of nature. Spectacular and innovative, it is the largest glass greenhouse in the world as listed in the 2015 Guinness World Records! Be amazed by changing display of flowers and plants from the Mediterranean and semi-arid regions.
name: Flower Dome, Gardens by the Bay
notes: Closed once a month for maintenance. Please check website for details.

reviews.text:
Wonderful design.
Step into the Flower Dome and stand in awe of nature. Spectacular and innovative, it is the largest glass greenhouse in the world as listed in the 2015 Guinness World Records! Be amazed by changing display of flowers and plants from the Mediterranean and semi-arid regions.
Tip's
Flower Dome and cloud forest both of them is really wonderful. Get club promo ticket.
It take around 5 hours for visit

Another must visit attraction at the Gardens by the Bay. The sheer amount of flowering plants is overwhelming and impressive. I enjoyed the Dahlias and the variety of cute succulents. Pretty things worthy of the camera lenses.
Touristy but worth checking out once

Loved my adventure in the Flower Dome! Lots of interesting flora from around the globe, with I retesting sculptures and structures to enhance the beauty of nature. Definitely will be going back again and again.
Raining so less crowd. Good timing to take photos. Of course, with mask on

body: Built around a reservoir on top of a hill, the Pearl’s Hill City Park is the perfect spot for a respite. Catch Pearl’s Hill estate residents jogging amidst the serenity or enjoy a view of the pond, which comes alive with vivid colours when the lotus plants are in full bloom.
description: Hidden oasis of tranquility and peace
name: Pearl’s Hill City Park

reviews.text: Natural
A small but nice park to walk and exercise. One of the parks nearest to the city with an old history.

Feel good ~nice to take photo
No big
The Bodhi tree in the park is one of the oldest in Singapore.
Small park to getaway from the hustle and bustle of Chinatown.

body: These concave bowls of mist will naturally draw children to play as if amongst clouds.
companyDisplayName: JEWEL CHANGI AIRPORT TRUSTEE PTE. LTD.
description: Let your toddler slip in among puffs of cloud and hide away in gentle bowls of mist. Kids will love the chance to play in this dreamy setting and let their imagination take flight.
name: Jewel Changi Airport Canopy Park Foggy Bowl

reviews.text:
JEWEL CANOPY PARK IS AMAZING! Although quite tiring, the Manulife Sky Net and the Bouncing Net is really fun and safe. The ciew is also breathtaking even though its indoors.

For those who prefer relaxing activities, it is also nice to just take a stroll around the well designed park, decorated with all kinds of flora and fauna.

Definitely recommend!!

Great place to spend an hour here. Great with kids but only they are 110cm tall. Staff strictly adhere to the height requirement for kids for their safety. Entry ticket to the park is valid for the entire day. You may re-enter the park within the same day but not for the ticketed attractions which are limited to single entry.
Quite crowded, maybe due to the school holidays, so its hard to maintain a safe distance. The queue moves quickly though
Fun but a bit pricey for the bouncing with the 1 hour limit time

My mom and sister went to the Canopy park yesterday.

While the attractions were big fun, they encountered issues with unfriendly and doubtful staffs at the Sky Net, resulted in really unpleasant experiences.

My mom and sister did not enter Sky Net until 3:30pm, but the staffs said they have already been to the attraction at 3pm. While there is apparently system error where the blame should be on the dev team, the staffs pointed the arrow at my parent. With complete false confidence, they said their system will not have any mistake, and accused my mom for lying, saying she definitely has been there at 3pm. The staff also repeatedly asked my 8 years old sister if she has been to the attraction, giving absolutely 0 respect and trust in my mom's words. My mom is a kind woman and my sister is still small so they really couldn't talk back, had a really tough time handling the rain of accusations from the attraction staffs.

What is there to scam for? An entry? System failure is to blame the consumer? Is that the way Canopy Park and holder group operate? Where are the core values?

I urge you to not go to Sky Net if you want to avoid awful experience. Everywhere was fine but just don't go to Sky Net.

source: JEWEL CHANGI AIRPORT TRUSTEE PTE. LTD.

address.buildingName: Saint John’s Island, Kusu Island and Sisters’ Island

body: Singapore’s offshore Southern Islands are made up of a total of eight islands. Full of undisturbed natural landscapes, three of these islands–Saint John’s Island, Kusu Island and Sisters’ Islands— are great for camping, picnicking, snorkelling and sightseeing. They are easily accessible by ferry from Marina South Pier; round trip tickets are at S$18 for adults and S$12 for children. Saint John’s Island (www.nparks.gov.sg/ gardens-parks-and-nature/parks-and-nature- reserves/sisters-islands-marinepark/ st-johns-island-trail) was once a quarantine centre for infectious diseases and later a drug rehabilitation centre. It has since undergone transformation and is now known for many friendly felines, swimming lagoons, beaches, picnic grounds and trekking routes. Legend has it that Kusu Island was a result of a giant tortoise turning itself into an island in order to save two shipwrecked sailors who then returned to the island to give thanks. In a nod to its origins story, the island is also home to a famous tortoise sanctuary, which houses them in hundreds. Sisters’ Islands are two islands separated by a narrow channel and is said to be named after varied versions of a folktale where two sisters drown at sea. The Sisters’ Islands Marine Park (www.nparks.gov.sg/gardensparks- and-nature/parks-and-naturereserves/ sisters-islands-marine-park) located on the island is home to plenty of Singapore’s native marine biodiversity and is definitely worth a visit.
description: Full of quiet beauty, the Southern Islands are perfect for a quick getaway into unfiltered natural landscapes.
name: Southern Islands

body: Step into a world of fascinating creatures bearing reminisce of the pre-historic era at the Live Turtle & Tortoise Museum. Turtles range in size—from miniature to enormous—and visitors can get upclose and personal with them alongside tortoises in a staged area. Be fascinated by an array of turtle and tortoise species—the museum houses the Sulcata Tortoise, Golden Temple Turtle, Golden Terrapin, Six Legged Tortoise, Indian Star Tortoise, Soft Shell Turtle and more. Many of the turtles and tortoises from the museum are rescued and rehabilitated into healthy environments for them to thrive and flourish in. Visitors to the museum can look forward to live turtle races on the weekends and race remote-controlled turtles on any operating day. Turtle feeding sessions also happen sporadically throughout the day. After visiting, visitors will be able to take home turtle-themed memorabilia from the gift shop. Trade discount will be 5% off ticket prices.
description: Birthed from a passion for turtle and tortoises, the museum features a fascinating diversity of the reptile species.
name: Live Turtle & Tortoise Museum

pricing.others: Adult S$14, Child aged three to six & Senior Citizen aged 62 and above S$10; Singapore Citizens enjoy S$4 off each ticket

reviews.text: Educational but enterance fee too expensive.
Small area but worth to drop by

Pretty fascinating to see so many different species of tortoise and turtles. But not well supervised. Once you enter, people pretty much do anything they want to do. Some people were feeding where it says “no feeding”. Touch them and press them however they wanted. Feel bad for the turtles.

Entrance is only reasonable for Singapore citizens and PR. We had to pay “Foreigner fee” because we are EP/DP. The food items for feeding are separate charge. Of course the kids wants to feed the turtles endlessly!

This place is really fun for anyone who likes turtles and tortoises. It is fairly small, so it won't take you long to walk around. Feeding the animals is definitely the highlight - they have vegetables and pellets for purchase so you can feed various turtles and tortoises. Our young kids had a great time. There is also a bench swing that's nice and peaceful. Would definitely recommend this place!

Not such a big place but they are flexible with how we play with the animals not so stringent. Quite hard to get in so best to drive. No atm so either cash or paynow. Wld be best if cheaper but still an Afternoon well spent

body: Located at the topmost level of Jewel, the Canopy Park is a 14,000 sqm recreational park featuring world-class play attractions for all ages. Visit the Discovery Slides, a sculptural playscape with four slides and a viewing deck, or the Foggy Bowls which feature gentle bowls of mist. Nature-lovers can enjoy creative displays of seasonal flowers at the Petal Garden and stylized plants in the form of animals at the Topiary Walk.
companyDisplayName: JEWEL CHANGI AIRPORT TRUSTEE PTE. LTD.
description: Canopy Park, located at the topmost level (L5) of Jewel, welcomes the young and young at heart with an array of exciting play attractions.
name: Jewel Changi Airport Canopy Park

reviews.text:
JEWEL CANOPY PARK IS AMAZING! Although quite tiring, the Manulife Sky Net and the Bouncing Net is really fun and safe. The ciew is also breathtaking even though its indoors.

For those who prefer relaxing activities, it is also nice to just take a stroll around the well designed park, decorated with all kinds of flora and fauna.

Definitely recommend!!

Great place to spend an hour here. Great with kids but only they are 110cm tall. Staff strictly adhere to the height requirement for kids for their safety. Entry ticket to the park is valid for the entire day. You may re-enter the park within the same day but not for the ticketed attractions which are limited to single entry.
Quite crowded, maybe due to the school holidays, so its hard to maintain a safe distance. The queue moves quickly though
Fun but a bit pricey for the bouncing with the 1 hour limit time

My mom and sister went to the Canopy park yesterday.

While the attractions were big fun, they encountered issues with unfriendly and doubtful staffs at the Sky Net, resulted in really unpleasant experiences.

My mom and sister did not enter Sky Net until 3:30pm, but the staffs said they have already been to the attraction at 3pm. While there is apparently system error where the blame should be on the dev team, the staffs pointed the arrow at my parent. With complete false confidence, they said their system will not have any mistake, and accused my mom for lying, saying she definitely has been there at 3pm. The staff also repeatedly asked my 8 years old sister if she has been to the attraction, giving absolutely 0 respect and trust in my mom's words. My mom is a kind woman and my sister is still small so they really couldn't talk back, had a really tough time handling the rain of accusations from the attraction staffs.

What is there to scam for? An entry? System failure is to blame the consumer? Is that the way Canopy Park and holder group operate? Where are the core values?

I urge you to not go to Sky Net if you want to avoid awful experience. Everywhere was fine but just don't go to Sky Net.

source: JEWEL CHANGI AIRPORT TRUSTEE PTE. LTD.

address.buildingName: Henderson Road; Southern Ridges; Bukit Merah

admissionInfo: Free
body: Constructed at 36-metres above ground, Henderson Waves is Singapore’s highest pedestrian bridge. Its unique wave-like architecture—comprising a series of undulating curved ribs—makes the 274-metre-long bridge a popular destination for wedding shoots. Here, couples can mark their trip to Singapore with a series of fun, romantic photos. Come nightfall, the bridge is transformed with warm LED lights that highlight its curvy design. It is part of The Southern Ridges walk, a ten-kilometre-long trail that links Mount Faber Park, Telok Blangah Hill Park, Kent Ridge Park, Labrador Nature Reserve and HortPark. The bridge is not accessible by wheelchair.
description: The highest pedestrian bridge in the country has unique wave-like architecture, making it a popular destination for wedding shoots.
name: Henderson Waves

reviews.text: Beautiful bridge, excellent for chilling if you arrived at night, just sit down at the side and enjoy the view. The breeze on top is also refreshing, good for cooling down after a bike ride. Unfortunately, the designated seats at the side of the bridge were closed due to Corona measures.

As a piece of architecture it is great not only huge but also unique. Must place to go for those who admires nature and loves to have long walk in serene enviornment. Elderly age group might find it difficult to reach while using stairs but there are many benches to sit and relax too. Best time to visit is in evening or when temp is not too hot or humid.

A nice place to see the southern shores of Singapore and catch the sunset. Surrounded by nature and also connected to hort Park and mount faber. Good place to hike and exercise as well.

Better to be in running/walking shoes as there is loads of walking and the path way leading to the bridge is pretty steep.

Wonderful Walk, Vast Views, Inexpensive Activity.
It was very hot mid day, but a peaceful nature walk right in the city. A two to three hours morning hike is the most comfortable.
Good sneakers is a must. Great views and a good workout !

Good fun for a walk.  No shade so rather hot.  Walked over Henderson wave bridge into mount Faber park which was cool.  Great walks and good views.  Good sign posts.  Bridge may be a little off putting if you’re worried about heights!

admissionInfo: Free Admission
body:
[26 MAR 2020] In view of COVID-19 Safe-Distancing Measures, Magical Shores is temporarily suspended.

When dusk descends, a wild, mystical magic stirs within Siloso Beach. A magic that brings the shores alive with a magnificent medley of light and sounds. A magic that transforms the environment with every move you make. A magic that truly lets you see nature in a whole new light. Come and awaken your sense of wonder. Magical Shores is a multi-sensory experience that transforms Siloso beach into an interactive light and sound spectacle. Whirl around and see striking visual effects change on sand instantly, or catch nature’s enchanting song and dance that illuminates the island’s greenery after dark. Get your cameras ready, these are moments you'd want to keep forever. #magicalshores
description: Magical Shores
name: Magical Shores
notes: [26 MAR 2020] In view of COVID-19 Safe-Distancing Measures, Magical Shores is temporarily suspended

reviews.text: Sand is clean. All safty measures followed.
Nice and relaxing,but during this days of pandemic,its quite boring and few people hanging around
Nice peaceful scenic place. However quite in accessible and not suitable if the person is not very mobile independently. Insect repellent is good to have.

A beautiful beach, easy to reach on foot or via the cable cars. The sea is warm and inviting and you can admire the huge amounts of boats out in the bay. Some might find the boats an eyesore, but its a reminder of Singapore's global position and (in my books) adds to the wonder.
What a shame what was made out of this beach with this new restrictions, isn't it too much to treat such a peace of liberty and relaxation? Not worth anymore to go!

body: A recent addition to Singapore’s list of national gardens, Jurong Lake Gardens can be found in the heartlands of Jurong and comprises the Lakeside Garden, Chinese Garden, Japanese Gardens, and Garden Promenade. Spaces have been landscaped and designed for families and communities to come together. The 90-hectre garden also consist of play pools that mimic tidal patterns and coastal water movements, grasslands, a natural garden playground for children, a freshwater swamp, naturalised waterways and People’s Association PAssion WaVe facility that offers many water sports activities. The northern strip of Lakeside Garden as well as Chinese and Japanese Gardens are closed for redevelopment from 1 June 2019 and will be completed from 2021 onwards.
description: Be enamoured by lush bonsai collections, moon gates and tiered pagodas in the greenery of Jurong Lake Gardens.
name: Jurong Lake Gardens
notes: Timing varies for different parts of Jurong Lake Gardens

reviews.text: The view during the night is splendid. It is enchanted with multiple city lights which is reflected in it's water. I really enjoyed strolling near the water. It is a good place to visit with your family and friends. You can also leave your kids at the playground as you stroll around. Overall, I recommend this place for a pleasant stroll or a jog.

One of the most beautiful and largest garden/park in Singapore! It recently got renovated to include lot more attractions. Perfect for family gathering. Took about 4 hours to walk (non stop) the entire place, it stretches from Lakeside to Chinese Garden. Both the day and night view is really good. Definitely a good place for jogging, breezy and fresh air!

Awesome place tucked away in the western heartlands of Singapore. Its got a bit for everyone.. fun for kids and families, fauna for bird and animal lovers, flora for those who love colors around in the form of greens and flowers, landscape and birding photographers, fitness enthusiasts, foodies.. all have it here. Great place and love to be living in close vicinity.

Jurong Lake Gardens has come a along way. What started off as an off-beat park connector has now transformed into a lively, big, spacious, well-lit public park. The park is definitely beautiful at night, owing to the yellow lights casted on the trees and tracks. The highlight would be The Rasau Walk segment of the park which lights up beautifully at night. There are plenty of amenities in the park and sufficient rain shelters and vending machines that sell hot food and drinks. Accessible from Lakeside MRT and Yuan Ching Road, the park is also connected to Chinese Garden and Japanese Garden. There is a cafe in the middle, and NEA office that doubles as plant nursery, amd Active SG swimming pool. Family friendly.

One of the latest gardens added to the beautiful Singapore landscape. The garden is part of the in progress bigger Jurong Lake district. I love the Active SG Gym and public swimming pool. Small but gorgeous. You can enjoy hot showers there after a good swim !

admissionInfo: Free
body: Formerly known as Serangoon Island, Coney Island was owned by the Haw Par brothers—the duo behind the famed Tiger Balm brand—back in the early 1900s. Today the island has retained its rustic charm and is a sanctuary for a diverse range of plant and animal species. Explore the coastal forests, mangroves and various plants and flowers, some of which are critically endangered. Bird watchers can look out for resident Baya Weavers, Oriental Magpie-robins and flocks of parakeets. A popular activity among visitors is to cycle along the 2.5-kilometre Coney Island Park Connector which offers a breath-taking view of the Serangoon Reservoir. To preserve the park’s natural habitat, there is no electricity or piped water available on the island and visitors are advised to bring along a bottle of water.
description: Situated on an island off the Singapore coast, the park is great for cycling and bird-watching.
name: Coney Island Park

reviews.text:
The coast to coast trail is extremely tiring. 36 km.
Remember to bring 4 liters of water. Suntan. Good running shoes or you get blisters. Enjoy. 👌🏻
Lovely place for a day walking and cycling.... just be careful with beach flies and mosquitoes.
Greats place to enjoy the Corney Island
Great place to have a surrounding full of nature in a bustling country like Singapore.
really like this place. very tranquil

body:
Contrary to popular belief, cities are not static by nature. Every brick, every building, every street represents innumerable decisions.

At the Urban Mutations: The Changing Face of Cities at Science Centre Singapore, guests are encouraged to reflect on the active role that they need to play in building the cities of tomorrow. Spread across three themed zones, the exhibition showcases the current state of cities and urges everyone to question their urban practices, whilst exploring the stories of a few selected cities modelled around sustainability, greening, diversity and smart technologies –

CITIES UNDER PRESSURE

In this zone, the complexity of the “city” system is dissected into basic components to reveal its hidden workings, and the tensions that can arise. Here, guests can examine and reflect upon their experience.

URBAN EARTH

Through dynamic representa¬tions of maps and global data, cities around the world are visualised together in a multi-media spectacle. This gives us a planet-wide appreciation of cities from the angle of their differences or similarities too. How does your city compare against other cities globally?

URBAN FUTURES

Explore an array of urban solutions selected for their originality, specificity or exemplary character. Be amazed by initiatives and innovations undertaken by various cities and their citizens to address the urban challenges that they face.
