admissionInfo: Free
body: The Singapore Botanic Gardens (SBG), with its 82 hectares of lush landscapes, photogenic pavilions and sculptural landmarks, is Singapore’s first UNESCO heritage site. It is split into three main areas: the Tanglin Core, Central Core and Bukit Timah Core. The Tanglin Core—the oldest part of the gardens—includes a Botany Centre and the SBG Heritage Museum (Opening hours: Mon–Sun 9am–6pm), where visitors can learn about SBG’s rich heritage. Located in the Central Core tourist belt are the Nassim Gate Visitor Centre and the popular National Orchid Garden, which carries more than 60,000 plants and orchids across 1,000 species. Besides exploring the park’s open spaces, travellers can visit specialized gardens like the Ethnobotany Garden and the Centre for Ethnobotany. The garden features plants native to Southeast Asia, which are traditionally used for medicinal and craft purposes. Through interactive displays, artefacts and information panels at the centre, visitors will discover the roles plants have played in shaping the world we know today. Young visitors can cultivate a love for nature and the environment at the interactive play areas in Jacob Ballas Children’s Garden. After exploring the gardens, visitors can opt for plenty of dining options in and around the area, including the one-Michelin-starred Corner House. Happening every weekend, visitors can sign up for free monthly tours led by experienced volunteer guides to discover the different themes around the gardens. For group bookings (more than 20 pax), contact them two weeks in advance for arrangement.
description: The country’s first UNESCO World Heritage Site is a showcase of spectacular tropical flora. There are also many idyllic photo spots throughout the Gardens such as Swan Lake and The Bandstand gazebo.
name: Singapore Botanic Gardens

pricing.others: (National Orchid Garden) Adult S$5, Senior Citizen S$1; Free admission for children below 12 years

reviews.text:
Beautiful garden and huge. Good for sightseeing and exercise. Came first time about 10 years ago. It looks more green now compared to last time.

It is beautifully managed park. Loved the place. There is one garden for children inside called Jacob Ballas Garden. It has a lot of themed locations for children to learn and play.

One of the best-reserved places in Singapore. It's very well maintained and one can spend hours roaming around or just relaxing. The place is vast and probably will take you more than half a day to fully explore it. I always enjoy going here for morning runs and then treating myself to a good full-filling breakfast in one of the many award-winning restaurants located inside the garden. Recommended full time 😁.

The plants were beautiful and well maintained... nice spacious space to immense yourself in the nature. When you are down for a break, there are also various restaurants to choose from. Really enjoyed myself there... would be even better if the humidity and weather show some mercy

It's so clean and fresh. There are a lot of different sections to explore! You probably won't finish it in a day! There are quite a number of dining options and some attractions require payment. Mostly is free roaming though. There is a variety of wildlife here, I saw a monitor lizard, salamanders, wild chickens (baby chicks following the mum) and lots of birds. It's a really relaxing place. One thing to note: When it rains, the ground can get pretty slippery and might ruin your trip, most areas are not sheltered. There are pavilions around tho.

So much has changed and it is still a wondorous place to stroll and feel the sweet air. ...thanks i can still smell and feel...."not covid infected". ...Go and enjoy what nature breathing is all about...enlighten your senses with the good old faithful trees that have being there before we were born....

admissionInfo: - ^Admission Ticket to Flower Dome and Cloud Forest
body:
Explore plant life from around the world. From diverse species in the Cooled Conservatories to towering vertical gardens and much more, discover a world where wonder blooms at Gardens by the Bay.

Flower Dome - Step into the Flower Dome and stand in awe of nature. Spectacular and innovative, it is the largest glass greenhouse in the world as listed in the 2015 Guinness World Records! Be amazed by changing the display of flowers and plants from the Mediterranean and semi-arid regions.

Replicating the cool and dry Mediterranean climate, Flower Dome showcases exotic plants from five continents which are displayed in nine different Gardens. Wander amongst thousand-year-old olive trees and unusual Baobabs as you take in sights of the Flower Field Display.

Cloud Forest - Enter the Cloud Forest, a mysterious world veiled in mist. Take in breath-taking mountain views surrounded by diverse vegetation and hidden floral gems. And learn about rare plants and their fast-disappearing environment.

Explore the tropical highlands amidst orchids, pitcher plants, and ferns from the cool-moist Tropical Montane region. Be amazed as you encounter our breath-taking indoor waterfall at 30 metres and descend through the surreal mist-filled Cloud Walk and Treetop Walk.

For Booking Enquiries: 

Origin Journeys by The Traveller DMC
Contact: (65) 9665 6292 / (65) 8873 6500
Email: booking@originjourneys.com

Address: 

Gardens By The Bay
18 Marina Gardens Dr, Singapore 018953
Operating Hours: Tuesday to Sunday & Public Holiday from 9.00 AM to 8:00 PM
Closure Dates for Maintenance Cloud Forest: 21 Sep, 12 Oct, 09 Nov, 14 Dec Flower Dome: 22 Sep, 13 Oct, 10 Nov, 15 Dec
description: Explore plant life from around the world
name: Gardens by the Bay

reviews.text:
The place is beautiful with lots of plants variety to look at. Especially inside the two domes. Remember to check out the pricing online and buy the tickets online first before coming over to collect it. It will be faster this way. One of the dome has the world's tallest indoor waterfall and the place is beautiful. The other dome has various plants at different season.

Remember to check out the maintenance of the indoor waterfall for the day of your visit. I went once and it was closed.

There are other places to look around outside of the domes but usually it's too hot during the day.

There are light and music show at the supertree groves at 8pm and other timings. There are also food places nearby the supertree groves to dine at.

You can go back towards the city with a link bridge towards Marina Bay Sands (the ship like hotel).

Enjoy your day here !

You should and must visit this place at night when it comes alive with light making it quasi magical.

One of the flower domes hosts a restaurant/bar. The view from up there is breathtaking.

No need to add photos. Loads already available.. we took loads.

must seeing destination in Singapore! beautiful during the day and night!

i love this place during the day and even more during the night with all the lights ON.

I prefer to come for the light show around 20.00 or at night around 00.00 am since it wont be crowded.

It has some attraction to visit as well. The easiest way to reach by the bayfront mrt or taxi.

Its free entrance so dont worry about that!

Enjoy your day!

Spending a vacation with my beloved student to Singapore.  This place is very beautiful filled with lights on a giant tree in the garden.  At night, visitors can enjoy the view of the lake and artificial fountains and sit under a giant tree while enjoying the song of the Queen that comes out of the tree.  At 9 pm there will be very beautiful fireworks.

Whilst the light show is suspended, and for good reason. It was great to go and visit at night. Our daughter loved the twinkly lights and it was like having our own private viewing. Always lovely to go and enjoy. Especially when there's no crowds.

body: Sitting 57 floors aboveground is the Sands SkyPark with its iconic 150-metre-long infinity pool. Alongside are restaurants, bars, nightclubs and an observation deck from which to take in sweeping, 360-degree views of the city. The resort’s luxury mall, The Shoppes at Marina Bay Sands, features an extensive selection of designer boutiques, celebrity chef restaurants and dining options. The integrated resort is also home to the lotus-shaped ArtScience Museum – the first of its kind in the world – and Spectra, a kaleidoscopic outdoor light and water show that takes place nightly over the waters fronting the Event Plaza.
description: The Marina Bay Sands integrated resort comprises convention and exhibition facilities, 2,561­ hotel rooms and suites, a casino spanning four floors, and the Sands Theatre that features Broadway and West End musicals, amongst others.
name: Marina Bay Sands
notes: Exact opening hours for individual establishments can be found on the official website.

reviews.text:
Marina Bay Sands.

Nice - but overpriced for the level of accommodation, we had 3 people in a room and only supplied 2 cups for tea and coffee + 1 English breakfast tea bag and not much else, dated rooms.

Plenty of better options with more inclusions in Singapore.
Go and have a drink in the rooftop bar and admire the pool but otherwise save your money for elsewhere.

Love the quietness and cleanliness of the place even if you are not there to gamble you can still come here for some fine food or shopping alone or with family. During weekdays is really a nice place to stroll around and of course not to be missed is the new Apple store which is accessible only from the shopping floor and be ready for long winding queue just to enter, best way in is to make any appointment to visit this store that gives u priority to enter.

I did this rating 2 years ago. It was for both marina bay sands and for the convention centre. As you can see the swimming pool at the top is amazingly beautiful. The restaurants at the top are extremely expensive however and if you ever get the chance to afford it, do get the tables hanging outside - it is an amazing view (from what I saw standing at the entrance) these are just some views I managed to take from the top of marina bay sands. The convention center is tough to get around unless you're familiar with the place though since it is associated with a number of other places too and can be confusing/ get lost if you aren't sure where you are etc.

World class exhibition center at the heart of Singapore. Attached to the Marina Bay Sands Hotel, Shopes, and Casino, this really is THE destination to attend conferences where you have access to world class brands. Grab a bite to eat, step out and watch the light show, and enjoy the luxurious amenities. There's nothing quite like this place anywhere else in the world!
A Cajun  type of fried chicken with waffles And spiced watermelon. We were serviced by Joyce who introduced us Mac cheese and other surprises.
Comes on at 1030am. Great place for coffee and snacks in the morning. Spacious and peaceful.

body:
The Ann Siang Hill area is a quiet enclave amid the hustle and bustle of Chinatown. Meander through brightly coloured shophouses and gain insight into the lives of Singapore's early immigrants. Located beside the former Telok Ayer Bay, it was one of three hills (the others being Mount Wallich and Mount Erskine, which were eventually levelled) collectively known as Telok Ayer Hills.

In the early days of the settlement, clove and nutmeg plantations were established in many parts of the island, including the Ann Siang and Duxton Hill areas. Charles Scott was the first to plant these crops on Ann Siang Hill, which was originally named after him. Ann Siang Hill was superbly irrigated; an underground spring ran through the area and was tapped from a well on the hill. A series of terrible blights decimated the clove and nutmeg plantations across the island, causing my plantation owners to abandon their land.

After Scott left his plantation, it passed through the hands of another owner before being sold to Chia Ann Siang in 1894. From then on, the face of Ann Siang Hill changed forever. Shophouses sprang up; Chinese and Straits Chinese residents and businesses moved in and the area was transformed into an urban district. All that was left of the old Ann Siang Hill was Scotts' plantation house, which Chia kept as his family residence.

reviews.text: A neat raised viewing platform. Not something you would expect in the heart of town. Very small area but great place for a different scene when doing a chinatown, club street, tanjong pagar trail.
Some calm spots around this area of you've a look and many more great food places nearby these days. Go enjoy have a slow relaxing time.
It was really nice and calming. The greeneries were excellent and air felt fresher. Really enjoyed myself.
it's good for taking a stroll or sitting and reading or drinking a beer
Ok to go after dinner near china town, small hill for after meal walk

body: This Chinatown mural features the exteriors of Chinatown’s buildings along with a collage which juxtaposes the historic district against the modern cityscape and a Chinese opera singer. At the other end of the alley, a mural of a bulls and labourers pulling a cart loaded with Chinatown’s buildings pay homage to the district’s historic roots.
description: This Chinatown mural features the exteriors of Chinatown’s buildings along with a collage which juxtaposes the historic district against the modern cityscape and a Chinese opera singer. At the other end of the alley, a mural of a bulls and labourers pulling a cart loaded with Chinatown’s buildings pay homage to the district’s historic roots.
name: Bullock Cart & Chinatown Scenes &  Murals

body: Welcome to Siloso, a sunny haven where excitement takes precedence, over boredom. Home to the coolest bars and restaurants, Siloso, Singapore's hippest beach, is the beach to head to for fun-loving people – day and night. Get into your favourite bikini and take a dip. Or simply bask in the sun and admire the other hot bods. Themed bars abound - you can surf a man-made wave or chill-out in a whirlpool bath on the beach. A host of dining options awaits with tempting all-day menus from exceptional bistros and restaurants. Don't forget to try your hand at skim-boarding or kayaking, cycling, rollerblading or other exciting beach activities! After dark, Siloso really comes alive, with parties, music, lively bars and restaurants celebrating the beach lifestyle long into the night – every night.
description: 1 of 3 Golden Sandy Beaches in Sentosa
name: Siloso Beach
notes: To facilitate safe distancing, reserve your beach entry at sentosa.com.sg/beachreservations

body: One of the major Buddhist temples in Singapore, this is a fine example of the Chinese Tang dynasty style of architecture in the heart of Chinatown. As its name suggests, the museum houses a tooth relic of Buddha, as well as other revered artefacts. Built in 2007, the temple takes up the complex’s ground floor, and visitors will marvel at the rich interiors comprising paintings, statues, tapestries and other exhibits related to Buddha and Buddhism. The building also has a roof garden, a library, a vegetarian restaurant in the basement and a bookstore. Visitors can gain more insight into the Buddhist way of life during the ‘Discovering Buddhism’ class, led by resident monks. Admission to the temple is free, and complimentary tours are conducted every Saturday in English at 2pm and Mandarin at 10am.
description: The Chinese Tang dynasty-style building in the heart of Chinatown houses a tooth relic of Buddha, as well as other revered artefacts.
name: Buddha Tooth Relic Temple and Museum

reviews.text:
I was here woth my sister back may 2019. Such a solemn place. Such respect to Singaporeans maintaining the temple peaceful, solemn and calmness inside. There are museums on the 2nd and 3rd floor. On the rooftop was the huge bell.
Well filming is actually not allowed once you are inside...

Stunningly beautiful, intriguing and spiritual.   Allocate a good hour to immerse yourself and enjoy.
When i visited the roof top was closed,  however level 1 and 4 still worthwhile
History and culture come to life in this Temple. Beautiful on the inside and outside. Love the lanterns, love the buddha images. Very calming place.
Feel and vibration here is great. A must visit in Singapore.

A must place to see. Once you get in, you realize how much history you can see at one place. Very convenient location. Easy to find and reach by walk or city transit. There's a thing for all ladies. You must obey the religious and come with clothes that cover your shoulders and legs if uncovered. At the entrance you can find a very kind lady who will support you with a scarf if you have forgot about this obligation.
Many thanks for your hospitality and kindness.

body: Bruce Lee makes an appearance along the walls of Chinatown Complex, holding the iconic durian, no less. Painted by students from the school of design at Temasek Polytechnic, this cheeky mural enlivens the area with quirky elements that have come to be commonly associated with Singapore’s culture, including the aforementioned fruit. Other local touches include an Oriental dragon, curry puffs, and even an ‘I love Singapore’ singlet.
description: Bruce Lee makes an appearance along the walls of Chinatown Complex, holding the iconic durian, no less. Painted by students from the school of design at Temasek Polytechnic, this cheeky mural enlivens the area with quirky elements that have come to be commonly associated with Singapore’s culture, including the aforementioned fruit. Other local touches include an Oriental dragon, curry puffs, and even an ‘I love Singapore’ singlet.
name: Bruce Lee Mural

body: Located at the newly opened Paya Lebar Quarter Mall, this 5,000 square feet indoor playground is at the 3rd level of PLQ Mall. The playground boasts a Foam Pit, Ball Pit, Trampolines, Slides, Swings, Race Car Track, lots of climbing structures and many other elements for the kids' enjoyment! Get more information here.
description: Located at PLQ Mall, this 5,000 sqf indoor playground will sure to delight the kids!
name: SMIGY Indoor Playground
notes: Opening Hours may vary

body: Bak Kut Teh (肉骨茶) or directly translated to ‘meat bone tea’ in English is a Chinese soup commonly found in Singapore and Malaysia. Don’t be fooled by its name: the soup itself does not contain tea of any kind. One possible explanation for the name is the fact that you would drink this soup with Chinese tea. Traditionally, the dish is prepared through many hours of simmering pork ribs in a broth of pepper and garlic, amongst other herbs under charcoal fire as depicted by the 3D sticker. A popular dish in Singapore with its own heritage, every Singaporean will have their favourite Bak Kut Teh.
description: Bak Kut Teh (肉骨茶) or directly translated to ‘meat bone tea’ in English is a Chinese soup commonly found in Singapore and Malaysia. A popular dish in Singapore with its own heritage, every Singaporean will have their favourite Bak Kut Teh.
name: Bak Kut Teh 3D Floor Sticker

body: Singapore’s first permanent indoor snow centre, Snow City is a family-centric attraction with an array of activities for all ages. Explore different zones, filled with interactive arctic exhibitions, life-sized snow sculptures and slide down a thrilling 60-metre snow slope. Visitors can also hop onto bumper cars at Drift on Ice, Singapore’s coldest bumpe r car arena, and enjoy belly laughs while whizzing past other riders. For visitors who wish to challenge themselves to high elements, Snow City also houses two climbing facilities—The Cliff@Snow City Singapore and The Indoor Boulder— for them to scale.
description: Snow City offers a taste of winter in the tropical city with a sub-zero environment covered with 150 tons of powdery white snow.
name: Snow City
notes: Mon–Sun Last Admission 5pm; Public Holidays Last Admission 5pm;

pricing.others: Adult S$21, Child S$17 (1 hour snow play session + 1 hour bumper call ride)

reviews.text:
Terrible management of the place. Me and my friends bought a 2hr session online. When we reached there at 2pm, the place was full due to covid and the next available session was at 4pm. The waiting area was filled with people to the max. There wasn't even a vending machine that you can buy drinks. The chairs also looked like it needed cleaning. When it was 4pm, it was also not our turn yet because there were still people from the 3pm list. We went in only like 4.30pm and didn't really finished the 2 hour because it closes at 6. The jacket and shoes seems dirty. The gloves were also torned. The wait for the bumper car was long. The only thing that was fun was the slide.

It understandable to limit people in the place but there should be better management such as allowing pre booking of timeslot so that people don't have to wait so long or arriving with a online ticket to find out the place was full and there is no next session. The staff outside isn't very friendly or helpful either.

Not worth the time and money to go there.

The place was small to place snow with. The main place mostly used for sky and slide and was told on usual day, we can't even play there.

It wasn't that cold inside even it was below 0 degree since it is cold place only and not windy.

No camera was allowed inside. There were a quite a number of photographers inside. To take photo of us. Each photo cost you $25 with buy 2 get 1 free.

The bumper car which is located at level 2 was on maintenance.

They limit the number of people inside. There was a queue in front when we finished.

Preferably to buy the tickets online. 1pm-2pm is maintenance timing. Locker is available at $2 per one time use.

Beat the heat! Experience winter in sunny singapore. Boots and jackets will be provided. Gloves will have to be rented. It’s not a really big place but enough for a day of fun. Personal cameras and phones are not allowed so minus a star for that. Lots of parking available.

I enjoyed my time at snow city, especially in these times of sweltering heat!!! Affordable prices for admission though the photos are a real pinch. Would appreciate if we could enjoy a cuppa in the snow chamber. Doesn't need to be fancy, a vending machine would do~ I think everyone would root for an updated snow city with more activities, let's hope it happens soon!
It is super fun but too many people

body: Wild Wild Wet is one of Singapore’s largest water parks that promises thrills and spills for the whole family with 16 water rides, including seven exciting new additions. At Free Fall, visitors will plunge down one of Asia’s longest free fall water slides at speeds of up to 50 feet per second. Friends and families can race each other down the Kraken Racer, Singapore’s first four-lane mat racer slide. Families with young children can head over to Kidz Zone, a child-friendly paradise packed with kid-sized versions of Wild Wild Wet’s exhilarating rides. Life jackets and baby water carriers are free to rent at the park.
description: Beat the heat and hop on exhilarating rides  at one of the largest water parks in Singapore, Wild Wild Wet.
name: Wild Wild Wet

pricing.others: Adult S$24; Child S$18 (Off-Peak); Adult S$32; Child S$24 (Peak); Family (2 Adults & 2 Children) S$78 (Off-Peak) S$102 (Peak)

reviews.text:
First let me say that I did have fun overall, the water slides were great and it’s a nice well kept Park. I’ll go back for sure when all this covid business has passed. Unfortunately the day was tainted by small problems...

1. We bought our tickets online that had QR code. We thought this would allow us to walk straight in, but we had to queue for 20 minutes to have this converted to a piece of paper. They then didn’t have a scanner to scan my phone for this, instead I had to hand my phone to the cashier where she manually typed out the code. They will be handling hundreds of phones which is not good at all with the current covid situation.

2. We then had to queue for 30 minutes to get to the lockers. This is fine, but the locker room is absolutely huge and they allowed very limited capacity. This is ok, they’re trying to be responsible, but meanwhile there was little to no social distancing in the queue and the majority of people weren’t wearing masks due to previously being on water slides.

3. The park was very busy and the queues were 20-30 minute waits. They were implementing limited hours for certain slides and some were closed altogether. I don’t understand the logic. It would surely make more sense to have all rides open at all times to spread all the people out and prevent so many people being gathering in the same place.

4. There was an abundance of groups of >5. One group I saw was 20+, this isn’t acceptable in today’s phase. It’s hard for staff to enforce this, maybe there should be external officers to enforce this more strictly.

First time visitor and thinking about a season membership. Whilst its not in the glitz of Sentosa, this has everything you could wish for  from thrill seekers to families with young and older children. A real life saver whilst we are on holiday at home.

Now the time  to visit for the
1 for 1👍👍👍
Enough rides to enjoy with kids. Tent room to hire n enjoy in group. Locker room . But much waiting time to get on a ride. Good fun for kids .
A great place to get wild and wet!

admissionInfo: Purchase your tickets at https://www.tayostation.com/ now!
body: Tayo Station spans at a massive 10,000-square-feet-space that integrates indoor playground attractions, edutainment area and sensory play space for young children from 1 to 12 years old. Drive and zoom around the all-time favourite, Tayo's Road Circuit or climb, swing and slide in the 3-storey Gani's Playground! Other attractions include Poco's Hinoki Play, Cliff Ball Pool and many more that are created to entertain while offering a healthy level of challenge for all kids! A perfect getaway for the little captains who are always filled with energy and just love to play!
description: Indoor Themed Playground based on the popular animation "Tayo the Little Bus" located at Downtown East
name: Tayo Station

reviews.text: A fun play date of my girls with some friends! The staff were all very professional in managing safe entry, with temperatures taken and hand sanitized. Going in was seamless. The place is very large and it gives children ample space to move and run around. Especially love the miniature road with rides! A great way to learn some traffic rules for the little ones. The slides were of ideal heights, ball pits are all full and clean. Truly satisfy!

Hooray, Tayo station is back in operation again after the circuit breaker. It is so popular that appointment are all Fully booked especially on weekend.

Currently they are limiting to only 2hrs per session.

This time I decided to bring Little O for a play date. He enjoyed his play date with his classmates.

I can see that Tayo’s Station has been diligent in maintaining the hygiene via regular sanitization.

It is great to see them enjoy themselves !!

Will definitely come back again 😊
Fun place for the young ones. There's wheelers to ride on and obstacle grounds to climb and venture on.

My kids are a huge fan of Tayo Station and the moment we learn that it has reopen, we were so hyped up for a playdate with other friends. We had so much fun enjoying the various activities provided there especially the road circuit with petrol kiosk and mechanic stations. Apart from the mandatory temperature checks, i felt very safe with the extra preacuations taken to prevent overcrowding and the frequent hand sanitizing. Staff was extremely friendly and helpful.
It was so much fun that the kids were reluctant to leave the play area even after time is up. Overall, definitely a fun and safe enviornment. We recommend for parents to book in advance. We will definitely be back again!

The kiddos had their first indoor playground playdate yesterday evening and it was soo fun! My boy had always been a huge fan of tayo bus, he owns one himself. But tada! There is sooooo many there! He get to scoot ard with his friends!! Its not out first time there but definitely a better experience this time as there were capacity restrictions due to covid. So no overcrowding, no snatching and fightings! The balls at the ball pit were half the qty before covid though.... i would recommend tayo station over pororo park:)

admissionInfo: Free
body: Maghain Aboth Synagogue - which translates to “Shield of our Fathers” - is established as Southeast Asia’s oldest surviving synagogue, and visits are by appointment only. The 2-storey Jewish house of worship is easily distinguished from its neighbours by the three blue Stars of David emblazoned on the cream-coloured façade, along with its name in Hebrew. Unlike other places of worship, the prayer hall does not bear any images of gods or prophets, as this is forbidden in Judaism. A tour of the interior reveals a mix of neoclassical and colonial architecture.
description: Built in 1878, this is Southeast Asia’s oldest surviving synagogue.
name: Maghain Aboth Synagogue
notes: Visits are available only by appointment.

reviews.text:
Lovely synagogue and congregation.
Thank you for making me welcome and letting me say Kadesh, for my father, tonight.
Todah 🙏🏻
I have not been inside but the building from the outside looks lovely. Security is good and tight.
History and Tradition one of the great Jewish treasures in the world
Historic building for the Jews in S'pore

Amazing building and we'll maintained. The community has been here for almost 150 years. Albert Einstein even came to visit and raise funds from the community here to the Hebrew University. Very interesting history.

body: The Singapore City Gallery offers insights into the country’s physical transformation from fishing village to first-world metropolis. Learn about Singapore’s urban planning efforts through audio-visual and interactive exhibits spanning over three storeys. A large model of the city centre, enhanced by light and sounds, gives visitors a comprehensive overview of modern Singapore, including its landmarks and skyscrapers. The gallery’s other highlight is “A Day in Singapore” - a 270° multimedia panoramic display - that pieces together scenes of daily life in Singapore. Admission is free.
description: Learn about the urban planning efforts that tranformed the country from a fishing village into a first-world metropolis.
name: Singapore City Gallery

reviews.text: The gallery did a fantastic job displaying the past, present, and future strategies of Singapore's city planning. It is offering an engaging mixture of 3D models, interactive elements as well as images with text. Contentwise I am more than impressed by how many thoughts go into urban planning. Singapore hit a sweet spot of mixing nature with the artificial.

Free gallery exploring the development of Singapore as a city. It's definitely worth a visit. The models of the city are superb and so detailed. They have several exhibitions, and their permanent gallery has high amounts of technology implementation and interactivity. It gives you a better idea of how the city has grown and how Singapore works on a macro scale.

Probably my favorite free gallery in Singapore.  Enormous scaled maps of Singapore, great exhibits on the past, present and future of the city.  Nice rotating gallery and terrific bench-art in the URA building foyer (you'll see when you're there).  Some friends I brought there found it boring, others have spent hours there with me.  If you like maps and cities and urban planning, you'll enjoy this a lot.  Maxwell Food Centre is literally across the street if you need to refuel.

I really loved this place. Great 3D model of the whole city which you can see looking down for a great overview as well as walk around. I went there as part of a walking tour, and will return tomorrow to spend more time there because there's so much to see and learn about Singapore there

Lovely place to find out about the city planning of Singapore, including a massive model of the city area. Big pluses as well that it is free and air conditioned. It is a good afternoon stop if in the Chinatown area. The ground floor frequently has temporary exhibitions at well. Maxwell hawker centre opposite has a good selection of reasonably priced food if you get hungry during your visit.

body:
This historical mosque, began life in 1827 as a thatched hut. Its modest structure gave rise to its other name, given by its Indian Muslim congregation - Kucha Palli, meaning 'small mosque' in Tamil. The Indian-Muslim worshippers at Al-Abrar Mosque were mostly from the Coromandal Coast of Southern India, known as Chulias. Mostly traders and money changers, many settled and worked in Chinatown. The mosque was not only their spiritual refuge, but also a social venue in which the community could meet and interact.

From 1850 to 1855, the humble hut was transformed into a brick and plaster structure, with a simple Indian-Islamic theme. In 1986, extensive renovations were carried out, resulting in the mosque that stands here today. The prayer hall was extended by one floor, increasing the mosque's capacity from 300 to 800. Craftsmen, specialising in mosque architecture, where brought in to design the new elements and to ensure that blended with the old features.

Craftsmen, specialising in mosque architecture, where brought in to design the new elements and to ensure that blended with the old features.
name: Al-Abrar Mosque

reviews.text: Nice masjid that is tucked away amongst the skyscrapers
Cosy little mosque 🕌 . Looking forward to the new look after the renovations
Historical building,easy to have praying but hard to get car park.

One of the few Mosques in the midst of the busiest part of town. Not a huge building but suitable if you are in the area and just need a place to solat or seek some personal tranquility. Friday sermons are held in Tamil and Arabic mostly.
India mosque in between cafes in telor ayer, Chinatown area. I was there for shalat jumat. The imam speaking in tamil language. What a new experience i ever had

address.buildingName: Along Nicoll Drive and Changi Coast Road

admissionInfo: Free
body: This 3.3-kilometre linear park that stretches from Changi Point to Changi Ferry Terminal is lit from 7pm to 7am daily, and visitors can fish, cycle and gather for picnics or barbecues (but camping is strictly prohibited). They can also take a stroll among native trees such as the petite petai laut, from which the leaves are used to brew a traditional post pregnancy tonic. Visitors can relax and enjoy the sea view at The Seagrill Changi (www.seagrill.com.sg) or experience the hawker centre culture at the nearby Changi Village, where nasi lemak (rice cooked in coconut milk, served with an array of side dishes) and other local dishes are served late into the night. A short drive away is the Changi Ferry Terminal, from which travellers can take a short boat ride to Pulau Ubin and Chek Jawa.
description: Visitors can escape the hustle and bustle of city life while enjoying the sea view and delicious hawker food.
name: Changi Beach Park
nearestMrtStation: Pasir Ris Station / Changi Airport Station

reviews.text: This is where families get together....some picnicking...some fishing...some cycling...while children play and run around....fun time here...
A bit crowded currently and the scene is really nice. Just the people there didn't care too much and didn't really keep it clean after the visit.
Nice location but so many people camping, fishing, cycling here. There were a lot of trash in the resting area. People can u help to keep the environment clean as u enjoyed the view?
I kind of miss the sea breeze and were there for an afternoon walk and makan. Beach is clean and water as good as you can get in spore. Good for family outing and picnic away from the city.
This is a good place for relaxation with your family or friends, but you have prepare your own foods as there's no food court around. Lucky there is still toilets around.

body: Located in central downtown of Singapore, this Roman Catholic Church is the oldest in Singapore and is the seat of the current archbishop. Built in 1847, it was closed in 2013 to undergo a major restoration and reopened in November 2016. Architecture buffs will love its neoclassical look, complete with matching wooden pews, stained glass panels and 14 paintings of the Stations of the Cross. It also houses Singapore’s oldest working pipe organ, a restored Bevington and Sons organ from 1912. Interred in the church are the remains of Singapore’s first two archbishops, Michel Olçomendy and Gregory Yong, and a crypt located in the cathedral’s basement will house the remains of other bishops. The cathedral was gazetted as a national monument in 1973.
description: The grand dame, with its neoclassical look, stained glass panels and 14 paintings of the Stations of the Cross, houses Singapore’s oldest working pipe organ from 1912.
name: Cathedral of the Good Shepherd
nearestMrtStation: Bras Basah Station / City Hall Station

reviews.text: This is a beautiful Catholic cathedral which is regarded as a national monument of Singapore. Architecturally, the church is very beautiful and pleasing to the eye.

The church is very well maintained. They have morning coffee every Sunday after the 10:30 am mass. The priests give good homilies which you can practice and apply in your daily life. The ushers are friendly and accommodating. The choirs are good especially the one conducted by Dr Low.
I love  this place of worship

A grand old dame is now looking wonderful after the renovations. Masses available daily and is a center of hubbub and activity during key dates. It is also an oasis of peace and tranquility with a 24hr adoration room. Air-conditioning during masses with over-spill areas and live stream during key dates. Good community and welcoming

Beautiful holy place.  This is truly a Catholic church with beautiful figures of Jesus, Mary and Joseph.  The atmosphere was very peaceful with many kind people leaving after the Sunday evening service.

body: After the original chapel on the site of the present building was destroyed by two lightning strikes in 1852, it was torn down. In its place, a cathedral with early English Gothic influences was built. Designed by Colonel Ronald MacPherson in 1856, St Andrew’s Cathedral is Singapore’s largest cathedral and the most established Anglican place of worship. Located in the bustling Civic District, where modern Singapore began, its design pays fitting tribute to key historical figures. Stained glass windows on the apse honour Singapore’s founder, Sir Stamford Raffles, and other British officials. In 1942 during World War II, there were frequent Japanese air raids and the cathedral was used as an emergency hospital. It was gazetted as a national monument in 1973. Free guided tours on weekdays from 10.30am to 3pm are available, but do call the cathedral beforehand. The recently opened Cathedral Café, which also acts as a welcome centre, is open daily from 9am to 5pm.
description: Singapore’s largest cathedral showcases early English Gothic influences. It is located in the bustling Civic District, and its design pays tribute to key historial figures of Singapore.
name: St Andrew's Cathedral
notes: Weekend opening hours are subject to service and event timings; Closed on Public Holidays

reviews.text:
Was back here for my daughter's wedding on Oct 10, 2020 morning but under very strict restriction due to covid-19 safe distancing measures set by the church so as to comply with the government's ruling of gatherings for religious groups. We even had to comply to timing i.e. only 1 hour of solemnization, wearing of masks, and photo taking was only restricted to immediate and extended family only.
There was no buffet served after the wedding solemnization.
We were only allowed 100 pax and the rest we arranged for a Youtube live feed of the whole ceremony from the start. Fortunately, the government relaxed the rules so my husband was allowed to walk her down the aisle.
This to me was the most memorable part of a church wedding ceremony.
I'm really grateful for this really.

Tourists should check in for a day tour at SAC if they could. This is a peaceful place to seek refuge and respite during the weekday. Sincerely hope it would be a cathedral relevant to all walks of lives even in 10, 50 or 100 years time (unlike some parts of the world). Seems to observe more older folks, elderlies around during the weekend as compared to children and young adults. SAC is exceptionally busy with walk in crowds, tourists during Easter and Christmas celebrations.

As an architecture designer and urban planner, one of my past time is to visit religious buildings, cities, and obscure buildings so as to expand my understanding of people's needs and learn from the past masters and also some mistakes perhaps other had made as I would not like to repeat them. Here is one cathedral that really impressed. The serenity and peace fill me whenever I stepped into the church. All other life challenges vanish in a single moment. I love to sit quietly watching and observing. Not really sure what I was seeing, perhaps just space out.

This magnificent church in the center of Singapore is a bastion for Christians of all walks. They have traditional, contemporary, Indian and Filipino services. They have multiple chapels and the New Sanctuary church is a very cool underground church. Incredibly friendly and so easy to get to as it is literally on top of an MRT stop.

Lovely cathedral.  Pleasant cafe beside it, exit City Hall mrt.  Good chicken pie n Nasi biryani, coffee average.  Food pricing $5-6 average. Very spacious n air con as well as a few outdoor high tables. Close view of Cathedral.

body:
Great Southern Hotel was once the place for Chinese high society in the 1930s. Built by tycoon Eu Tong Sen, Great Southern was considered highly modern when it opened in 1927. Popular with high society including celebrities from Hong Kong and China, the six-storey hotel was once the tallest building in the area and was the first Chinese hotel in Singapore to boast a lift service. The hotel was designed by architectural firm Swan & Maclaren and was once regarded as the Raffles Hotel of Chinatown.

Occupying the entire fifth floor, the chic Southern Cabaret was the hotel's greatest asset. Here the glitterati would live it up. They sipped the finest liquor, smoked opium on handcrafted pipes and danced with night away. Great Southern Hotel also provided services such as the remittance of money to China, the booking of steamer tickers, luggage transfer and other travel-related services. The hotel stayed in business well past it heyday and eventually closed down in 1994.

reviews.text: A lot of China mainland product, good environment.

If not for the system limitation, this store is not worthy of a single star.
Poorly trained, rude and disgruntled staff. I was shopping on the top floor for a dining table. Took some photos to show my mom possible choices when an angry middle aged female staff abruptly stopped me from taking photos. I asked her why and she said she need to stop me before I get caught by security. Completely absurd and I asked to talk to her manager. The manager, a male middle age man behaved in a gangster-like manner and asked me in an intimidating manner if I were Singaporean and know the rules, forcing me to delete the photos off my mobile phone. Most disgusting shopping experience ever. Please avoid this place at all costs or shop at your own peril!
Lots of interesting Chinese products.

If there was a no star option, I would have given them zero star... classic example of how big business exploit customers. I ordered a bunch of goods and the stated delivery time was 3 days later. But it never came. I tried to contact them. No response. ZERO. NADA. horrible service and no responsibility.
Exciting place, can find lots of Chinese medicines..

body: Completed in 1910, the Abdul Gafoor Mosque—also known as Masjid Abdul Gafoor—took over the site and religious functions of the former Al-Abrar Mosque. The area was a lively business hub, so the mosque largely catered to South Indian merchants. One of its trustees, Abdul Gafoor, a Muslim Tamil chief clerk at a law firm back then, had built shophouses around it and collected enough income to construct a new mosque. He passed away in 1919 as the sole trustee of the mosque and its related properties. Today, Majlis Ugama Islam Singapura (MUIS)—also known as the Islamic Religious Council of Singapore—owns the mosque. Visitors may notice its unconventional symmetry and the inclusion of classic Western designs alongside Moorish details, which set it apart from other mosques. Besides being gazetted as a national monument in July 1979, it was also awarded the Architectural Heritage Award from Singapore’s Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) in October 2003 to recognise its efforts in innovative restoration and conservation works.
description: The mosque features a unique fusion of Moorish, South Indian and Western architectural designs, and it was gazetted as a national monument in 1979.
name: Abdul Gafoor Mosque

reviews.text:
The prayer hall is raised above the ground and surrounded with verandahs at the entrance and sides. It is oriented towards Mecca and thus skewed away from the lot lines and the street.
The verandahs are enclosed by a balustrade with circular and lancet-shaped openings and framed by repetitive cinquefoil arches double-framed with heavy mouldings. The bays are marked out with pilasters with ornate capitals. The wide openings give the interior an airiness that contrasts with the heavy columns in the centre of the prayer hall.
On either side of the main entrance are two graduated cinquefoil arched openings. The larger ones are nearest the entrance, while the smaller ones are further away.
The main entrance to the prayer hall is pedimented with an elaborate sundial in which the 25 rays of the sunburst are done in calligraphy. The sundial is flanked on either side by a series of pilasters and columns in miniature. The pediment above the sundial is shaped like an onion dome. The two square minarets on the left and right are complete with miniature columns and arches.
There are panels with calligraphic inscriptions in several places in the mosque, including over the entrance.
The interior of the cupola at the centre of the prayer hall is supported by four large cluster columns that form semicircular arches. Square and round calligraphic inscriptions decorate the interior of the cupola.
The cluster columns that hold up the cupola have elaborate mouldings and capitals.
From the exterior, the cupola emerges from the roof deck as a hexagonal-shaped tower that is divided into three levels and marked out with Doric pilasters.
On the first level of the tower are eight cinquefoil windows with coloured glass panes that let light through to the interior. These windows are ornamented with recessed mihrab-shaped moulding and cinquefoil arches.
The second level has pilasters and capitals and is topped by a balustrade with bottleneck balusters.
There are minarets at the corners of the hexagon. These minarets are crowned with onion-shaped domes with a crescent moon and a star at the pinnacle. The very centre of the hexagon is crowned with a large onion dome topped with a smaller onion dome. On the pinnacle is a star and crescent moon.
The corners of the front verandah have simpler and less elaborate cupolas.
The four corners of the building are anchored by large Corinthian columns in a cluster with elaborate capitals in a leaf design. The interior and exterior of the mosque have several types of columns and pilasters. They are both structural and ornamental and range from Doric to Corinthian. Columns can be paired with pilasters and pilasters are inset into columns.
The mihrab is plain. There is a narrow rectangular panel with a quotation from the Qur'an above it. Next to the mihrab is the minbar, a three-step timber staircase from which the imam leads prayers.
Above the prayer hall is a flat roof deck surrounded by a parapet wall with bottle-shaped balusters. It is topped with a line of 22 small six-level minarets crowned with onion domes, each with a crescent moon. The miniature minarets rise from the pilasters that frame the cinquefoil arched openings below
There is also a type of single-leafed window that is recessed and framed by an elaborate cinquefoil arch. It is flanked with pilasters and pedimented and has the same star-and-crescent pattern of the larger arched openings.
The ablution area in this mosque was originally a pool. This was later drained and a modern wash area put in. It is located outside at the southwest end of the mosque.
Currently mosque under reno. Men prayer hall at basement but good news its air conditioning. Looks near and tidy. May Allah make this Mosque a great mosque.
Very beautiful mosque 🕌 great architecture looks beautiful and get peaceful feelings. You can walk around or get up and enjoy panoramic views...
A beautiful masjid. Highly recommend Tamil people to come here for Jumaah. Open for visitors also, but remember to come in decent outfits!
Is a nice place of worship and you can get an coffee or tea just outside the most and local Indian delights

body:
Re-discover the wonders of science at Science Centre Singapore – a leading regional science centre in Asia that promotes interest, learning and creativity in science and technology through imaginative and immersive experiences!

After closing its doors for three months due to the Covid-19 pandemic, Science Centre Singapore and its Group of Attractions will re-open in stages, from 17 July 2020.

Science Centre Singapore, KidsSTOP™ and Omni-Theatre will operate daily till 26 July 2020. Thereafter, it will transit into a three-day week from Fridays to Sundays from 31 July 2020 until further notice. Our attractions will open from 10am to 1pm (Session A) and 2pm to 5pm (Session B) with last admission at 12.30pm and 4.30pm respectively. Meanwhile, Omni-Theatre will only be screening We Are Stars at 11.30am and 3.30pm.

To limit large gatherings and close contact over a prolonged duration, guests have to purchase their one-time entry admission tickets for either Session A or Session B online. Tickets will not be available for sale on-site.

Snow City will operate daily from 10am to 6pm till 26 July 2020 with last admission at 5pm. Thereafter, from 29 July 2020 until further notice, the attraction will transit into a five-day week from Wednesdays to Sundays from 10am to 5pm with last admission at 4pm. Tickets are available based on either an hourly basis or 2-hourly basis.

Butterflies Up-Close will re-open on 31 July 2020 and operate hourly from Fridays to Sundays from 10am to 1pm (Session A) and 2pm to 5pm (Session B) with last admission at 12pm and 4pm respectively, until further notice.

Kindly note that the Curiosity Shop, Coffee Bee snack outlet and ASTRO Shop at Science Centre Singapore will remain fully operational within the operating hours. While PocoLoco and Nooka’s Snack Bar at Snow City will be temporarily closed until further notice, Pictureworks and Shaman’s Souvenir Shop will remain fully operational within operating hours.

All attractions, including Snow City, will be closed from 1pm to 2pm for disinfection.

While much around our lives have changed, the Centre’s commitment to edu-tain our guests remain unchaged. During this time, we remain committed to prioritising the safety and well-being of all guests, partners, volunteers and staff on our campus.

GRADUAL OPENING OF EXHIBITIONS AND SHOWS

To ensure a safe experience for all guests, access to exhibitions, programmes and activities at the Science Centre Singapore and its group of attractions will be administered progressively. As such, some of our exhibits and all shows will be unavailable as we re-open in phases in line with safety guidelines. Find out more about our re-opening plans here.

As a token of appreciation for the continued support and timed session arrangement, we are offering a $5 Curiosity Voucher with every Science Centre Singapore adult ticket purchased as well as a $5 activity voucher with every KidsSTOP™ child ticket purchased from 17 to 26 July 2020.

SITE-WIDE PRECAUTIONARY MEASURES

Science Centre Singapore is SG Clean certified, a government-led and nation-wide cleanliness initiative. Apart from controlled admission capacity, we have put in place a number of enhanced measures to ensure a safe and enjoyable experience for our guests and partners:

- Safe Distancing Measures: Clearly demarcated queue lines, signages and ground markers have been administered site-wide to ensure one-metre spacing between guests.

- Mandatory Temperature Screening and Contact Tracing: All guests must have their temperatures screened and check-in and check-out via the SafeEntry system.

- Personal Hygiene Measures: Hand-sanitisers will be made available at all key access points, and guests and staff will be required to wear masks.Information signages and dedicated manpower will be deployed at various zones to strictly enforce these measures.

- Daily Disinfection Protocol: To mitigate health risks, the Centre will be closed from 1pm to 2pm to carry out thorough cleaning and disinfection.

- Erstotizer Coating: A long-term German-based disinfectant coating will be applied to high-touch points and surfaces such as push buttons, flip-covers and touch-screens, door handles and frames, turnstiles, staircase handrails, lift buttons etc. Erstotizer has been tested to be active against infections and can drastically reduce viruses, bacteria and microbes on surfaces coated with it.

UPON ARRIVAL

All guests should have their e-tickets or redemption vouchers ready for contactless scanning at the entrance. The ticketing counters will not be opened for ticket purchase. Guests are encouraged to download the TraceTogether App with the Bluetooth function on their mobile devices switched on.

DURING THE VISIT

Throughout the course of the visit, guests must maintain a safe distance of at least one-metre between their group and staff as well as others near them. Guests are strongly encouraged to maintain high standards of personal hygiene during their visit such as frequent washing and sanitising of hands while moving from one point to another. If unwell, guests should seek immediate assistance from staff. Gloves are available upon request.

In line with safety regulations, water coolers will not be available. All guests are encouraged to bring along their own water bottle. Meanwhile, do continue to take precautions, look out for one another, and seek help from our staff when necessary.

Look out for further updates on our digital platforms including Facebook and Instagram.

reviews.text: A great place for science enthusiasts! The shows are really great. The one I saw was on automation and robotics, I really loved it! If you are going on a trip to Singapore, please pay a visit to this amazing place.

Great for educational trips. Very Clean and exciting attractions! A replica of the famous Tesla Coil is showcased there. There is also an area for the kids (KidStop) if I recall. There is also monthly special themes like Insects and Dinosaur to Circus and Magic.

We went old school style, visiting the science centre! Not at all what we had 20 years ago but so glad it's still around and displaying so many science projects and displays of cool science tricks. My 6yo and 3yo definitely loved it. Omni theatre was breathtaking! So lucky it was a free entrance for Singaporeans during off peak period. Just pay for omnitheatre or the kidstop or other specialised exhibitions.

Great place to visit. So much to do and the kids had an amazing time. The 3 hour sessions due to Covid-19 are not enough to do everything so we will definitely be back. The mirror maze was a favourite with our 1yo, and our 7yo loved seeing the Tesla coil even though it wasn't running.

A cool place to learn science. It is convenient for people to visit this place as it is only a 10 minutes walk from the station. There are many topics of science being covered in this centre and has many school outreach programmes to allow students to grasp complicated science concepts.

reviews.text:
JEWEL CANOPY PARK IS AMAZING! Although quite tiring, the Manulife Sky Net and the Bouncing Net is really fun and safe. The ciew is also breathtaking even though its indoors.

For those who prefer relaxing activities, it is also nice to just take a stroll around the well designed park, decorated with all kinds of flora and fauna.

Definitely recommend!!

Great place to spend an hour here. Great with kids but only they are 110cm tall. Staff strictly adhere to the height requirement for kids for their safety. Entry ticket to the park is valid for the entire day. You may re-enter the park within the same day but not for the ticketed attractions which are limited to single entry.
Quite crowded, maybe due to the school holidays, so its hard to maintain a safe distance. The queue moves quickly though
Fun but a bit pricey for the bouncing with the 1 hour limit time

My mom and sister went to the Canopy park yesterday.

While the attractions were big fun, they encountered issues with unfriendly and doubtful staffs at the Sky Net, resulted in really unpleasant experiences.

My mom and sister did not enter Sky Net until 3:30pm, but the staffs said they have already been to the attraction at 3pm. While there is apparently system error where the blame should be on the dev team, the staffs pointed the arrow at my parent. With complete false confidence, they said their system will not have any mistake, and accused my mom for lying, saying she definitely has been there at 3pm. The staff also repeatedly asked my 8 years old sister if she has been to the attraction, giving absolutely 0 respect and trust in my mom's words. My mom is a kind woman and my sister is still small so they really couldn't talk back, had a really tough time handling the rain of accusations from the attraction staffs.

What is there to scam for? An entry? System failure is to blame the consumer? Is that the way Canopy Park and holder group operate? Where are the core values?

I urge you to not go to Sky Net if you want to avoid awful experience. Everywhere was fine but just don't go to Sky Net.

source: JEWEL CHANGI AIRPORT TRUSTEE PTE. LTD.

body: The Night Safari is the world’s first nocturnal wildlife park. Guests can catch a glimpse of animal life in habitats ranging from the Himalayan foothills to Southeast Asian jungles. The park’s four interlinked walking trails feature threatened and endangered species, such as clouded leopard. Visitors can encounter free-ranging wallabies on the Wallaby Trail. Crawling through a cave, visitors can also get close to Ridley’s beauty snakes and Asian black forest scorpions. The Creatures of the Night Show, which showcases survival instincts of nocturnal creatures, is a must-watch.
description: With more than 1,000 creatures here, you can be sure that no two nights are ever the same at Night Safari. Whether you are exploring the wildlife park by tram or by foot, your night here is set to be wild.
name: Night Safari
nearestMrtStation: Ang Mo Kio Station / Choa Chu Kang Station / Marsiling Station / Woodlands Station / Khatib Station
notes: Last admission at 10.15pm

pricing.others: Night Safari: Adult: S$57, Child: S$40 (3 - 12 years old),  Senior Citizen: S$22

reviews.text: Great experience. Visited with my brother while travelling and we both enjoyed it even though we are in our late 20s. Really good for families with young children. Staff were fun, knowledgeable and friendly. I would have loved to visit as a child. Would be nice if the ticket pricing was more competitive (or have better bundle offers with other major attractions. But I suppose as tourists it is expected and I've had the same experience in a lot of developed countries.

It was great fun.. enjoyed it fully.. don't forget to have dinner near entrance to add extra fun.. they serve really good food.. since it is dark u may miss to see few animals but overall experience was great and memorable..

Last visited about 25 years ago when it open as the world's first night safari. No major recollection except being on the tram and a deer chased our tram at one part.

Managed to spent a little bit more time here this time round and walked through 1 or 2 of the trails, I must say the trails are more interesting than the tram rides. If you can afford more time to walk, definitely take the trails as there are more interesting things to see. The trip was thoroughly interesting except for the fact that thunderstorm brought an unexpected end. Nice experience to see the animals active at night in person rather than on TV.

Get up close and observe the animals when they are most active at night. Get a voice guided tour via the tram and start on an educational safari tour. Be greeted by the deers, bears, lions, tiger, elephants .. and my personal favourite were the hyenas as i was lucky enough to hear their ‘laughter’. After the tour, you may carry on to explore on foot. I have you know, its dark. But a great load of fun.

Well-maintained and no mosquito!
We didn’t have to wait for tram ride and could see many animals. But better to wait in line early for show. Capacity is only 50 people now.  Highly recommend to visit in this period.

body: S.E.A. Aquarium at Resorts World Sentosa (RWS) is one of the world’s largest aquariums home to more than 100,000 marine animals representing 1,000 species. Featuring more than 50 diverse habitats, S.E.A. Aquarium exhibits close to 80 threatened species and a variety of beautiful corals that mirror a pristine aquatic environment. Through interactive programmes, up-close animal encounters and immersive learning journeys, S.E.A. Aquarium aims to inspire visitors to protect the world’s oceans.
companyDisplayName: RESORTS WORLD AT SENTOSA PTE. LTD.
description: Enter and explore the marine realm of S.E.A. Aquarium, home to more than 100,000 marine animals of over 1,000 species, across 50 different habitats, each one as fascinating as the next. It's a marine life experience you won’t forget.
name: S.E.A. Aquarium (Resorts World Sentosa)
notes: Operating hours are subject to change without prior notice.

reviews.text: Crowd management was excellent. The staff were all very proactive and motivated and were very ready to help. Excellent service! Even though with the safety management measures in place, I still managed to cover all the exhibits, which was great! And despite having to manage large crowds at times, the staff were chirpy and polite. 👍👍👍 The exhibits were breathtaking and tastefully done. Both adults and kids had fun!

Such an amazing and magnificent Aquarium. Such calming vibes, with the background music matching well with the atmosphere/environment. Definitely a lot of species and types of sea creatures to be seen. A lot to be learn. SEA AQUARIUM also has side activities for children, and they also have theming following the season. For example, Halloween. Really recommended. Will definitely go again!
Last time I saw Max in sea aquarium

We love the discovery pool the most. The staff there is very friendly and professional. We learn a lot from him. There are sea snails, star fishes,sea cucumber for visitors to explore,my daughter loves it!
Due to social distancing policy,remember to register/apply to enter online before you go. You can not stay at any spot for long time,and no where to rest in the aquarium. Do bring your pram if you have little one.
It is so beautiful. Well maintain. Staff there were polite n they made sure that social distancing was applied. And everyone has their mask on. Worth the trip and money well spend.

source: RESORTS WORLD AT SENTOSA PTE. LTD.

admissionInfo: Free
body: Part of the network of linked green spaces known as The Southern Ridges, HortPark is popular with joggers in the early mornings and evenings. Known as a one-stop gardening resource centre, it frequently brings together horticulture-related recreational, educational and retail activities under one green canopy. There are eight themed gardens, including Singapore’s first therapeutic garden in a public park— the Edible Garden—where visitors can learn about the culinary and medicinal uses of various plants—and the Pitter Patter Potter Garden, which is specially designed for children aged five to ten. HortPark’s signature event is Gardeners’ Day Out—held on the third Saturday of every month—and features a garden market, food bazaar, talks, workshops, fun activities for children and free walking tours. Visitors can enjoy an idyllic meal with verdant views at Vineyard restaurant (vineyardhortpark.com.sg), which also welcomes corporate events.
description: The park serves as a one-stop gardening resource centre, and also features a collection of well manicured and fantastically designed gardens.
name: HortPark

reviews.text: Tucked in amongst the skyscrapers is this gem of an educational resource for the kids and inspiration for adult gardners. The best way to get there is along the Southern Ridges walk from Mt Faber via the Henderson Waves, the Forest Trail and the Anderson Arch. So much of interest, both natural and designed by men and women. Highly recommended.

A very quiet garden to walk around. The car park is beautifully landscaped. If one is energetic can cut through the garden to go to the Kent ridge canopy walk as it connects it to the southern ridges.
C lots of veg.n seedling plants greenhouse beside hv fans n air conditioning  too.
Nice place to stroll through. Gardens were nice & toilets were clean. Cafe looked nice too, although we didn't get to stop by this time.
Beautiful garden with various plants n edible plants that is also very good educational place for anyone. Worth to explore the entire area. Do check out the trails that links to Mt Faber. It's fun!!!
